ABSTRACT	O
Distributed	B
Constraint	I
Optimization	I
-LRB-	O
DCOP	O
-RRB-	O
is	O
a	O
general	O
framework	O
that	O
can	O
model	O
complex	O
problems	O
in	O
multi-agent	O
systems	O
.	O
Several	O
current	O
algorithms	O
that	O
solve	O
general	O
DCOP	O
instances	O
,	O
including	O
ADOPT	O
and	O
DPOP	O
,	O
arrange	O
agents	B
into	O
a	O
traditional	O
pseudotree	O
structure	O
.	O
We	O
introduce	O
an	O
extension	O
to	O
the	O
DPOP	O
algorithm	O
that	O
handles	O
an	O
extended	O
set	O
of	O
pseudotree	B
arrangements	I
.	O
Our	O
algorithm	O
correctly	O
solves	O
DCOP	O
instances	O
for	O
pseudotrees	O
that	O
include	O
edges	O
between	O
nodes	O
in	O
separate	O
branches	O
.	O
The	O
algorithm	O
also	O
solves	O
instances	O
with	O
traditional	O
pseudotree	B
arrangements	I
using	O
the	O
same	O
procedure	O
as	O
DPOP	O
.	O
We	O
compare	O
our	O
algorithm	O
with	O
DPOP	O
using	O
several	O
metrics	O
including	O
the	O
induced	O
width	O
of	O
the	O
pseudotrees	O
,	O
the	O
maximum	O
dimensionality	O
of	O
messages	O
and	O
computation	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
maximum	B
sequential	I
path	I
cost	I
through	O
the	O
algorithm	O
.	O
We	O
prove	O
that	O
for	O
some	O
problem	O
instances	O
it	O
is	O
not	O
possible	O
to	O
generate	O
a	O
traditional	O
pseudotree	O
using	O
edge-traversal	O
heuristics	O
that	O
will	O
outperform	O
a	O
cross-edged	B
pseudotree	I
.	O
We	O
use	O
multiple	O
heuristics	O
to	O
generate	O
pseudotrees	O
and	O
choose	O
the	O
best	O
pseudotree	O
in	O
linear	O
space-time	O
complexity	O
.	O
For	O
some	O
problem	O
instances	O
we	O
observe	O
significant	O
improvements	O
in	O
message	O
and	O
computation	O
sizes	O
compared	O
to	O
DPOP	O
.	O

Approach	O
to	O

:	O

Experience	O
ABSTRACT	O
The	O

is	O

and	O
design	B
.	O

of	O

Restoration	O
of	O

technique	I

paper	O

edge	I

against	O

.	O

84	O
percent	O
and	O

percent	O
,	O

A	O
strategy	O
for	O
a	O

differential	B
game	I
based	O
on	O
fuzzy	O
reasoning	O

paper	O

a	O

of	O
a	O

game	I

.	O

for	O

reasoning	I

matrices	I
GSM	O
,	O
game	B
similarity	I
matrix	I
,	O
and	O

of	O

,	O

of	O

player	O
can	O

.	O
Two	O

vectors	I

.	O

.	O

systems	I

.	O

this	O

of	O

sup	O

problem	I

Games	O
machines	O
play	O
Individual	B
rationality	I
,	O
or	O

is	O
best	O

oneself	O
,	O

a	O

game	B

rationality	I

of	O

.	O

ABSTRACT	O
Dead-Reckoning	B
-LRB-	O
DR	O
-RRB-	O
is	O

to	O

for	O

Distributed	O
Multiplayer	B
Games	I

inconsistency	O
.	O

.	O

Basin	B
configuration	I
of	O
a	O
six-dimensional	B
model	I
of	O
an	O
electric	B
power	I
system	I
As	O
part	O
of	O
an	O

project	O
on	O
the	O
stability	O
of	O
massively	O
complex	O
electrical	B
power	I
systems	I

discuss	O
the	O
global	O

structure	O
of	O
contacts	O
among	O
the	O
basins	O
of	O
attraction	O
of	O
a	O
six-dimensional	O

system	O
.	O
This	O
system	O
represents	O
a	O
simple	O
model	O
of	O
an	O
electrical	B
power	I
system	I
involving	O
three	O
machines	O
and	O
an	O

bus	I
.	O

states	I
,	O

a	O

from	O

point	O
of	O

of	O
the	O
operation	O
of	O
a	O
real	O
electrical	B
power	I
system	I
.	O

the	O
aid	O
of	O
a	O
global	B
map	I
of	O
basins	O
,	O
one	O
could	O

intervention	O
strategy	O
to	O
boot	O
the	O
power	O
system	O

into	O
its	O
normal	O
state	O
.	O
Our	O
method	O
involves	O
taking	O

sections	O
of	O
the	O
six-dimensional	O
state	B
space	I
,	O

conditions	O
.	O

relations	O
among	O

basins	O
are	O
given	O
for	O
a	O
specific	O
numerical	O
example	O

that	O
is	O

choosing	O
particular	O
values	O
for	O
the	O
parameters	O
in	O
our	O
model	O

Modelling	O

.	O
We	O

as	O

.	O

.	O

systems	I

Despite	O

systems	I

analysis	B
of	I
time	I
series	I
from	O

.	O

as	O

systems	I
,	O
which	O

as	O

systems	I

points	O
in	O
time	O
.	O
Recently	O
there	O
has	O
been	O
much	O
work	O
on	O
the	O
direct	O
‘	B
bottom-up’	I
approach	I
to	O

as	O

systems	I
that	O

model	B

but	I

of	O

in	O
living	B
systems	I
[	O
8,9	O
]	O
.	O

series	I
analysis	I
of	O
these	O
systems	O
,	O
referred	O

or	O
‘	B
top-down’	I
approach	O
,	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
studied	O

detail	O
before	O
.	O
This	O
is	O

because	O
non-autonomous	B
systems	I
can	O
still	O

in	O

as	O
other	O
types	O
of	O
systems	O

deterministic	B
[	O
10	O
]	O
and	O
the	O

[	O
11	O
]	O
regime	O
.	O

,	O

is	O
now	O

that	O

type	O
of	O

new	O

framework	I
is	O
required	O
to	O

of	O
such	O
systems	O
.	O
In	O

case	O
of	O
chronotaxic	B
systems	I

Hypotheses	O
Refinement	O
under	O
Topological	O
Communication	O
Constraints	O
*	O
ABSTRACT	O
We	O
investigate	O
the	O
properties	O
of	O
a	O
multiagent	B
system	I
where	O
each	O
-LRB-	O
distributed	O
-RRB-	O
agent	O
locally	O
perceives	O
its	O
environment	O
.	O
Upon	O
perception	O
of	O
an	O
unexpected	O
event	O
,	O
each	O
agent	O
locally	O
computes	O
its	O
favoured	B
hypothesis	I
and	O
tries	O
to	O
propagate	O
it	O
to	O
other	O
agents	O
,	O
by	O
exchanging	O
hypotheses	O
and	O
supporting	O
arguments	O
-LRB-	O
observations	O
-RRB-	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
we	O
further	O
assume	O
that	O
communication	O
opportunities	O
are	O
severely	O
constrained	O
and	O
change	O
dynamically	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
mostly	O
investigate	O
the	O
convergence	O
of	O
such	O
systems	O

global	B
consistency	I
.	O
We	O
first	O
show	O
that	O
-LRB-	O
for	O
a	O
wide	O
class	O
of	O
protocols	O
that	O
we	O
shall	O
define	O
-RRB-	O
,	O
the	O
communication	O
constraints	O
induced	O
by	O
the	O
topology	O
will	O
not	O
prevent	O
the	O
convergence	O
of	O
the	O
system	O
,	O
at	O
the	O
condition	O
that	O
the	O
system	O
dynamics	O
guarantees	O
that	O
no	O
agent	O
will	O
ever	O
be	O

forever	O
,	O
and	O
that	O
agents	O
have	O

time	O
for	O
computation	O
and	O
arguments	O
exchange	O
.	O

this	O
assumption	O
can	O
not	O
be	O
made	O
in	O
most	O
situations	O
though	O
,	O
we	O
then	O
set	O
up	O
an	O
experimental	O
framework	O
aiming	O
at	O
comparing	O

MSP	O
:	O
Multi-Sequence	O
Positioning	O
of	O
Wireless	O
Sensor	O
Nodes	O
*	O
Abstract	O
Wireless	B
Sensor	I
Networks	I
have	O
been	O
proposed	O
for	O
use	O
in	O
many	O
location-dependent	O
applications	O
.	O
Most	O
of	O
these	O
need	O
to	O
identify	O
the	O
locations	O
of	O
wireless	O
sensor	O
nodes	O
,	O
a	O
challenging	O
task	O
because	O
of	O
the	O
severe	O
constraints	O
on	O
cost	O
,	O
energy	O
and	O
effective	O
range	O
of	O
sensor	O
devices	O
.	O
To	O
overcome	O
limitations	O
in	O
existing	O
solutions	O
,	O
we	O
present	O
a	O
Multi-Sequence	O
Positioning	O
-LRB-	O
MSP	O
-RRB-	O
method	O
for	O
large-scale	O
stationary	O
sensor	O
node	B
localization	I
in	O
outdoor	O
environments	O
.	O
The	O
novel	O
idea	O
behind	O
MSP	O
is	O
to	O
reconstruct	O
and	O
estimate	O
two-dimensional	O
location	O
information	O
for	O
each	O
sensor	O
node	O
by	O
processing	O
multiple	O
one-dimensional	O
node	O
sequences	O
,	O
easily	O
obtained	O
through	O
loosely	O
guided	O
event	B
distribution	I
.	O
Starting	O
from	O
a	O
basic	O
MSP	O
design	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
four	O
optimizations	O
,	O
which	O
work	O
together	O
to	O
increase	O
the	O
localization	B
accuracy	O
.	O
We	O
address	O
several	O
interesting	O
issues	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
incomplete	O
-LRB-	O
partial	O
-RRB-	O
node	O
sequences	O
and	O
sequence	O
flip	O
,	O
found	O
in	O
the	O

we	O
built	O
.	O

system	O

theoretical	O
analysis	O
,	O
extensive	O
simulation	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
two	O

systems	O
-LRB-	O
an	O
indoor	O

with	O
46	O
MICAz	O
motes	O
and	O
an	O
outdoor	O

with	O
20	O
MICAz	O
motes	O
-RRB-	O
.	O
This	O

that	O

can	O
achieve	O
an	O
accuracy	O
within	O
one	O
foot	O

event	B

.	O

-LRB-	O
anchors	O
-RRB-	O

soft	O
cost	O
-LRB-	O
events	O
-RRB-	O
,	O

localization	B
accuracy	O
.	O

Context	O
Sensitive	O
Stemming	B
for	O
Web	B
Search	I
ABSTRACT	O
Traditionally	O
,	O
stemming	B
has	O
been	O
applied	O
to	O
Information	O
Retrieval	O
tasks	O
by	O
transforming	O
words	O
in	O
documents	O
to	O
the	O
their	O
root	O
form	O
before	O
indexing	O
,	O
and	O
applying	O
a	O
similar	O
transformation	O
to	O
query	O
terms	O
.	O
Although	O
it	O
increases	O
recall	O
,	O
this	O
naive	O
strategy	O
does	O
not	O
work	O
well	O
for	O
Web	B
Search	I
since	O
it	O
lowers	O
precision	O
and	O
requires	O
a	O
significant	O
amount	O
of	O
additional	O
computation	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
context	O
sensitive	O
stemming	B
method	O
that	O
addresses	O
these	O
two	O
issues	O
.	O
Two	O
unique	O
properties	O
make	O
our	O
approach	O
feasible	O
for	O
Web	B
Search	I
.	O
First	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
statistical	O
language	B
modeling	I
,	O
we	O
perform	O
context	O
sensitive	O
analysis	O
on	O
the	O
query	O
side	O
.	O
We	O
accurately	O
predict	O
which	O
of	O
its	O
morphological	O
variants	O
is	O
useful	O
to	O
expand	O
a	O
query	O
term	O
with	O
before	O
submitting	O
the	O
query	O
to	O
the	O
search	O
engine	O
.	O
This	O
dramatically	O
reduces	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
bad	O
expansions	O
,	O
which	O
in	O
turn	O
reduces	O
the	O

of	O
additional	O
computation	O
and	O
improves	O

precision	O
at	O

time	O
.	O

,	O
our	O
approach	O
performs	O
a	O
context	B
sensitive	I
document	I
matching	I
for	O
those	O
expanded	O
variants	O
.	O
This	O
conservative	O
strategy	O
serves	O
as	O

against	O
spurious	O
stemming	B
,	O
and	O
it	O
turns	O
out	O
to	O
be	O
very	O

for	O

precision	O
.	O

word	O

handling	O
as	O

of	O
our	O
stemming	B
approach	O
,	O

experiments	O
on	O
a	O

Web	B
search	I
engine	O
show	O
that	O
stemming	B
only	O
29	O
%	O
of	O
the	O
query	O
traffic	O
,	O
we	O
can	O
improve	O
relevance	O
as	O
measured	O
by	O
average	O
Discounted	O

Gain	O
-LRB-	O
DCG5	O
-RRB-	O
by	O
6.1	O
%	O
on	O

.	O

a	I
model	I
of	I
the	I
smallest	I

.	O

)	O

for	O

/	O

a	O
suffix	B

tree	O
T/sub	O

for	O

time	I

on	O

structures	I
.	O
Farach	O
used	O
this	O
approach	O

first	O

algorithm	O
for	O

.	O

.	O

a	O
new	O
and	O

algorithm	I
based	O
on	O
a	O
coupled	B
BFS	I
-LRB-	O

search	I
-RRB-	O
.	O
Our	O

algorithm	I

A	O
network	B
simplex	I
algorithm	I
with	O
O	O
-LRB-	O
n	O
-RRB-	O
consecutive	O
degenerate	B
pivots	I
We	O
suggest	O
a	O
pivot	O
rule	O
for	O
the	O
primal	O
simplex	O
algorithm	O
for	O
the	O
minimum	B
cost	I
flow	I
problem	I
,	O
known	O
as	O
the	O
network	B
simplex	I
algorithm	I
.	O
Due	O
to	O
degeneracy	B
,	O
cycling	B
may	O
occur	O
in	O
the	O
network	B
simplex	I
algorithm	I
.	O
The	O

can	O
be	O

by	O
maintaining	O
strongly	O
feasible	O
bases	O
proposed	O
by	O
Cunningham	O
-LRB-	O
1976	O
-RRB-	O
;	O
however	O

do	O

any	O

variables	O

can	O
still	O
perform	O
an	O

long	O
sequence	O
of	O
degenerate	B
pivots	I
.	O
This	O

is	O
known	O
as	O
stalling	B
.	O
Researchers	O
have	O
suggested	O
several	O
pivot	O
rules	O
with	O
the	O
following	O
bounds	O
on	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
consecutive	O
degenerate	B
pivots	I
:	O
m	O
,	O
n/sup	O
2	O
/	O
,	O
k	O
-LRB-	O
k	O
+	O
1	O
-RRB-	O
/	O
2	O
,	O
where	O
n	O
is	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
nodes	O
in	O
the	O
network	O
,	O
m	O
is	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
arcs	O
in	O
the	O
network	O
,	O
and	O
k	O
is	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
degenerate	O
arcs	O
in	O
the	O
basis	O
.	O
-LRB-	O
Observe	O
that	O
k	O
<	O
or	O
=	O
n.	O
-RRB-	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O

describe	O
an	O

rule	I
that	O

at	O

pivots	I
.	O
This	O

a	O
negative	B
cost	I
augmenting	I
cycle	I
to	O

of	O
entering	O
variables	O

In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O

algorithms	B
for	I

.	I

.	O

feature	O

ABSTRACT	O
With	O
the	O
overwhelming	O
volume	O
of	O
online	O
news	O
available	O
today	O

is	O
an	O

need	O
for	O
automatic	B
techniques	I
to	O
analyze	O
and	O
present	O
news	O
to	O

user	O
in	O
a	O

.	O

research	O

only	O
on	O

news	O

their	O
topics	O

a	O

.	O
We	O
believe	O

topic	O
quickly	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
work	O

we	O
attempt	O
to	O
capture	O
the	O
rich	O
structure	O
of	O
events	B
and	O
their	O
dependencies	B

event	B
models	O
.	O

of	O

dependencies	B

.	O

a	O

on-topic	O

.	O

.	O

of	O

.	O

among	O

.	O

of	O

process	I

and	O
time	B

.	O

management	I

.	O

large	B

transient	B
buffer	I

of	O

.	O

transient	B

probability	I

by	O

ABSTRACT	O
This	O
paper	O

a	O

for	O
automated	B
negotiation	I
between	O
two	O
agents	O
.	O

suppose	O
an	O
agent	O
who	O

base	O

by	O

logic	B
program	I
.	O

of	O

an	O
agent	O
.	O

we	O

of	O
extended	B
abduction	I
in	O

intelligence	O
and	O

in	O

.	O

respectively	O
used	O
for	O
producing	O
conditional	B
proposals	I
and	O
neighborhood	O

.	O

of	O

for	O

.	O

technology	I
and	O

Hidden-Action	O
in	O
Multi-Hop	B
Routing	B
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
multi-hop	B
networks	O
,	O
the	O
actions	O
taken	O
by	O
individual	O
intermediate	O
nodes	O
are	O
typically	O
hidden	O
from	O
the	O
communicating	O
endpoints	O
;	O
all	O
the	O
endpoints	O
can	O
observe	O
is	O
whether	O
or	O
not	O
the	O
end-to-end	O
transmission	O
was	O
successful	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
absence	O
of	O
incentives	B
to	O
the	O
contrary	O
,	O
rational	O
-LRB-	O
i.e.	O
,	O
selfish	O
-RRB-	O
intermediate	B
nodes	I
may	O
choose	O
to	O
forward	O
packets	O
at	O
a	O
low	O
priority	B
or	O
simply	O
not	O
forward	O
packets	O
at	O
all	O
.	O
Using	O
a	O
principal-agent	O
model	O

we	O
show	O
how	O
the	O
hidden-action	O
problem	O
can	O
be	O
overcome	O
through	O
appropriate	O
design	O
of	O
contracts	B
,	O
in	O
both	O
the	O
direct	O
-LRB-	O
the	O
endpoints	B
contract	B
with	O
each	O
individual	O
router	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
recursive	O
-LRB-	O
each	O
router	O
contracts	B
with	O
the	O
next	O
downstream	O
router	O
-RRB-	O
cases	O
.	O
We	O
further	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
per-hop	O
monitoring	O
does	O
not	O
necessarily	O
improve	O
the	O
utility	O
of	O
the	O
principal	O
or	O
the	O
social	O
welfare	O
in	O
the	O
system	O
.	O

addition	O
,	O
we	O
generalize	O
existing	O
mechanisms	B
that	O
deal	O
with	O
hidden-information	O

ABSTRACT	O
In	O
online	O
,	O
dynamic	O
environments	O
,	O
the	O
services	B
requested	O
by	O
consumers	O
may	O
not	O
be	O
readily	O
served	O
by	O
the	O
providers	O
.	O
This	O
requires	O
the	O
service	B
consumers	O
and	O
providers	O
to	O
negotiate	B
their	O
service	B
needs	O
and	O
offers	O
.	O
Multiagent	O
negotiation	B
approaches	O
typically	O
assume	O
that	O
the	O
parties	O
agree	O
on	O
service	B
content	O
and	O
focus	O
on	O
finding	O
a	O
consensus	O
on	O
service	B
price	B
.	O
In	O
contrast	O
,	O
this	O
work	O
develops	O
an	O
approach	O
through	O
which	O
the	O
parties	O
can	O
negotiate	B
the	O
content	O
of	O
a	O
service	B
.	O
This	O
calls	O
for	O
a	O
negotiation	B
approach	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
parties	O
can	O
understand	O
the	O
semantics	O
of	O
their	O
requests	O
and	O
offers	O
and	O
learn	O
each	O
other	O
's	O
preferences	O
incrementally	O
over	O
time	O
.	O
Accordingly	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
an	O
architecture	O
in	O
which	O
both	O
consumers	O
and	O
producers	O
use	O
a	O
shared	O
ontology	B
to	O
negotiate	B
a	O
service	B
.	O
Through	O
repetitive	O
interactions	O
,	O
the	O
provider	O
learns	O
consumers	O
'	O
needs	O
accurately	O
and	O
can	O
make	O
better	O
targeted	O
offers	O
.	O
To	O
enable	O
fast	O
and	O
accurate	O
learning	O
of	O
preferences	O
,	O
we	O
develop	O
an	O
extension	O
to	O
Version	O
Space	O
and	O
compare	O
it	O
with	O
existing	O

techniques	O
.	O

a	O

for	O
measuring	O
semantic	B

between	O
services	B
and	O

our	O
approach	O
using	O
different	O
similarity	B
metrics	I
.	O

ABSTRACT	O
Often	O

of	O
the	O
preferences	O

by	O
a	O
group	O
of	O
agents	O
.	O

is	O
that	O

may	O

.	O
Mechanism	B
design	I
is	O

.	O

automated	B
mechanism	I
design	I
--	O

is	O

for	O

hand	O
.	O

.	O

The	O
LOGIC	O
Negotiation	B
Model	O
ABSTRACT	O

-LRB-	O
LOGIC	O
-RRB-	O
.	O

model	O

two	O

of	O

-RRB-	O

-RRB-	O
.	O

five	O
LOGIC	O
dimensions	O
.	O

between	O
these	O
matrices	O
.	O

relationship	O

a	O
target	O

for	O
each	O
relationship	O
that	O
an	O
agent	O

.	O

.	O

Network	B
Monitors	I
and	O
Contracting	O
Systems	O
:	O
Competition	O
and	O
Innovation	O
ABSTRACT	O
Today	O
's	O
Internet	O
industry	O
suffers	O
from	O
several	O
well-known	O
pathologies	O
,	O
but	O
none	O
is	O
as	O
destructive	O
in	O
the	O
long	O
term	O
as	O
its	O
resistance	O
to	O
evolution	O
.	O
Rather	O
than	O
introducing	O
new	O
services	O
,	O
ISPs	O
are	O
presently	O
moving	O
towards	O
greater	O
commoditization	B
.	O
It	O
is	O
apparent	O
that	O
the	O
network	O
's	O
primitive	O
system	O
of	O
contracts	B
does	O
not	O
align	O
incentives	B
properly	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
identify	O
the	O
network	O
's	O
lack	O
of	O
accountability	O

a	O
fundamental	O
obstacle	O
to	O
correcting	O
this	O
problem	O
:	O

economic	O
model	O

argue	O
that	O
optimal	O
routes	O
and	O
innovation	B
are	O

new	O
monitoring	B
capability	O
is	O

and	O
incorporated	O
with	O
the	O
contracting	B
system	O
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
we	O
derive	O
the	O
minimum	O
requirements	O
a	O
monitoring	B
system	O
must	O
meet	O
to	O
support	O
first-best	O
routing	O
and	O
innovation	B
characteristics	O
.	O

work	O

not	O

a	O
new	O
protocol	O

the	O
factors	O
that	O
influence	O
innovation	B
.	O

Deterministic	B
single-photon	I
source	I
for	O
distributed	B
quantum	I
networking	I
A	O
sequence	O
of	O
single	O
photons	O
is	O
emitted	O
on	O
demand	O
from	O
a	O
single	B
three-level	I
atom	I
strongly	O
coupled	O
to	O
a	O
high-finesse	B
optical	I
cavity	I
.	O
The	O
photons	O
are	O
generated	O
by	O
an	O
adiabatically	B
driven	I
stimulated	I
Raman	I
transition	I
between	O
two	O
atomic	O
ground	O
states	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
vacuum	B
field	I
of	O
the	O
cavity	O
stimulating	O
one	O
branch	O
of	O
the	O
transition	O
,	O
and	O
laser	O
pulses	O
deterministically	O
driving	O
the	O
other	O
branch	O
.	O
This	O
process	O
is	O
unitary	O
and	O
therefore	O
intrinsically	O
reversible	O
,	O

Schedulability	O
analysis	O
of	O
real-time	O
traffic	O
in	O
WorldFIP	B
networks	I
:	O
an	O
integrated	O
approach	O
The	O
WorldFIP	O
protocol	O
is	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
profiles	O
that	O
constitute	O
the	O
European	O
fieldbus	O
standard	O
EN-50170	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
particularly	O
well	O
suited	O
to	O
be	O
used	O
in	O
distributed	B
computer-controlled	I
systems	I
where	O
a	O
set	O
of	O
process	O
variables	O
must	O
be	O
shared	O
among	O
network	O
devices	O
.	O
To	O
cope	O
with	O
the	O
real-time	O
requirements	O
of	O
such	O
systems	O
,	O
the	O
protocol	O
provides	O
communication	B
services	I
based	O
on	O
the	O
exchange	O
of	O
periodic	O
and	O
aperiodic	O
identified	O
variables	O
.	O
The	O
periodic	O
exchanges	O
have	O
the	O
highest	O
priority	O
and	O
are	O
executed	O
at	O
run	O
time	O
according	O
to	O
a	O
cyclic	O
schedule	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
respective	O
schedulability	O
can	O
be	O
determined	O
at	O
pre-run-time	O
when	O
building	O
the	O
schedule	O
table	O
.	O
Concerning	O
the	O
aperiodic	B
exchanges	I
,	O
the	O
situation	O
is	O
different	O
since	O
their	O
priority	O
is	O
lower	O
and	O
they	O
are	O
bandied	O
according	O
to	O
a	O
first-come-first-served	B
policy	I
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
a	O
response-time-based	O
schedulability	O
analysis	O
for	O
the	O
real-time	O
traffic	O
is	O
presented	O
.	O
Such	O
analysis	O
considers	O
both	O
types	O
of	O
traffic	O
in	O
an	O
integrated	O
way	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
their	O
priorities	O
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
a	O
fixed-priorities-based	O
policy	O
is	O
also	O
used	O
to	O
schedule	O
the	O
periodic	O
traffic	O
.	O
The	O
proposed	O
analysis	O
represents	O
an	O
improvement	O
relative	O
to	O
previous	O
work	O
and	O
it	O
can	O
be	O
evaluated	O
online	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
a	O
traffic	B
online	I
admission	I
control	I
.	O
This	O
feature	O
is	O
of	O
particular	O
importance	O
when	O
a	O
planning	O
scheduler	O
is	O
used	O
,	O
instead	O
of	O
the	O
typical	O
offline	O
static	O
scheduler	O
,	O
to	O
allow	O
online	O
changes	O
to	O
the	O
set	O
of	O
periodic	B
process	I
variables	I

The	O

cultures	I

``	O

opportunity	I
''	O

Approximate	B
and	O

Multi-Issue	O
Negotiation	B
ABSTRACT	O
This	O
paper	O
analyzes	O
bilateral	O
multi-issue	O
negotiation	B
between	O
selfinterested	O
autonomous	O
agents	O
.	O
The	O
agents	O
have	O
time	B
constraints	I
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
both	O
deadlines	O
and	O
discount	O
factors	O
.	O
There	O
are	O
m	O
>	O
1	O
issues	O
for	O
negotiation	B
where	O
each	O
issue	O
is	O
viewed	O
as	O
a	O
pie	O
of	O
size	O
one	O
.	O
The	O
issues	O
are	O
``	O
indivisible	O
''	O
-LRB-	O
i.e.	O
,	O
individual	O
issues	O
can	O
not	O
be	O
split	O
between	O
the	O
parties	O
;	O
each	O
issue	O
must	O
be	O
allocated	O
in	O
its	O
entirety	O
to	O
either	O
agent	O
-RRB-	O
.	O
Here	O
different	O
agents	O
value	O
different	O
issues	O
differently	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
the	O
problem	O
is	O
for	O
the	O
agents	O
to	O
decide	O
how	O
to	O

the	O
issues	O
between	O
themselves	O
so	O
as	O
to	O
maximize	O
their	O
individual	O
utilities	O
.	O
For	O
such	O
negotiations	B
,	O
we	O
first	O
obtain	O
the	O
equilibrium	B
strategies	B
for	O
the	O
case	O
where	O
the	O
issues	O
for	O
negotiation	B
are	O
known	O
a	O
priori	O
to	O
the	O
parties	O
.	O
Then	O
,	O
we	O
analyse	O
their	O
time	O
complexity	O
and	O
show	O
that	O
finding	O
the	O
equilibrium	B
offers	O
is	O
an	O
NP-hard	O
problem	O
,	O
even	O
in	O
a	O
complete	O
information	O
setting	O
.	O
In	O
order	O
to	O
overcome	O
this	O
computational	O
complexity	O
,	O
we	O
then	O
present	O
negotiation	B
strategies	B
that	O
are	O
approximately	B
optimal	O
but	O
computationally	O
efficient	O
,	O

Inverse	B

stable	I

(	O

.	O

(	O

.	O

Securing	O
the	O
Internet	O
routing	B
infrastructure	I

and	O

and	O

systems	I

.	O

A	O
Semantic	B
Approach	O
to	O
Contextual	B
Advertising	I
ABSTRACT	O
Contextual	B
advertising	I
or	O
Context	O
Match	B
-LRB-	O
CM	O
-RRB-	O
refers	O
to	O
the	O
placement	O
of	O
commercial	O
textual	O
advertisements	O
within	O
the	O
content	O
of	O
a	O
generic	O
web	O
page	O
,	O
while	O
Sponsored	O
Search	O
-LRB-	O
SS	O
-RRB-	O
advertising	O
consists	O
in	O
placing	O
ads	O
on	O
result	O
pages	O
from	O
a	O
web	O
search	O
engine	O
,	O
with	O
ads	O
driven	O
by	O
the	O
originating	O
query	O
.	O
In	O
CM	O
there	O
is	O
usually	O
an	O
intermediary	O
commercial	O
ad-network	O
entity	O
in	O
charge	O
of	O
optimizing	O
the	O
ad	O
selection	O
with	O
the	O
twin	O
goal	O
of	O
increasing	O
revenue	O
-LRB-	O
shared	O
between	O
the	O
publisher	O
and	O
the	O
ad-network	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
improving	O
the	O
user	O
experience	O
.	O
With	O
these	O
goals	O
in	O
mind	O
it	O
is	O
preferable	O
to	O
have	O
ads	B
relevant	I
to	O
the	O
page	O
content	O
,	O
rather	O
than	O
generic	O
ads	O
.	O
The	O
SS	O
market	O
developed	O
quicker	O
than	O
the	O
CM	O
market	O
,	O
and	O
most	O
textual	O
ads	O
are	O
still	O
characterized	O
by	O
``	O
bid	O
phrases	O
''	O
representing	O
those	O
queries	O
where	O
the	O
advertisers	O
would	O
like	O
to	O
have	O
their	O
ad	O
displayed	O
.	O
Hence	O
,	O
the	O
first	O
technologies	O
for	O
CM	O
have	O
relied	O
on	O
previous	O
solutions	O
for	O
SS	O
,	O
by	O
simply	O
extracting	O
one	O
or	O
more	O

from	O
the	O

page	O
content	O
,	O
and	O

ads	O
corresponding	O
to	O
searches	O
on	O
these	O

,	O
in	O
a	O
purely	O

.	O
However	O
,	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
vagaries	O
of	O

,	O
and	O
the	O
lack	O
of	O
context	O
,	O
this	O
approach	O
leads	O
to	O
many	O
irrelevant	O
ads	O
.	O
To	O

problem	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O

system	O
for	O
contextual	O
ad	O
matching	B
based	O
on	O

.	O

ABSTRACT	O

.	O

architecture	O

of	O
distributed	O

that	O

to	O
game	O

Method	O

.	O

is	O
applied	O
to	O
optimal	B
design	I
problems	I
to	O
provide	O
a	O

for	O

.	O

.	O

of	O

.	O

,	O

quadtree	I
models	O

.	O
1	O
.	O

problem	I
-LRB-	O

.	O
The	O
total	O

of	O

in	O
this	O
setup	O

,	O

.	O

in	O

.	O

Adaptive	B
scheduling	I
of	O
batch	B
servers	I
in	O
flow	B
shops	I
Batch	B
servicing	I
is	O
a	O
common	O
way	O
of	O
benefiting	O
from	O
economies	O
of	O
scale	O
in	O
manufacturing	B
operations	I
.	O
Good	O
examples	O
of	O
production	B
systems	I
that	O
allow	O
for	O
batch	O
processing	O
are	O
ovens	B
found	O
in	O
the	O
aircraft	B
industry	I
and	O
in	O
semiconductor	B
manufacturing	I
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
study	O
the	O
issue	O
of	O
dynamic	B
scheduling	I
of	O
such	O
systems	O
within	O
the	O
context	O
of	O
multi-stage	O
flow	B
shops	I
.	O
So	O
far	O
,	O
a	O
great	O
deal	O
of	O
research	O
has	O
concentrated	O
on	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
control	B
strategies	I
,	O
which	O
only	O
address	O
the	O
batch	O
stage	O
.	O
This	O
paper	O
proposes	O
an	O
integral	B
scheduling	I
approach	I
that	O
also	O
includes	O
succeeding	O
stages	O
.	O
In	O

we	O
aim	O
for	O
shop	B
optimization	I
,	O
instead	O
of	O

performance	O

stage	O
.	O
Our	O

strategy	I
adapts	O
its	O
scheduling	O

to	O
shop	O
status	O
,	O
which	O
includes	O
information	O
on	O
a	O

of	O

arrivals	I
.	O
In	O

flow	B
shop	I
,	O

.	O

.	O

servers	I
approach	O
for	O
large-scale	B
secure	I

-LRB-	O

-RRB-	O

.	O

.	O

Normative	B
System	I
Games	O
ABSTRACT	O
We	O
develop	O
a	O
model	O
of	O
normative	B
systems	I
in	O
which	O
agents	O
are	O
assumed	O
to	O
have	O
multiple	O
goals	B
of	O
increasing	O
priority	O
,	O
and	O
investigate	O
the	O
computational	O
complexity	O
and	O
game	O
theoretic	O
properties	O
of	O
this	O
model	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
underlying	O
model	O
of	O
normative	B
systems	I
,	O
we	O
use	O
Kripke	B
structures	I
to	O
represent	O
the	O
possible	O
transitions	O
of	O
a	O
multiagent	O
system	O
.	O
A	O
normative	B
system	I
is	O
then	O
simply	O
a	O
subset	O
of	O
the	O
Kripke	B
structure	I
,	O
which	O
contains	O
the	O
arcs	O
that	O
are	O
forbidden	O
by	O
the	O
normative	B
system	I
.	O
We	O
specify	O
an	O
agent	O
's	O
goals	B
as	O
a	O
hierarchy	O
of	O
formulae	O
of	O
Computation	B
Tree	I
Logic	I
-LRB-	O
CTL	O
-RRB-	O
,	O
a	O
widely	O
used	O
logic	O
for	O
representing	O
the	O
properties	O
of	O
Kripke	O
structures	O
:	O
the	O
intuition	O
is	O
that	O
goals	O
further	O
up	O
the	O
hierarchy	O
are	O
preferred	O
by	O
the	O
agent	O
over	O
those	O
that	O
appear	O
further	O
down	O
the	O
hierarchy	O
.	O
Using	O
this	O
scheme	O
,	O
we	O
define	O
a	O
model	O
of	O
ordinal	B
utility	I
,	O
which	O
in	O
turn	O
allows	O
us	O
to	O
interpret	O
our	O
Kripke-based	O
normative	B
systems	I
as	O
games	B
,	O
in	O

agents	O
must	O

with	O
the	O
normative	B
system	I

.	O

then	O

computational	B
complexity	I
of	O
a	O

ABSTRACT	O
In	O
a	O
future	O
networked	O
physical	O
world	O
,	O
a	O
myriad	O
of	O
smart	B
sensors	I
and	O
actuators	O
assess	O
and	O
control	O
aspects	O
of	O
their	O
environments	O
and	O
autonomously	O
act	O
in	O
response	O
to	O
it	O
.	O
Examples	O
range	O
in	O
telematics	O
,	O
traffic	O
management	O
,	O
team	O
robotics	O
or	O
home	O
automation	O
to	O
name	O
a	O
few	O
.	O
To	O
a	O
large	O
extent	O
,	O
such	O
systems	O
operate	O
proactively	O
and	O
independently	O
of	O
direct	O
human	O
control	O
driven	O
by	O
the	O
perception	O
of	O
the	O
environment	O
and	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
organize	O
respective	O
computations	O
dynamically	O
.	O
The	O
challenging	O
characteristics	O
of	O
these	O
applications	O
include	O
sentience	O
and	O
autonomy	O
of	O
components	O
,	O
issues	O
of	O
responsiveness	O
and	O
safety	O
criticality	O
,	O
geographical	O
dispersion	O
,	O
mobility	O
and	O
evolution	O
.	O
A	O
crucial	O
design	O
decision	O
is	O
the	O
choice	O
of	O
the	O
appropriate	O
abstractions	O
and	O
interaction	O
mechanisms	O
.	O
Looking	O
to	O
the	O
basic	O
building	O
blocks	O
of	O
such	O
systems	O
we	O
may	O
find	O
components	O
which	O
comprise	O
mechanical	O
components	O
,	O
hardware	O
and	O
software	O
and	O
a	O
network	O
interface	O
,	O
thus	O
these	O
components	O
have	O
different	O
characteristics	O
compared	O
to	O
pure	O
software	O
components	O
.	O
They	O
are	O
able	O
to	O
spontaneously	O
disseminate	O
information	O
in	O
response	O
to	O
events	O
observed	O
in	O
the	O
physical	O
environment	O
or	O
to	O
events	O
received	O
from	O
other	O
component	O
via	O
the	O
network	O
interface	O
.	O
Larger	O
autonomous	O
components	O
may	O
be	O
composed	O
recursively	O
from	O
these	O
building	O
blocks	O
.	O
The	O
paper	O
describes	O
an	O
architectural	O
framework	O
and	O
a	O
middleware	O
supporting	O
a	O
component-based	O
system	O
and	O
an	O
integrated	O
view	O
on	O
events-based	O
communication	O
comprising	O
the	O
real	O
world	O
events	O
and	O
the	O
events	O
generated	O
in	O
the	O
system	O
.	O
It	O
starts	O
by	O
an	O
outline	O
of	O
the	O
component-based	O
system	O
construction	O
.	O

generic	B
event	I
architecture	I
GEAR	O
is	O
introduced	O
which	O
describes	O
the	O
event-based	O

between	O
the	O
components	O

event	O
layer	O
.	O

channels	O

.	O

interactions	O
through	O

.	O

which	O

needs	O

to	O

quality	O

.	O

On-line	B
robust	I
processing	I
techniques	I
for	O
elimination	O
of	O
measurement	O
drop-out	O
When	O
processing	O
measurement	O
data	O
,	O

is	O
usually	O
assumed	O
that	O
some	O

of	O
normally	B
distributed	I
measurement	I
noise	I
is	O
present	O
.	O
In	O
some	O

,	O
outliers	O
are	O
present	O
in	O
the	O
measurements	O

the	O
noise	O
is	O
far	O
from	O
normally	O
distributed	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
case	O
classical	B
least-squares	I
procedures	I
for	O

Fourier	B
spectra	I
-LRB-	O
or	O
derived	O

frequency	B
response	I
function	I
-RRB-	O
can	O
give	O
results	O

are	O
inaccurate	O

useless	O
.	O

this	O
paper	O

of	O
measurement	B
outliers	I

.	O

A	O

ABSTRACT	O
We	O
propose	O
t	O
,	O

index	O
for	O

of	O
point-distribution	O
.	O
t	O
is	O

minimum	O
distance	O
between	O
each	O
pair	O
of	O
points	O
normalized	O
by	O
the	O
average	O
distance	O
between	O
each	O
pair	O
of	O
points	O
.	O
We	O
find	O
that	O
a	O

of	O
points	O
that	O
achieve	O
a	O
maximum	O
value	O
of	O
t	O
result	O
in	O

honeycomb	B
structure	I
.	O

propose	O
that	O
t	O
can	O

as	O

good	O

evaluate	O
the	O

of	O

points	O

coverage-related	O

sensor	I

-LRB-	O
WSNs	O
-RRB-	O
.	O

idea	O

problem	O
for	O

.	O

t	O
at	O

to	O

algorithm	O
called	O

.	O

HEW	O
selects	O
network	B
management	I
software	I
For	O

,	O
Hamburgische	B
Electricitats-Werke	I
AG	O
-LRB-	O
HEW	O
-RRB-	O

provided	O
a	O

to	O

Hamburg	B
,	O
Germany	B
.	O

,	O

system	I
-LRB-	O
DMS	O
-RRB-	O

.	O

.	O

,	O

Oyj	I

to	O
integrate	O
future	O
applications	O

Optimization	O
of	O
requantization	O
parameter	O
for	O
MPEG	O
transcoding	O
This	O
paper	O
considers	O
transcoding	O
in	O
which	O
an	O
MPEG	O
stream	O
is	O
converted	O
to	O
a	O
low-bit-rate	B
MPEG	I
stream	I
,	O
and	O
proposes	O
a	O
method	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
transcoding	B
error	I
can	O
be	O
reduced	O
by	O
optimally	O
selecting	O
the	O
quantization	O
parameter	O
for	O
each	O
macroblock	B
.	O
In	O
transcoding	O
with	O
a	O
low	O
compression	B
ratio	I
,	O
it	O
is	O
crucial	O
to	O
prohibit	O
transcoding	O
with	O
a	O
requantization	O
parameter	O
which	O
is	O
1	O
to	O
2	O
times	O
the	O
quantization	O
parameter	O
of	O
the	O
input	O
stream	O
.	O
Consequently	O
,	O
as	O
the	O
first	O
step	O
,	O
an	O
optimization	O
method	O
for	O

somehow	O
.	O

Unifying	O
Distributed	O
Constraint	B
Algorithms	B
in	O
a	O
BDI	B
Negotiation	B
Framework	O
ABSTRACT	O
This	O
paper	O
presents	O
a	O
novel	O
,	O
unified	O
distributed	O
constraint	B
satisfaction	O
framework	O
based	O
on	O
automated	O
negotiation	B
.	O
The	O
Distributed	O
Constraint	B
Satisfaction	O
Problem	O
-LRB-	O
DCSP	O
-RRB-	O
is	O
one	O
that	O
entails	O
several	O
agents	O
to	O
search	O
for	O
an	O
agreement	O

which	O

.	O

Remote	B

to	O

*	O
ABSTRACT	O

.	O

Fractional	B
motion	I
control	I
:	O
application	O
to	O

cutting	I
table	I

.	O
A	O

to	O
path	O
tracking	O
using	O
fractional	B
differentiation	I
is	O
proposed	O

its	O

cutting	I

.	O

of	O
optimal	B

minimum	B

and	O

system	I

differentiation	I
is	O

here	O

a	O

filter	I
.	O
A	O
methodology	O

at	O
improving	O
the	O
accuracy	O
especially	O
on	O

is	O
presented	O
.	O

reference-input	O
obtained	O
is	O
compared	O
with	O
spline	B
function	I
.	O
Both	O
are	O
applied	O
to	O
an	O
XY	B
cutting	I
table	I
model	O
and	O
actuator	B
outputs	O
compared	O

One	O
surface	O
was	O
then	O
polished	O
and	O
cleaned	O
using	O
a	O
protocol	O
designed	O
to	O
eliminate	O
as	O
much	O
preparation-related	O
contamination	O
as	O
possible	O
.	O
This	O
is	O
as	O
follows	O
:	O
The	O
lead	O
surface	O
was	O
polished	O
by	O
hand	O
using	O
a	O
damp	B
abrasive	I
disc	I
(	O
BuehlerMet	O
II	O
®)	O
to	O
remove	O
visible	O
surface	B
defects	O
and	O
to	O
expose	O
a	O
fresh	O
metal	B
surface	I
.	O
Coupons	O
were	O
then	O
polished	O
using	O
a	O
sequence	O
of	O
diamond	B

ABSTRACT	O

An	O

sound	B
wall	I
system	I

the	O

sound	I
walls	I
.	O
The	O
wall	B
system	I
(	O
denoted	O
as	O
flexi-wall	B
)	O
consists	O
of	O
stay-in-place	B
poly-blocks	I
as	O
formwork	O
,	O
light	B
polyurethane	I
foam	I
(	O
LPF	B
)	O
reinforced	O
with	O
steel	B
rebars	I
as	O
structural	B
cores	I
and	O
polyurea	B
as	O
a	O
coating	B
of	O
the	O
wall	B
surfaces	I
(	O
Fig.	O
1	O
)	O
.	O
Poly-blocks	B
are	O
interlocking	B
light-weight	I
blocks	I
which	O
are	O
stacked	O
up	O
layer	O
by	O
layer	O
and	O
act	O
as	O
formwork	O
for	O
the	O
LPF	B
cores	I
.	O
The	O
poly-block	B
is	O
20	O
×	O
20	O
×	O
80cm3	O
and	O
includes	O
four	O
cylindrical	B
voids	I
with	O
14cm	O
diameter	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
made	O
of	O
molded	B
low-density	I
polyurethane	I
and	O
weighs	O
approximately	O
1kg	O
.	O
The	O
poly-blocks	B
are	O
fire-resistant	B
blocks	I
and	O
have	O
an	O
excellent	O
capability	O
to	O
absorb	B
,	O
mitigate	B
and	O
reflect	B
a	O
wide	O
range	O
of	O
noises	O
with	O
unmatched	O
frequency	O
of	O
reflective	O
noise	O
.	O
Polyurea	B
coating	I
is	O
an	O
abrasion-resistant	B
finishing	I
layer	I
,	O
which	O
is	O
sprayed	B
on	O
the	O
surfaces	B
of	I
the	I
wall	I
and	O
sets	O
within	O
2	O
–	O
3min	O
.	O
This	O
layer	B
also	O
enhances	B
the	I
surface	I
resistance	I
of	O
poly-blocks	B
against	O
stone	B
impact	I
,	O
weathering	B
,	O
fire	B
development	I
,	O
chemicals	B
and	O
penetration	B
.	O
LPF	B
is	O
an	O
expanding	B
liquid	I
mixture	I
which	O
is	O
injected	O
into	O
the	O
poly-block	B
voids	I
and	O
cures	B
within	O
10min	O
.	O

rebars	I
are	O

into	O
holes	B

in	O
the	O
existing	B
sound	I
wall	I
to	O

to	O

Privacy	B
in	O

of	O
Immediate	B
Gratification	I
ABSTRACT	O
Dichotomies	O

attitudes	O
and	O

Consistency-preserving	O
Caching	O
of	O
Dynamic	O
Database	B
Content	I
*	O
ABSTRACT	O
With	O
the	O
growing	O
use	O
of	O
dynamic	O
web	O
content	O
generated	O
from	O
relational	B
databases	I
,	O
traditional	O
caching	O
solutions	O
for	O
throughput	O
and	O
latency	O
improvements	O
are	O
ineffective	O
.	O
We	O
describe	O
a	O
middleware	O
layer	O
called	O
Ganesh	O
that	O
reduces	O
the	O
volume	O
of	O
data	O
transmitted	O
without	O
semantic	O
interpretation	O
of	O
queries	O
or	O
results	O
.	O
It	O
achieves	O
this	O
reduction	O
through	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
cryptographic	O
hashing	O
to	O
detect	O
similarities	O
with	O
previous	O
results	O
.	O
These	O
benefits	O
do	O
not	O
require	O
any	O
compromise	O
of	O
the	O
strict	O
consistency	O
semantics	O
provided	O
by	O
the	O
back-end	O
database	O
.	O

,	O
Ganesh	O
does	O
not	O
require	O
modifications	O
to	O
applications	O
,	O
web	O
servers	O
,	O
or	O
database	O
servers	O
,	O
and	O
works	O
with	O
closed-source	O
applications	O
and	O
databases	O
.	O

benchmarks	O
representative	O
of	O
dynamic	O
web	O
sites	O
,	O

of	O
our	O
prototype	O

that	O

can	O

by	O
as	O
much	O

for	O
non-data	O
intensive	O
applications	O
and	O
by	O
as	O
much	O
as	O
tenfold	O
for	O
data	O
intensive	O
ones	O
.	O

An	O
Efficient	O
Heuristic	B
Approach	I
for	O
Security	O
Against	O
Multiple	O
Adversaries	O
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
adversarial	B
multiagent	I
domains	I
,	O
security	O
,	O
commonly	O
defined	O
as	O
the	O
ability	O
to	O
deal	O
with	O
intentional	O
threats	O
from	O
other	O
agents	O
,	O
is	O
a	O
critical	O
issue	O
.	O
This	O
paper	O
focuses	O
on	O
domains	O
where	O
these	O
threats	O
come	O
from	O
unknown	O
adversaries	O
.	O
These	O
domains	O
can	O
be	O
modeled	O
as	O
Bayesian	B
games	I
;	O
much	O
work	O
has	O
been	O
done	O
on	O
finding	O
equilibria	O
for	O
such	O
games	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
often	O
the	O
case	O
in	O
multiagent	O
security	O
domains	O
that	O
one	O
agent	O
can	O
commit	O
to	O
a	O
mixed	O
strategy	O
which	O
its	O
adversaries	O
observe	O
before	O
choosing	O
their	O
own	O
strategies	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
case	O
,	O
the	O
agent	O
can	O
maximize	O
reward	O
by	O
finding	O
an	O
optimal	O
strategy	O
,	O
without	O
requiring	O
equilibrium	O
.	O
Previous	O
work	O
has	O
shown	O
this	O
problem	O
of	O
optimal	O
strategy	O
selection	O
to	O
be	O
NP-hard	B
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
we	O
present	O
a	O
heuristic	O
called	O
ASAP	O
,	O
with	O
three	O
key	O
advantages	O
to	O
address	O
the	O
problem	O
.	O
First	O
,	O
ASAP	O
searches	O
for	O
the	O
highest-reward	O
strategy	O
,	O
rather	O
than	O
a	O
Bayes-Nash	O
equilibrium	O
,	O
allowing	O
it	O
to	O
find	O
feasible	O
strategies	O
that	O
exploit	O
the	O
natural	O
first-mover	O
advantage	O
of	O
the	O
game	O
.	O
Second	O
,	O
it	O
provides	O
strategies	O
which	O
are	O
simple	O
to	O
understand	O
,	O
represent	O
,	O
and	O
implement	O
.	O
Third	O
,	O
it	O
operates	O
directly	O
on	O
the	O
compact	O
,	O
Bayesian	B
game	I
representation	O
,	O
without	O
requiring	O
conversion	O
to	O
normal	O
form	O
.	O
We	O
provide	O
an	O
efficient	O
Mixed	O
Integer	O
Linear	O
Program	O
-LRB-	O
MILP	O
-RRB-	O
implementation	O
for	O
ASAP	O
,	O
along	O
with	O
experimental	O
results	O
illustrating	O
significant	O
speedups	O
and	O
higher	O
rewards	O
over	O
other	O
approaches	O
.	O

Modeling	O
frequently	O
accessed	O
wireless	O
data	O
with	O
weak	B
consistency	I
To	O
reduce	O
the	O
response	O
times	O
of	O
wireless	B
data	I
access	I
in	O
a	O
mobile	B
network	I
,	O
caches	B
are	O
utilized	O
in	O
wireless	B
handheld	I
devices	I
.	O
If	O
the	O
original	O
data	B
entry	I
has	O
been	O
updated	O
,	O
the	O
cached	B
data	O
in	O

.	O

time-to-live	O
-LRB-	O

-RRB-	O

.	O

propose	O
an	O
analytic	B
model	I
to	O

algorithm	O
for	O
frequently	O
accessed	O
data	O
.	O
The	O
analytic	B
model	I
is	O
validated	O
against	O
simulation	B
experiments	I
.	O
Our	O
study	O
quantitatively	O
indicates	O
how	O
the	O
TTL-based	O
algorithm	O
reduces	O
the	O
wireless	B
communication	I
cost	I
by	O
increasing	O
the	O
probability	O
of	O
stale	O
accesses	O
.	O

,	O

parameter	O

on	O
the	O

From	O

,	O
polymerization	B
techniques	I

polymerization	I
.	O
Step-growth	B
polymerization	I
is	O

ABSTRACT	O

for	O

machine	B

.	O

model	O
achieves	O
a	O
static	B
ranking	I
pairwise	O
accuracy	O
of	O
67.3	O
%	O
-LRB-	O
vs.	O
56.7	O
%	O
for	O
PageRank	B
or	O
50	O
%	O
for	O
random	O
-RRB-	O
.	O

.	O

Graphs	I
*	O
ABSTRACT	O
Archival	B
storage	O
of	O
sensor	O
data	O
is	O
necessary	O
for	O
applications	O
that	O
query	O
,	O
mine	O
,	O
and	O
analyze	O
such	O
data	O
for	O
interesting	O
features	O
and	O
trends	O
.	O
We	O
argue	O
that	O
existing	O
storage	O
systems	O
are	O
designed	O
primarily	O
for	O
flat	O
hierarchies	O
of	O
homogeneous	O
sensor	O
nodes	O
and	O
do	O
not	O
fully	O
exploit	O
the	O
multi-tier	O
nature	O
of	O
emerging	O
sensor	O
networks	O
,	O
where	O
an	O
application	O
can	O
comprise	O
tens	O
of	O
tethered	O
proxies	O
,	O
each	O
managing	O
tens	O
to	O
hundreds	O
of	O
untethered	O
sensors	O
.	O
We	O
present	O
TSAR	O
,	O
a	O
fundamentally	O
different	O
storage	O
architecture	O
that	O
envisions	O
separation	B
of	I
data	I
from	O
metadata	O
by	O
employing	O
local	O
archiving	B
at	O
the	O
sensors	O
and	O
distributed	O
indexing	O
at	O
the	O
proxies	O
.	O
At	O
the	O
proxy	O
tier	O
,	O
TSAR	O
employs	O
a	O
novel	O
multi-resolution	O
ordered	O
distributed	B
index	I
structure	I
,	O
the	O
Interval	B
Skip	I
Graph	I
,	O
for	O
efficiently	O
supporting	O
spatio-temporal	O
and	O
value	O
queries	O
.	O
At	O
the	O
sensor	O
tier	O
,	O
TSAR	O
supports	O
energy-aware	O
adaptive	O
summarization	O
that	O
can	O
trade	O
off	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
transmitting	O
metadata	O
to	O
the	O
proxies	O
against	O
the	O
overhead	O
offalse	O
hits	O
resultingfrom	O
querying	O
a	O
coarse-grain	O
index	O
.	O
We	O
implement	O
TSAR	O
in	O
a	O
two-tier	O
sensor	O
testbed	O
comprising	O

proxies	O
and	O
Mote-based	O
sensors	O
.	O
Our	O
experiments	O
demonstrate	O
the	O
benefits	O
and	O
feasibility	O
of	O
using	O
our	O
energy-efficient	O
storage	O
architecture	O
in	O
multi-tier	O
sensor	O
networks	O
.	O

A	O

LVQ	I

.	O

LVQ	O
-LRB-	O

uses	O
a	O

Fuzzy	O

-LSB-	O
Halden	B
Reactor	I

The	O

Reactor	I
Project	I

.	O
PEANO	B
is	O

system	O
that	O
makes	O

of	O

of	O

process	O

.	O

of	O

and	O
span	O
drifts	O
were	O

detected	O
by	O
the	O
system	O
.	O

is	O
a	O
system	O
for	O
thermal	B
performance	I
monitoring	I
and	O
optimisation	O
,	O
which	O
relies	O
on	O

first	O
principle	O
models	O
.	O

system	O

New	O

Robust	B

law	I

.	O

Integrate-and-fire	B
neurons	I
driven	O
by	O
correlated	B
stochastic	I
input	I
Neurons	O
are	O
sensitive	O
to	O
correlations	O
among	O
synaptic	O
inputs	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
analytical	O
models	O
that	O
explicitly	O
include	O
correlations	O
are	O
hard	O
to	O
solve	O
analytically	O
,	O
so	O
their	O
influence	O
on	O
a	O
neuron	O
's	O
response	O
has	O
been	O
difficult	O
to	O
ascertain	O
.	O
To	O
gain	O
some	O
intuition	O
on	O
this	O
problem	O
,	O
we	O
studied	O
the	O
firing	B
times	I
of	O
two	O
simple	O
integrate-and-fire	O
model	O
neurons	O
driven	O
by	O
a	O
correlated	B
binary	I
variable	I
that	O
represents	O
the	O
total	O
input	O
current	O
.	O
Analytic	O
expressions	O
were	O
obtained	O
for	O
the	O
average	O
firing	O
rate	O
and	O
coefficient	B
of	I
variation	I
-LRB-	O
a	O
measure	O
of	O
spike-train	B
variability	I
-RRB-	O
as	O
functions	O
of	O
the	O
mean	O
,	O
variance	O
,	O
and	O
correlation	O
time	O
of	O
the	O
stochastic	O
input	O
.	O
The	O
results	O
of	O
computer	B
simulations	I
were	O
in	O
excellent	O
agreement	O
with	O
these	O
expressions	O
.	O
In	O
these	O
models	O
,	O
an	O
increase	O
in	O
correlation	O
time	O
in	O
general	O
produces	O
an	O
increase	O
in	O
both	O
the	O
average	O
firing	O
rate	O
and	O
the	O
variability	O
of	O
the	O
output	B
spike	I
trains	I
.	O
However	O
,	O
the	O
magnitude	O
of	O
the	O
changes	O
depends	O
differentially	O
on	O

of	O

input	O

and	O
variance	O

firing	O

is	O
higher	O
when	O

variance	O
is	O

to	O

mean	O
,	O

increase	O
in	O
variability	O
is	O
higher	O
when	O
the	O
variance	O
is	O
relatively	O
small	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
the	O
firing	O
rate	O
always	O
tends	O
to	O
a	O
finite	O
limit	O
value	O
as	O
the	O
correlation	O
time	O
increases	O
toward	O
infinity	O
,	O
whereas	O
the	O
coefficient	B
of	I
variation	I
typically	O
diverges	O
.	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
temporal	B
correlations	I
may	O
play	O
a	O
major	O
role	O
in	O

the	O
variability	O
as	O

as	O
the	O
intensity	O
of	O
neuronal	O
spike	O
trains	O

in	O

based	O
Distributed	O
Multi-Player	O
Games	O
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
a	O
distributed	O
multi-player	O
game	O
that	O
uses	O
dead-reckoning	B
vectors	O
to	O
exchange	O
movement	O
information	O
among	O
players	O
,	O
there	O
is	O
inaccuracy	O
in	O
rendering	O
the	O
objects	O
at	O
the	O
receiver	O
due	O
to	O
network	O
delay	O
between	O

sender	O
and	O
the	O

.	O
The	O
object	O
is	O
placed	O
at	O
the	O
receiver	O

by	O

vector	O

that	O

the	O

position	O
could	O
have	O
changed	O
considerably	O
at	O

sender	O
.	O

would	O
be	O

if	O
it	O
is	O
consistent	O
among	O
all	O
players	O
;	O
that	O
is	O
,	O
at	O
the	O
same	O
physical	O

,	O
all	O
players	O
see	O
inaccurate	O
-LRB-	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
the	O
real	O
position	O
of	O
the	O
object	O
-RRB-	O
but	O

same	O
position	O
and	O

for	O
an	O
object	O
.	O

and	O

players	O

.	O

in	O
game	O
playing	O
.	O
In	O

``	O

''	O

.	O

.	O

error	I
of	O

Data	B
extraction	I
from	O
the	O
Web	O
based	O
on	O
pre-defined	O
schema	B
With	O

Internet	B

has	O

.	O

.	O

schema	B
.	O

has	O

developed	O
.	O

high	O
accuracy	O

For	O
mixtures	B
described	O
by	O

.	O

of	O
this	O
calculation	O

to	O
a	O

methods	I
.	O

Time-integration	O
of	O

chemistry	I

models	I

a	O

of	O

species	I

.	O

.	O

.	O

Shading	B
can	O

.	O

.	O

A	B
nanocomposite	I
system	I
consisting	O
of	O
a	B

matrix	I
and	I
embedded	I

has	O
been	O
fabricated	O
.	O
The	B
ferromagnetic	I
characteristics	I
as	O

,	I

and	I
magnetic	I

of	I
the	I

adjusted	O
by	O
the	B
electrochemical	I
parameters	I
.	O
Furthermore	O
the	O
spatial	O
distribution	B
of	O
the	O
metal	O
structures	O
within	O
the	O
pores	O
can	O
be	O
varied	O
which	O
means	O
that	O
the	O

between	O
the	O
particles	O
can	O
be	O
influenced	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
case	O
of	O
densely	B
packed	I
particles	I
within	O
the	O
pores	O
dipolar	O
coupling	O
between	O
them	O
occurs	O
and	O
results	O
in	O
quasi	O
magnetic	O
chains	O
which	O
offer	O
a	B
much	I
larger	I
magnetic	I
anisotropy	I
than	O
non-interacting	B
particles	I
.	O
By	O
modifying	B
the	I
current	I
density	I
small	B
Ni-particles	I
(	I
3	I
–	I
6nm	I
)	I
can	O
be	O
deposited	O
.	O
If	O
the	O
packing	O
density	O
of	O
these	B
particles	I
is	O
sufficiently	O
close	O
,	O
Ni-tubes	B
of	O

A	O

ABSTRACT	O
This	O
paper	O
proposes	O
a	O
framework	O
for	O
agent-based	O
distributed	O
machine	O
learning	O
and	O
data	O
mining	O
based	O
on	O
-LRB-	O
i	O
-RRB-	O
the	O
exchange	O
of	O
meta-level	O
descriptions	O
of	O
individual	O
learning	O
processes	O
among	O
agents	O
and	O
-LRB-	O
ii	O
-RRB-	O
online	O
reasoning	O
about	O
learning	O
success	O
and	O
learning	O
progress	O
by	O
learning	O
agents	O
.	O
We	O
present	O
an	O
abstract	O
architecture	O
that	O
enables	O
agents	B
to	O
exchange	O
models	O
of	O
their	O
local	O

processes	O
and	O
introduces	O
a	O

of	O
different	O

for	O
integrating	O
these	O
processes	O
.	O
This	O
allows	O

to	O
apply	O
existing	O
agent	B
interaction	O

to	O
distributed	B
machine	I

available	O
in	O

,	O
and	O
enables	O
agents	O
to	O

in	O

about	O
their	O
own	O
learning	O

.	O
We	O
apply	O
this	O
architecture	O
to	O
a	O
real-world	O
distributed	B
clustering	I
application	I
to	O
illustrate	O
how	O
the	O
conceptual	O
framework	O
can	O
be	O
used	O
in	O
practical	O
systems	O

which	O

may	O
be	O
using	O
different	O
datasets	O
,	O

and	O
learning	O

.	O

Structural	B

of	I

.	O

]	O

]	O

.	O

]	O
.	O

systems	I

.	O

MANET	O
is	O

research	O
area	O
with	O
practical	O
applications	O
.	O
However	O
,	O

MANET	I
is	O

to	O
its	O

open	B
medium	I
,	O

,	O

cooperation	I
,	O
and	O
constrained	O
capability	O
.	O

Estimating	O
the	O
Global	B
PageRank	I
of	O
Web	B
Communities	I
ABSTRACT	O
Localized	B
search	I
engines	I
are	O
small-scale	O
systems	O
that	O
index	O
a	O
particular	O
community	O
on	O
the	O
web	O
.	O
They	O
offer	O
several	O
benefits	O
over	O
their	O
large-scale	O
counterparts	O
in	O
that	O
they	O
are	O
relatively	O
inexpensive	O
to	O
build	O
,	O
and	O
can	O
provide	O
more	O
precise	O
and	O
complete	O
search	O
capability	O
over	O
their	O
relevant	O
domains	O
.	O
One	O
disadvantage	O
such	O
systems	O
have	O
over	O
large-scale	O
search	O
engines	O
is	O
the	O
lack	O
of	O
global	B
PageRank	I
values	O
.	O
Such	O
information	O
is	O
needed	O
to	O
assess	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
pages	O
in	O
the	O
localized	O
search	O
domain	O
within	O
the	O
context	O
of	O
the	O
web	O
as	O
a	O
whole	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
present	O
well-motivated	O
algorithms	B
to	O
estimate	O
the	O
global	B
PageRank	I
values	O
of	O
a	O
local	B
domain	I
.	O
The	O
algorithms	B
are	O
all	O
highly	O
scalable	O
in	O
that	O
,	O
given	O
a	O
local	B
domain	I
of	O
size	O
n	O
,	O
they	O
use	O
O	O
-LRB-	O
n	O
-RRB-	O
resources	O
that	O
include	O
computation	O
time	O
,	O
bandwidth	O
,	O
and	O
storage	O
.	O
We	O
test	O
our	O
methods	O
across	O
a	O
variety	O
of	O
localized	B
domains	I
,	O
including	O
site-specific	O
domains	O
and	O
topic-specific	B
domains	I
.	O
We	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
by	O
crawling	O
as	O
few	O
as	O
n	O
or	O
2n	O
additional	O
pages	O
,	O
our	O
methods	O
can	O
give	O
excellent	O
global	B
PageRank	I
estimates	O
.	O

of	O

model	I

SPOT	I
stereo	I
images	I
A	O
digital	O
elevation	O
model	O
-LRB-	O
DEM	O
-RRB-	O
can	O
be	O
extracted	O
automatically	O
from	O
stereo	B
satellite	I
images	I
.	O
During	O

decade	O
,	O
the	O
most	O
common	O
satellite	O
data	O
used	O
to	O

was	O
the	O
across-track	O
SPOT	O
.	O
Recently	O
,	O
the	O
addition	O
of	O
along-track	B
ASTER	I
data	I
,	O
which	O
can	O

downloaded	O

provides	O

.	O

when	O
compared	O
to	O
a	O

7.5-min	O
DEM	O
standard	O
product	O
.	O
The	O

shows	O
that	O
SPOT	O
produces	O
better	O
DEM	O
results	O
in	O
terms	O
of	O
accuracy	O
and	O
details	O
,	O
if	O
the	O
radiometric	B
variations	I
between	O
the	O
images	O
,	O
taken	O
on	O
subsequent	O
satellite	O
revolutions	O
,	O
are	O
small	O
.	O
Otherwise	O
,	O
the	O
ASTER	B
stereo	I
pair	I
is	O
a	O
better	O
choice	O
because	O
of	O
simultaneous	B
along-track	I
acquisition	I
during	O
a	O

pass	O
.	O

4.6	O
m	O
,	O
respectively	O

A	O
multi-physics	B
description	I
of	I
a	I
multiscale	I
system	I
is	O
often	O
referred	O
to	O
as	O
a	O
‘	B
hybrid’	I
model	I
.	O
In	O
fluid	B
dynamics	I
,	O
a	O
typical	O
hybrid	B
combines	O
a	O
molecular	B
treatment	I
(	O
a	O
‘	B
micro’	I
model	I
)	O
with	O
a	O
continuum-fluid	B
one	I
(	O
a	O
‘	O
macro’	B
model	I
)	O
,	O
with	O
the	O
aim	O
of	O
obtaining	B
the	I
accuracy	I
of	I
the	I
former	I
with	I
the	I
efficiency	I
of	I
the	I
latter	I
[	O
1	O
–	O
4	O
]	O
.	O
The	O
micro	B
and	I
macro	I
models	I
generally	O
have	O
characteristic	O
timescales	O
that	O
are	O
very	O
different	O
,	O
which	O
means	O
that	O
time-accurate	O
simulations	O
can	O
be	O
extremely	O
challenging	O
:	O
the	O
size	O
of	O
the	O
timestep	O
required	O
to	O
make	O
the	O
micro	O
model	O
stable	O
and	O
accurate	O
is	O
so	O
small	O
that	O
simulations	O
over	O
significant	O
macro-scale	O
time	O
periods	O
are	O
intractable	O
.	O
If	O
the	O
system	O
is	O
‘	O
scale-separated’	O
,	O
a	O
physical	O
(	O
as	O
distinct	O
from	O
numerical	O
)	O
approximation	O
can	O
be	O
made	O
that	O
enables	O
the	O
coupled	O
models	O
to	O
advance	O
at	O
different	O
rates	O
(	O
asynchronously	O
)	O
with	O
negligible	O
penalty	O
on	O
macro-scale	O
accuracy	O
.	O
E	O
et	O
al	O
.	O
[	O
5	O
]	O
were	O
the	O
first	O
to	O
introduce	O
and	O
implement	O
this	O
concept	O
in	O
a	O
time-stepping	O
method	O
for	O
coupled	O
systems	O
,	O
referred	O
to	O
in	O
the	O
classification	O
of	O
Lockerby	O
et	O
al	O
.	O
[	O
6	O
]	O
as	O
a	O
continuous	O
asynchronous	O
(	O
CA	O
)	O
scheme	O
(‘	O
continuous’	O
since	O
the	O
micro	O
and	O
macro	O
models	O
advance	O
without	O
interruption	O
[	O
5	O
])	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
extend	O
this	O
idea	O
to	O
multiscale	O
systems	O
comprising	O
an	O
arbitrary	O
number	O
of	O
coupled	O
models	O
.	O

A	O
knowledge	B
management	I
framework	I
for	O
the	O
support	O
of	O
decision	O
making	O
in	O
humanitarian	O
assistance/disaster	O
relief	O
The	O
major	O
challenge	O
in	O
current	O
humanitarian	O
assistance/disaster	O
relief	O
-LRB-	O
HA/DR	O
-RRB-	O
efforts	O
is	O
that	O
diverse	O
information	O
and	O
knowledge	O
are	O
widely	O
distributed	O
and	O
owned	O
by	O
different	O
organizations	O
.	O
These	O
resources	O
are	O
not	O
efficiently	O
organized	B
and	O
utilized	O
during	O
HA/DR	O
operations	O
.	O
We	O
present	O
a	O
knowledge	B
management	I
framework	I
that	O
integrates	O
multiple	O
information	B
technologies	I
to	O

,	O

for	O

decision	O
making	O
in	O
HA/DR	O
.	O
The	O
framework	O
will	O
help	O
identify	O
the	O
information	B
needs	I
,	O
be	O
aware	O
of	O
a	O
disaster	O
situation	O
,	O
and	O
provide	O

with	O
useful	O
relief	O

based	O
on	O
past	O
experience	O
.	O
A	O

,	O

and	O
authoritative	O
knowledge	O
base	O
within	O
the	O
framework	O
will	O

knowledge	B
sharing	I
and	O
reuse	O
.	O
This	O
framework	O
can	O
also	O
be	O
applied	O
to	O
other	O

decision-making	I
environments	I
,	O

assistance	I

In	O
summary	O
,	O
we	O
have	O
developed	O
a	O
technique	O
for	O
site-specific	B
nanowire	I
size	I
reduction	I
by	O
FIB	B
thinning	I
.	O
Transmission	B
electron	I
microscope	I
images	I
of	O
a	O
thinned	B
tungsten	I
composite	I
nanowire	I
with	O
width	O
reduced	O
from	O
80	O
to	O
20nm	O
show	O
uniform	B
shrinking	I
along	O
the	O
length	O
of	O
the	O
wire	B
and	O
high	B
resolution	I
images	I
show	O
no	O
obvious	O
changes	O
of	O
the	O
morphology	O
after	O
thinning	B
.	O
The	O
critical	O
current	O
density	O
of	O
the	O
as-deposited	B
wire	I
and	O
one	O
thinned	O
to	O
a	O
width	O
of	O
50nm	O
is	O
1.7	O
×	O
105	O
and	O
1.4	O
×	O
105A	O
/	O
cm2	O
at	O
4.26K	O
,	O
respectively	O
,	O
suggesting	O
insignificant	O
modulation	B
of	I
the	I
electrical	I
properties	I
during	O
thinning	B
.	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
FIB-milling	B
is	O
a	O
potential	O
approach	O
for	O
controllable	B
size	I
reduction	I

Isogeometric	B
analysis	I
(	O
IGA	B
)	O
is	O
a	O
numerical	B
simulation	I
method	I
which	O
is	O
directly	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
NURBS-based	B
representation	I
of	O
CAD	O
models	O
.	O
It	O
exploits	O
the	O
tensor-product	O
structure	O
of	O
2	O
-	O
or	O
3-dimensional	O
NURBS	B
objects	O
to	O
parameterize	O
the	O
physical	O
domain	O
.	O
Hence	O
the	O
physical	O
domain	O
is	O
parameterized	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
a	O
rectangle	O
or	O
to	O
a	O
cube	O
.	O
Consequently	O
,	O

parameterized	O
NURBS	O
surfaces	O
and	O
NURBS	O
volumes	O
are	O
needed	O
in	O

to	O
represent	O
non-quadrangular	O
or	O
non-hexahedral	O
domains	O
without	O
splitting	O
,	O
thereby	O
producing	O
a	O
very	O
compact	O
and	O
convenient	O
representation.The	O
Galerkin	O
projection	O
introduces	O
finite-dimensional	O
spaces	O
of	O
test	O
functions	O
in	O
the	O
weak	O
formulation	O
of	O
partial	O
differential	O
equations	O
.	O
In	O
particular	O
,	O
the	O
test	O
functions	O

in	O
isogeometric	O
analysis	O
are	O

the	O
inverse	O
of	O

with	O
the	O
NURBS	O
basis	O
functions	O
.	O

of	O

,	O
some	O

the	O
resulting	O
test	O

do	O
not	O
necessarily	O

the	O
required	O
regularity	O
properties	O
.	O
Consequently	O
,	O
numerical	O
methods	O
for	O
the	O
solution	O
of	O
partial	O
differential	O
equations	O
cannot	O
be	O
applied	O
properly.We	O
discuss	O
the	O
regularity	O
properties	O
of	O
the	O
test	O
functions	O
.	O
For	O
one	O
-	O
and	O
two-dimensional	O
domains	O
we	O
consider	O
several	O
important	O
classes	O
of	O

.	O

of	O

test	O

.	O

function	O
space	O

.	O

.	O

Hybrid	O
broadcast	O
for	O
the	O
video-on-demand	B
service	O
Multicast	B
offers	O
an	O
efficient	O
means	O
of	O
distributing	O
video	O
contents/programs	O
to	O
multiple	O
clients	O
by	O
batching	O
their	O
requests	O
and	O
then	O
having	O
them	O
share	O
a	O
server	O
's	O
video	O
stream	O
.	O
Batching	O
customers	O
'	O
requests	O
is	O
either	O
client-initiated	O
or	O
server-initiated	O
.	O
Most	O
advanced	O
client-initiated	O
video	O
multicasts	B
are	O
implemented	O
by	O
patching	O
.	O
Periodic	O
broadcast	O
,	O
a	O
typical	O
server-initiated	O
approach	O

can	O
be	O
entirety-based	O
or	O
segment-based	O
.	O
This	O
paper	O
focuses	O
on	O
the	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
VoD	O
service	O
for	O
popular	O
videos	O
.	O

the	O
limitation	O
of	O
conventional	B
patching	I
when	O
the	O
customer	B
request	I
rate	I
is	O
high	O
.	O

,	O

the	O
advantages	O
of	O
each	O

the	O

broadcast	O

we	O
propose	O
a	O
hybrid	B
broadcast	I
scheme	I
for	O
popular	O
videos	O

lowers	O
the	O
service	O

also	O
improves	O
clients	O
'	O
interactivity	B
by	O
using	O

.	O

Heuristics-Based	O
Scheduling	B
of	O
Composite	O
Web	B
Service	I
Workloads	O
ABSTRACT	O
Web	B
services	I
can	O
be	O
aggregated	O
to	O
create	O
composite	O
workflows	O
that	O
provide	O
streamlined	B
functionality	I
for	O
human	O
users	O
or	O
other	O
systems	O
.	O
Although	O
industry	O
standards	O
and	O
recent	O
research	O
have	O
sought	O
to	O
define	O
best	O
practices	O

improve	O
end-to-end	B
workflow	I
composition	I
,	O
one	O
area	O
that	O
has	O
not	O
fully	O
been	O
explored	O
is	O
the	O
scheduling	B
of	O
a	O
workflow	O
's	O
web	B
service	I
requests	O
to	O
actual	O
service	O
provisioning	O
in	O
a	O

,	O
multi-organisation	O
environment	O
.	O
This	O
issue	O
is	O
relevant	O
to	O
modern	O
business	O
scenarios	O
where	O
business	O
processes	O
within	O
a	O
workflow	O
must	O
complete	O
within	O
QoS-defined	O
limits	O
.	O
Because	O
these	O
business	O
processes	O
are	O
web	B
service	I
consumers	O
,	O
service	B
requests	I
must	O
be	O
mapped	O
and	O
scheduled	B
across	O
multiple	O
web	B
service	I
providers	O
,	O
each	O
with	O
its	O
own	O
negotiated	O
service	O
level	O
agreement	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
provide	O
heuristics	B
for	O
scheduling	B
service	O
requests	O
from	O
multiple	O
business	O
process	O
workflows	O
to	O
web	O
service	O
providers	O
such	O
that	O
a	O
business	O
value	O
metric	O
across	O
all	O
workflows	O
is	O
maximised	O
.	O
We	O
show	O
that	O
a	O
genetic	O
search	O
algorithm	O
is	O
appropriate	O
to	O
perform	O
this	O

and	O
through	O
experimentation	O
we	O
show	O
that	O
our	O
algorithm	O
scales	O
well	O
up	O
to	O
a	O
thousand	O
workflows	O
and	O
produces	O
better	O
mappings	O
than	O
traditional	O
approaches	O
.	O

of	O

for	O

ABSTRACT	O

of	O
the	O

Project	O
,	O
our	O
goal	O
is	O
to	O
identify	O

semantically	O

concepts	O

adequately	O

of	O

collection	O
.	O

of	O

.	O

for	O

.	O

documentconcept	O

realworld	O

.	O

on	O

.	I

A	O
unifying	O
co-operative	B
Web	I
caching	I
architecture	I
Network	B
caching	I
of	O
objects	O
has	O
become	O
a	O
standard	O
way	O
of	O
reducing	O
network	O
traffic	O
and	O
latency	O
in	O
the	O
Web	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
Web	O
caches	O
exhibit	O
poor	O
performance	O
with	O
a	O
hit	O
rate	O
of	O
about	O
30	O
%	O
.	O
A	O
solution	O
to	O
improve	O
this	O
hit	O
rate	O
is	O
to	O
have	O
a	O
group	O
of	O
proxies	O
form	O
co-operation	O
where	O
objects	O
can	O
be	O
cached	O
for	O
later	O
retrieval	O
.	O
A	O
cooperative	B
cache	I
system	I
includes	O
protocols	B
for	O
hierarchical	O
and	O
transversal	B
caching	I
.	O
The	O
drawback	O
of	O
such	O
a	O
system	O
lies	O
in	O
the	O
resulting	O
network	B
load	I
due	O
to	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
messages	O
that	O
need	O
to	O
be	O
exchanged	O
to	O
locate	O
an	O
object	O
.	O
This	O
paper	O
proposes	O
a	O
new	O
co-operative	B
Web	I
caching	I
architecture	I
,	O
which	O
unifies	O
previous	O
methods	O
of	O
Web	O
caching	O
.	O
Performance	O
results	O
shows	O
that	O
the	O
architecture	O
achieve	O
up	O
to	O
70	O
%	O
co-operative	B
hit	I
rate	I
and	O
accesses	O
the	O
cached	O
object	O
in	O
at	O
most	O
two	O
hops	O
.	O
Moreover	O
,	O

architecture	O

traffic	O
and	O
database	O

Summarization	O
beyond	O
sentence	O
extraction	O
:	O
A	O
probabilistic	O
approach	O
to	O
sentence	B
compression	I
When	O
humans	O
produce	O
summaries	O
of	O
documents	O
,	O
they	O
do	O
not	O
simply	O
extract	O
sentences	O
and	O
concatenate	O
them	O
.	O
Rather	O
,	O
they	O
create	O
new	O
sentences	O
that	O
are	O
grammatical	B
,	O
that	O
cohere	O
with	O
one	O
another	O
,	O
and	O
that	O
capture	O
the	O
most	O
salient	O
pieces	O
of	O
information	O
in	O
the	O
original	O
document	O
.	O
Given	O
that	O
large	O
collections	O
of	O
text/abstract	O
pairs	O
are	O
available	O
online	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
now	O
possible	O
to	O
envision	O
algorithms	O
that	O
are	O
trained	O
to	O
mimic	O
this	O
process	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
focus	O
on	O
sentence	B
compression	I
,	O
a	O
simpler	O
version	O
of	O
this	O
larger	O
challenge	O
.	O
We	O
aim	O
to	O
achieve	O
two	O
goals	O
simultaneously	O
:	O
our	O
compressions	O
should	O
be	O
grammatical	B
,	O
and	O
they	O
should	O
retain	O
the	O
most	O
important	O
pieces	O
of	O
information	O
.	O
These	O
two	O
goals	O
can	O
conflict	O
.	O
We	O
devise	O
both	O
a	O
noisy-channel	B
and	O
a	O
decision-tree	B
approach	O
to	O
the	O
problem	O
,	O
and	O
we	O
evaluate	O
results	O
against	O
manual	O
compressions	O
and	O
a	O
simple	O
baseline	O

student	I

ABSTRACT	O
In	O

of	O

with	O

contracts	O
.	O

an	O
agent	O

a	O

of	O
computational	O
trust	O

and	O

and	O
correlations	B
in	O
these	O

.	O

present	O
a	O

based	O
on	O
the	O
Dirichlet	B
distribution	I
that	O

and	O
correlations	B
from	O
their	O
direct	O

of	O
contract	O
outcomes	O

that	O
this	O

to	O
superior	O
estimates	O
compared	O
to	O

alternative	O
approach	O
using	O

.	O

how	O
agents	O
may	O

sufficient	O

of	O
this	O
Dirichlet	B

reputation	B
system	I
.	O

DiffusionRank	B
:	O
A	O
Possible	O
Penicillin	O
for	O
Web	B
Spamming	I
ABSTRACT	O
While	O
the	O
PageRank	B
algorithm	O
has	O
proven	O
to	O
be	O
very	O
effective	O
for	O
ranking	B
Web	O
pages	O
,	O
the	O
rank	B
scores	O
of	O
Web	O
pages	O
can	O
be	O
manipulated	O
.	O
To	O
handle	O
the	O
manipulation	O
problem	O
and	O
to	O
cast	O
a	O
new	O
insight	O
on	O
the	O
Web	O
structure	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
ranking	B
algorithm	O
called	O
DiffusionRank	B
.	O
DiffusionRank	B
is	O
motivated	O
by	O
the	O
heat	O
diffusion	O
phenomena	O
,	O
which	O
can	O
be	O
connected	O
to	O
Web	O
ranking	B
because	O
the	O
activities	O
flow	O
on	O
the	O
Web	O
can	O
be	O
imagined	O
as	O
heat	O
flow	O
,	O
the	O
link	O
from	O
a	O
page	O
to	O
another	O
can	O
be	O
treated	O
as	O
the	O
pipe	O
of	O
an	O
air-conditioner	O
,	O
and	O
heat	O
flow	O
can	O
embody	O
the	O
structure	O
of	O
the	O
underlying	O
Web	B
graph	I
.	O
Theoretically	O
we	O
show	O
that	O
DiffusionRank	B
can	O
serve	O
as	O
a	O
generalization	O
of	O
PageRank	B
when	O
the	O
heat	O
diffusion	O
coefficient	O
-	O
y	O
tends	O
to	O
infinity	O
.	O
In	O
such	O
a	O
case	O
1	O
/	O
-	O
y	O
=	O
0	O
,	O
DiffusionRank	B
-LRB-	O
PageRank	B
-RRB-	O
has	O
low	O
ability	O
of	O
anti-manipulation	O
.	O
When	O
-	O
y	O
=	O
0	O
,	O
DiffusionRank	B
obtains	O
the	O
highest	O
ability	O
of	O
anti-manipulation	O
,	O
but	O
in	O
such	O
a	O
case	O
,	O
the	O
web	O
structure	O
is	O
completely	O
ignored	O
.	O
Consequently	O
,	O
-	O
y	O
is	O
an	O
interesting	O
factor	O
that	O
can	O
control	O
the	O
balance	O
between	O

ability	O
of	O

the	O
original	O
Web	O
and	O
the	O

effect	O

.	O

that	O
,	O
when	O
-	O
y	O
=	O
1	O
,	O

has	O
a	O
Penicillin-like	O
effect	O
on	O
the	O
link	O
manipulation	O
.	O

can	O
be	O

to	O

relations	I

On	O

StarDust	O
:	O
A	O
Flexible	O
Architecture	O
for	O
Passive	O
Localization	B
in	O
Wireless	B
Sensor	I
Networks	I
*	O
Abstract	O
The	O
problem	O
of	O
localization	B
in	O
wireless	B
sensor	I
networks	I
where	O
nodes	O
do	O
not	O
use	O
ranging	B
hardware	O

remains	O

challenging	O
problem	O
,	O
when	O

the	O
required	O

and	O

of	O
the	O

phase	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
framework	O
,	O
called	O
StarDust	O
,	O
for	O
wireless	B
sensor	I
network	I
localization	B
based	O
on	O
passive	O
optical	O
components	O
.	O

StarDust	O
framework	O
,	O
sensor	B
nodes	I
are	O
equipped	O
with	O
optical	O

.	O

projects	O

the	O
deployed	O
sensor	O
network	O
,	O
and	O
records	O
an	O

of	O
the	O
reflected	O
light	O
.	O
An	O

processing	I
algorithm	O
is	O

for	O
obtaining	O

locations	O
of	O
sensor	B
nodes	I
.	O

node	O

to	O
a	O

we	O
propose	O
a	O
constraint-based	O
label	O
relaxation	O
algorithm	O
.	O

propose	O
and	O
develop	O
localization	B
techniques	O
based	O
on	O

,	O

,	O
deployment	O

for	O
a	O
node	O
and	O
deployment	O
location	O
for	O
a	O
node	O
.	O
We	O
evaluate	O
the	O
performance	B
of	O
a	O

our	O
framework	O

a	O

60ft2	O

.	O

.	O

Multi-phase	B
flows	I

together	O
.	O

in	O

studied	O
in	O
more	O
detail	O

Equilibrium	O
swelling	O
and	O
kinetics	O
of	O
pH-responsive	B
hydrogels	I
:	O
models	O
,	O
experiments	O
,	O
and	O
simulations	O
The	O
widespread	O
application	O
of	O
ionic	B
hydrogels	I
in	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
applications	O
like	O
control	O
of	O
microfluidic	B
flow	I
,	O
development	O
of	O
muscle-like	B
actuators	I
,	O
filtration/separation	B
and	O
drug	B
delivery	I
makes	O
it	O
important	O
to	O
properly	O
understand	O
these	O
materials	O
.	O
Understanding	O
hydrogel	O
properties	O
is	O
also	O
important	O
from	O
the	O
standpoint	O
of	O
their	O
similarity	O
to	O
many	O
biological	O
tissues	O
.	O
Typically	O
,	O
gel	B
size	I
is	O
sensitive	O
to	O
outer	O
solution	O
pH	O
and	O
salt	O
concentration	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
develop	O
models	O
to	O
predict	O
the	O
swelling/deswelling	B
of	O
hydrogels	O
in	O
buffered	B
pH	I
solutions	I
.	O
An	O
equilibrium	B
model	I
has	O
been	O
developed	O
to	O
predict	O
the	O
degree	O
of	O
swelling	O
of	O
the	O
hydrogel	O
at	O
a	O
given	O
pH	O
and	O
salt	O
concentration	O
in	O
the	O
solution	O
.	O
A	O
kinetic	O
model	O
has	O
been	O
developed	O
to	O
predict	O
the	O
rate	O
of	O
swelling	O
of	O
the	O
hydrogel	O
when	O
the	O
solution	O
pH	O
is	O
changed	O
.	O
Experiments	O
are	O
performed	O
to	O
characterize	O
the	O
mechanical	B
properties	I
of	O
the	O
hydrogel	O
in	O
different	O
pH	O
solutions	O
.	O
The	O
degree	O
of	O
swelling	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
the	O
rate	O
of	O
swelling	O
of	O
the	O
hydrogel	O
are	O
also	O
studied	O
through	O
experiments	O
.	O
The	O
simulations	O
are	O
compared	O
with	O
experimental	O
results	O
and	O
the	O
models	O
are	O
found	O
to	O
predict	O
the	O
swelling/deswelling	B
processes	O
accurately	O

ABSTRACT	O
Harvesting	O
energy	O
from	O
the	O
environment	O
is	O
feasible	O
in	O
many	O
applications	O
to	O
ameliorate	O
the	O
energy	O
limitations	O
in	O
sensor	B
networks	I
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
present	O
an	O
adaptive	O
duty	B
cycling	I
algorithm	O
that	O
allows	O
energy	B
harvesting	I
sensor	O
nodes	O
to	O
autonomously	O
adjust	O
their	O
duty	B
cycle	I
according	O
to	O
the	O
energy	O
availability	O
in	O
the	O
environment	O
.	O
The	O
algorithm	O
has	O
three	O
objectives	O
,	O
namely	O
-LRB-	O
a	O
-RRB-	O
achieving	O
energy	B
neutral	I
operation	I
,	O
i.e.	O
,	O
energy	O
consumption	O
should	O
not	O
be	O
more	O
than	O
the	O
energy	O
provided	O
by	O
the	O
environment	O
,	O
-LRB-	O
b	O
-RRB-	O
maximizing	O
the	O
system	O
performance	O
based	O
on	O
an	O
application	O
utility	O
model	O
subject	O
to	O
the	O
above	O
energyneutrality	O
constraint	O
,	O
and	O
-LRB-	O
c	O
-RRB-	O
adapting	O
to	O
the	O
dynamics	O
of	O
the	O
energy	O
source	O
at	O
run-time	O
.	O
We	O
present	O
a	O
model	O
that	O
enables	O
harvesting	O
sensor	O
nodes	O
to	O
predict	O
future	O
energy	O
opportunities	O
based	O
on	O
historical	O
data	O
.	O
We	O
also	O
derive	O
an	O
upper	O
bound	O
on	O
the	O
maximum	O
achievable	O
performance	O
assuming	O
perfect	O
knowledge	O
about	O
the	O
future	O
behavior	O
of	O
the	O
energy	O
source	O
.	O
Our	O
methods	O
are	O
evaluated	O
using	O
data	O
gathered	O
from	O
a	O
prototype	O
solar	O
energy	B
harvesting	I
platform	O
and	O
we	O
show	O
that	O
our	O
algorithm	O
can	O
utilize	O
up	O
to	O
58	O
%	O
more	O
environmental	B
energy	I
compared	O
to	O
the	O
case	O
when	O
harvesting-aware	O
power	B
management	I
is	O
not	O
used	O
.	O

This	O
conclusion	O
is	O
a	O
consequence	O
of	O
the	O
high	O
jet	O
speeds	O
and	O
small	O
nozzle	O
diameters	O
in	O

with	O
the	O
relatively	O

and	O

of	O

,	O

high	O
Weissenberg	O
numbers	O
and	O
moderate	O
values	O
of	O
the	O
extensibility	O
,	O
L	O
studied	O
here	O
.	O

discussed	O
in	O
earlier	O
papers	O
[	O

]	O
,	O
other	O
jetting	B
fluid	I
combinations	I
,	O

as	O

.	O

]	O

does	O

occur	O
and	O

time	O
controls	O
the	O
viscoelastic	O
behaviour	O
.	O

inkjet	B
fluid	I
assessment	I
methods	I

to	O
provide	B

full	I

search	I
.	O

bounded	O

.	O

HPCVIEW	B
:	O

A	O

paper	O
addresses	O
a	O
class	O
of	O

optimal	O
control	O

whose	O

``	O

and	O

computation	I
of	O

and	O
far	O

only	O

from	O

.	O
This	O
paper	O

control	O
problems	O

to	O
the	O
combinatorial	B
search	I
for	O

in	O
a	O

graph	O
.	O
Since	O

nodes	O

the	O
graph	O

weighted	O
in	O
a	O
sequence-dependent	B
manner	I
,	O
we	O

.	O

proposed	O

method	O

currently	O

to	O

problems	I

functions	I
.	O

problem	I
and	O
a	O

operation	I
problem	I
are	O

to	O

the	O
method	O

An	O
analytic	B
center	I
cutting	I
plane	I
method	I
for	O
semidefinite	B
feasibility	I
problems	I
Semidefinite	B
feasibility	I
problems	I
arise	O
in	O
many	O
areas	O
of	O
operations	B
research	I
.	O
The	O
abstract	O
form	O
of	O
these	O
problems	O
can	O
be	O
described	O
as	O
finding	O
a	O
point	O
in	O
a	O
nonempty	B
bounded	I
convex	I
body	I
Gamma	O
in	O
the	O
cone	O
of	O
symmetric	B
positive	I
semidefinite	I
matrices	I
.	O
Assume	O
that	O
Gamma	O
is	O
defined	O
by	O
an	O
oracle	B
,	O
which	O
for	O
any	O
given	O
m	O
*	O
m	O
symmetric	O
positive	O
semidefinite	O
matrix	O
Gamma	O
either	O
confirms	O
that	O
Y	O
epsilon	O
Gamma	O
or	O
returns	O
a	O
cut	O
,	O
i.e.	O
,	O
a	O
symmetric	O
matrix	O
A	O
such	O
that	O
Gamma	O
is	O
in	O
the	O
half-space	O
-LCB-	O
Y	O
:	O
A	O
.	O
Y	O
<	O
or	O
=	O
A	O
.	O
Y	O
-RCB-	O
.	O
We	O
study	O
an	O
analytic	O
center	O
cutting	O
plane	O
algorithm	O
for	O
this	O
problem	O
.	O
At	O
each	O
iteration	B
,	O
the	O
algorithm	O
computes	O
an	O
approximate	B
analytic	I
center	I
of	O
a	O
working	B
set	I
defined	O
by	O
the	O
cutting	O
plane	O
system	O
generated	O
in	O
the	O
previous	O
iterations	B
.	O
If	O
this	O
approximate	B
analytic	I
center	I
is	O
a	O
solution	O
,	O
then	O
the	O
algorithm	O
terminates	O
;	O
otherwise	O
the	O
new	O
cutting	O
plane	O
returned	O
by	O
the	O
oracle	B
is	O
added	O
into	O
the	O
system	O
.	O

.	O

A	O

of	O

has	O
not	O

.	O
The	O
proposed	O
multi-view	B
images	I
decoder	I
operates	O

of	O

.	O

images	I

of	O

nodes	O

and	O

of	O

nodes	O

specified	O

.	O

+	O
PlusII	O

tool	O
and	O
the	O
operating	B
frequency	I
is	O
30	B
MHz	I
.	O

can	O

in	O

the	O
decoder	O

the	O
proposed	O
architecture	O

that	O

architecture	O
works	O

the	O
frame	O
level	O
,	O

that	O

(	O

for	O

the	O
target	B
languages	I
.	O

A	O

ABSTRACT	O
Implicit	B
relevance	I
feedback	I
-LRB-	O
IRF	O
-RRB-	O
is	O
the	O
process	O
by	O
which	O
a	O
search	O
system	O
unobtrusively	O
gathers	O
evidence	O
on	O
searcher	O
interests	O
from	O
their	O
interaction	O
with	O
the	O
system	O
.	O
IRF	O
is	O
a	O
new	O
method	O
of	O
gathering	O
information	O
on	O
user	O
interest	O
and	O
,	O
if	O

is	O
to	O
be	O
used	O
in	O
operational	O
IR	O
systems	O

is	O
important	O
to	O
establish	O
when	O
it	O
performs	O
well	O
and	O
when	O
it	O
performs	O
poorly	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
investigate	O
how	O
the	O
use	O
and	O
effectiveness	O
of	O

is	O

by	O
three	O
factors	O
:	O
search	B
task	I

,	O
the	O
search	O
experience	O
of	O
the	O
user	O
and	O
the	O
stage	O
in	O
the	O
search	O
.	O
Our	O

suggest	O
that	O
all	O

of	O
these	O
factors	O
contribute	O
to	O
the	O
utility	O
of	O
IRF	O
.	O

Robust	O
Incentive	B
Techniques	O
for	O

one	O

today	O
's	O
P2P	B
systems	I
.	O

function	I

.	O

maxflowbased	O

.	O

.	O

Dynamic	B
spectrum	I
management	I
for	O
next-generation	O
DSL	O
systems	O
The	O
performance	O
of	O
DSL	O
systems	O
is	O
severely	O
constrained	O
by	O
crosstalk	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
electromagnetic	B
coupling	I
among	O
the	O
multiple	O
twisted	B
pairs	I
making	O
up	O
a	O
phone	B
cable	I
.	O
In	O
order	O
to	O
reduce	O
performance	O
loss	O
arising	O
from	O
crosstalk	O
,	O
DSL	O
systems	O
are	O
currently	O
designed	O
under	O
the	O
assumption	O
of	O
worst-case	O
crosstalk	O
scenarios	O
leading	O
to	O
overly	O
conservative	O
DSL	O
deployments	O
.	O
This	O
article	O
presents	O
a	O
new	O
paradigm	O
for	O
DSL	B
system	I
design	I
,	O
which	O
takes	O
into	O
account	O
the	O
multi-user	O
aspects	O
of	O
the	O
DSL	O
transmission	O
environment	O
.	O
Dynamic	B
spectrum	I
management	I
-LRB-	O
DSM	O
-RRB-	O
departs	O
from	O
the	O
current	O
design	O
philosophy	O
by	O
enabling	O
transceivers	B
to	O
autonomously	O
and	O
dynamically	O
optimize	O
their	O
communication	O
settings	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
both	O
the	O
channel	O
and	O
the	O
transmissions	O
of	O
neighboring	O
systems	O
.	O
Along	O
with	O
this	O
distributed	B
optimization	I
,	O
when	O
an	O
additional	O
degree	O
of	O
coordination	O
becomes	O
available	O
for	O
future	O
DSL	O
deployment	O
,	O
DSM	O
will	O
allow	O
even	O
greater	O
improvement	O
in	O
DSL	O
performance	O
.	O
Implementations	O
are	O
readily	O
applicable	O
without	O
causing	O
any	O
performance	O
degradation	O
to	O
the	O
existing	O
DSLs	O
under	O
static	B
spectrum	I
management	I
.	O
After	O
providing	O
an	O
overview	O
of	O
the	O
DSM	O
concept	O
,	O
this	O
article	O
reviews	O
two	O
practical	O
DSM	O
methods	O
:	O
iterative	B
water-filling	I
,	O
an	O
autonomous	B
distributed	I
power	I
control	I
method	I
enabling	O

Congestion	B
Games	I
with	O

Failures	I
:	O

Resources	I
ABSTRACT	O
We	O
define	O
a	O
new	O
class	O
of	O
games	O
,	O
congestion	B
games	I
with	O
loaddependent	O
failures	O
-LRB-	O
CGLFs	O
-RRB-	O
,	O
which	O
generalizes	O
the	O
well-known	O
class	O
of	O
congestion	B
games	I
,	O
by	O
incorporating	O
the	O
issue	O
of	O
resource	O
failures	O
into	O
congestion	B
games	I
.	O
In	O
a	O
CGLF	O
,	O
agents	O
share	O
a	O
common	O
set	O
of	O
resources	O
,	O
where	O
each	O
resource	O
has	O
a	O
cost	O
and	O
a	O
probability	O
of	O
failure	O
.	O
Each	O
agent	O
chooses	O
a	O
subset	O
of	O
the	O
resources	O
for	O
the	O
execution	O
of	O
his	O
task	O
,	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
maximize	O
his	O
own	O
utility	O
.	O
The	O
utility	O
of	O
an	O
agent	O
is	O
the	O
difference	O
between	O
his	O
benefit	O
from	O
successful	O
task	O
completion	O
and	O
the	O
sum	O
of	O
the	O
costs	O
over	O
the	O
resources	O
he	O
uses	O
.	O
CGLFs	O
possess	O
two	O
novel	O
features	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
the	O
first	O
model	O
to	O
incorporate	O
failures	O
into	O
congestion	O
settings	O
,	O
which	O
results	O
in	O
a	O
strict	O
generalization	O
of	O
congestion	B
games	I
.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
the	O
first	O
model	O
to	O
consider	O
load-dependent	B
failures	I
in	O
such	O
framework	O
,	O
where	O
the	O
failure	B
probability	I
of	O
each	O
resource	O
depends	O
on	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
agents	O
selecting	O
this	O
resource	O
.	O
Although	O
,	O
as	O
we	O
show	O
,	O
CGLFs	O
do	O
not	O
admit	O
a	O
potential	B
function	I
,	O
and	O
in	O
general	O
do	O
not	O
have	O
a	O
pure	B
strategy	I
Nash	I
equilibrium	I
,	O
our	O
main	O
theorem	O
proves	O
the	O
existence	O
of	O
a	O
pure	O
strategy	O
Nash	O
equilibrium	O
in	O
every	O
CGLF	O
with	O
identical	O

and	O

cost	O
functions	O
.	O

Direct	B
aperture	I
optimization	I
:	O
A	O
turnkey	B
solution	I
for	O
step-and-shoot	B
IMRT	I
IMRT	B
treatment	I
plans	I
for	O
step-and-shoot	O
delivery	O
have	O
traditionally	O
been	O
produced	O
through	O
the	O
optimization	O
of	O
intensity	B
distributions	I
-LRB-	O
or	O
maps	B
-RRB-	O
for	O
each	O
beam	B
angle	I
.	O
The	O
optimization	B
step	I
is	O
followed	O
by	O
the	O
application	O
of	O
a	O
leaf-sequencing	B
algorithm	I
that	O
translates	O
each	O
intensity	B
map	I
into	O
a	O

of	O
deliverable	O
aperture	O
shapes	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
article	O

we	O

planning	I
system	I

we	O

instead	O

and	O

weights	O
of	O
the	O
apertures	O
.	O
We	O
call	O
this	O
approach	O
``	O
direct	B
aperture	I
optimization	I
.	O
''	O
This	O
technique	O
allows	O

user	O

maximum	O

of	O

treatment	O

.	O

the	O
machine	B
dependent	I

the	O

.	O

using	O
a	O
simulated	B

algorithm	I
.	O

patient	B

ABSTRACT	O

about	O

.	O

feedback	I

in	O

query	I

.	O

AP	O

information	O

hierarchy	I

Bistability	B
of	O
harmonically	B
forced	I
relaxation	I
oscillations	I
Relaxation	O
oscillations	O
appear	O
in	O
processes	O
which	O
involve	O
transitions	O
between	O
two	O
states	O
characterized	O
by	O
fast	O
and	O
slow	O
time	O
scales	O
.	O

is	O
coupled	O
to	O

external	B
periodic	I
force	I
its	O

by	O
the	O
force	O
results	O
in	O
a	O
response	O
which	O
can	O
include	O
multiple	O
periodicities	O
and	O
bistability	B
.	O
The	O
prototype	O
of	O

is	O
the	O
harmonically	O
driven	O
van	B
der	I
Pol	I
equation	I
which	O
displays	O
regions	O
in	O
the	O
parameter	O
space	O
of	O
the	O
driving	O
force	O
amplitude	O
where	O

of	O
periods	O
2n	O
+	O

.	O

parameter	O

of	O

for	O
the	O

related	O

driven	I
Stoker-Haag	I
piecewise	I

equation	I
.	O

results	O
are	O

over	O

of	O
the	O
control	B
parameter	I
space	I
of	O
the	O
system	O
.	O

for	O

.	O

less	O

forced	O

der	I
Pol	I

the	O

.	O

Packet	O
spacing	O
:	O
an	O
enabling	O
mechanism	O
for	O
delivering	O
multimedia	O
content	O
in	O
computational	O
grids	O
Streaming	B
multimedia	I
with	O
UDP	B
has	O
become	O
increasingly	O
popular	O
over	O
distributed	B
systems	I
like	O
the	O
Internet	B
.	O
Scientific	O
applications	O
that	O
stream	B
multimedia	I
include	O
remote	B
computational	I
steering	I
of	O
visualization	B
data	I
and	O
video-on-demand	O
teleconferencing	O
over	O
the	O
Access	O
Grid	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
UDP	B
does	O
not	O
possess	O
a	O
self-regulating	O
,	O
congestion-control	O
mechanism	O
;	O
and	O
most	O
best-effort	O
traffic	O
is	O
served	O
by	O
congestion-controlled	O
TCP	O
.	O
Consequently	O
,	O
UDP	B
steals	O
bandwidth	O
from	O
TCP	O
such	O
that	O
TCP	O
flows	O
starve	O
for	O
network	O
resources	O
.	O
With	O
the	O
volume	O
of	O
Internet	B
traffic	O
continuing	O
to	O
increase	O
,	O
the	O
perpetuation	O
of	O
UDP-based	O
streaming	O
will	O
cause	O
the	O
Internet	O
to	O
collapse	O
as	O
it	O
did	O
in	O
the	O
mid-1980	O
's	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
non-congestion-controlled	O
TCP	O
.	O
To	O
address	O
this	O
problem	O
,	O
we	O
introduce	O
the	O
counter-intuitive	O
notion	O
of	O
inter-packet	B
spacing	I
with	O
control	O
feedback	O
to	O
enable	O
UDP-based	O
applications	O
to	O
perform	O
well	O
in	O
the	O
next-generation	O
Internet	O
and	O
computational	O
grids	O
.	O
When	O
compared	O
with	O
traditional	O
UDP-based	O
streaming	O
,	O
we	O
illustrate	O
that	O
our	O
approach	O
can	O
reduce	O
packet	O
loss	O
over	O
50	O
%	O
without	O
adversely	O
affecting	O
delivered	O
throughput	O

Optimal	B
control	I
using	O
the	O
transport	B
equation	I
:	O
the	O
Liouville	B
machine	I
Transport	O
theory	O
describes	O
the	O
scattering	B
behavior	I
of	O
physical	B
particles	I
such	O
as	O
photons	O
.	O
Here	O
we	O
show	O
how	O
to	O
connect	O
this	O
theory	O
to	O
optimal	B
control	I
theory	O
and	O
to	O
adaptive	B
behavior	I
of	O
agents	O
embedded	O
in	O
an	O
environment	O
.	O
Environments	O
and	O
tasks	O
are	O
defined	O
by	O
physical	O
boundary	O
conditions	O
.	O
Given	O
some	O
task	O
,	O
we	O
compute	O
a	O
set	O
of	O
probability	O
densities	O
on	O
continuous	O
state	O
and	O
action	O
and	O
time	O
.	O
From	O
these	O
densities	O
we	O
derive	O
an	O
optimal	O
policy	O
such	O
that	O
for	O
all	O
states	O
the	O
most	O
likely	O
action	O
maximizes	O
the	O
probability	O
of	O
reaching	O
a	O
predefined	O
goal	O
state	O
.	O
Liouville	O
's	O
conservation	O
theorem	O
tells	O
us	O
that	O
the	O
conditional	O
density	O
at	O
time	O
t	O
,	O
state	O
s	O
,	O
and	O
action	O
a	O

)	O

[	O
10	O
]	O
.	O
Alternatively	O
,	O
MANET	B
protocols	I
are	O
designed	O
to	O
be	O

to	O

with	O

of	O
nodes	O
,	O
however	O

aim	O
to	O
allow	O

to	O
occur	O
between	O
any	O
two	O
nodes	O
[	O
2	O
]	O
.	O

is	O
often	O

by	O

and	O
so	O

high	O

and	O

ABSTRACT	O
The	O
world	O
wide	O
web	O
contains	O

contents	O
that	O
are	O
interconnected	O
via	O
complex	O

.	O
This	O
huge	O
database	O
violates	O
the	O
assumption	O
held	O
by	O
most	O
of	O
conventional	O
statistical	O
methods	O
that	O
each	O

as	O

and	O
identical	O
sample	O
.	O

learning	O
methods	O

page	O
classification	B

link	B
structure	I
.	O

recently	O

early	O
stage	O
.	O

paper	O

.	O

ABSTRACT	O
An	O
ever-increasing	O
amount	O
of	O
information	O
on	O
the	O
Web	O
today	O
is	O
available	O
only	O
through	O
search	O
interfaces	O
:	O
the	O
users	O
have	O
to	O
type	O
in	O
a	O
set	O
of	O
keywords	O
in	O
a	O
search	O
form	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
access	O
the	O
pages	O
from	O
certain	O
Web	O
sites	O
.	O
These	O
pages	O
are	O
often	O
referred	O
to	O
as	O
the	O
Hidden	B
Web	I
or	O
the	O
Deep	B
Web	I
.	O

no	O

links	O
to	O

Web	I
pages	O

engines	O
can	O
not	O
discover	O
and	O

such	O
pages	O
and	O
thus	O
do	O
not	O
return	O
them	O
in	O
the	O
results	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
according	O
to	O
recent	O
studies	O
,	O
the	O
content	O
provided	O
by	O
many	O
Hidden	B
Web	I
sites	O
is	O
often	O
of	O
very	O
high	O
quality	O
and	O
can	O
be	O
extremely	O
valuable	O
to	O
many	O
users	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
study	O
how	O
we	O
can	O
build	O
an	O
effective	O

Web	I
crawler	O
that	O
can	O
autonomously	O
discover	O
and	O

pages	O
from	O
the	O
Hidden	O

.	O

the	O
only	O
``	O
entry	O
point	O
''	O
to	O
a	O
Hidden	B
Web	I
site	O
is	O
a	O
query	O
interface	O
,	O
the	O
main	O
challenge	O
that	O
a	O
Hidden	B
Web	I
crawler	O
has	O
to	O
face	O

how	O

automatically	O
generate	O

.	O

and	O

.	O

.	O

of	O

policies	O
on	O
4	O
real	O
Hidden	B
Web	I

and	O
our	O

.	O

An	O

of	O

/	I
control	I
The	O
piezoelectric	B
actuator	I
has	O
high-speed	O
response	O
in	O
comparison	O
with	O
the	O
electro-magnetic	O
actuator	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
not	O

to	O
achieve	O
both	O
high-speed	O
and	O
high-precision	B
response	I
by	O
feedforward	B
control	O
only	O
because	O
the	O
piezoelectric	O
element	O
has	O
nonlinear	B
properties	I
such	O
as	O
the	O
hysteresis	B
effect	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
feedback	B
control	I
is	O

to	O

performance	O
.	O
We	O

a	O
control	B
design	I
method	I
to	O

both	O
high-speed	O
and	O
high-precision	B
response	I
for	O
piezoelectric	B
actuators	I
using	O
the	O
discrete-time	O
H/sub	O
infinity	O
/	O
control	O
method	O
and	O

control	O
scheme	O
.	O

effectiveness	O
of	O
our	O

scheme	I

-LRB-	O

-RRB-	O

control-for	O
very	O

induction	O
motor	O
drives	O

by	O
a	O

-LRB-	O

-RRB-	O
is	O

.	O

computers	I

so-called	O

sign	I
problem	I

complexity	O
.	O

systems	I

.	O
