Vocabulary	B
Independent	O
Spoken	B
Term	I
Detection	I
ABSTRACT	O
We	O
are	O
interested	O
in	O
retrieving	O
information	O
from	O
speech	O
data	O
like	O
broadcast	O
news	O
,	O
telephone	O
conversations	O
and	O
roundtable	O
meetings	O
.	O
Today	O
,	O
most	O
systems	O
use	O
large	O
vocabulary	B
continuous	O
speech	O
recognition	O
tools	O
to	O
produce	O
word	O
transcripts	O
;	O
the	O
transcripts	O
are	O
indexed	O
and	O
query	O
terms	O
are	O
retrieved	O
from	O
the	O
index	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
query	O
terms	O
that	O
are	O
not	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
recognizer	O
's	O
vocabulary	B
can	O
not	O
be	O
retrieved	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
recall	O
of	O
the	O
search	O
is	O
affected	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
to	O
the	O
output	O
word	O
transcript	O
,	O
advanced	O
systems	O
provide	O
also	O
phonetic	B
transcripts	I
,	O
against	O
which	O
query	O
terms	O
can	O
be	O
matched	O
phonetically	O
.	O
Such	O
phonetic	B
transcripts	I
suffer	O
from	O
lower	O
accuracy	O
and	O
can	O
not	O
be	O
an	O
alternative	O
to	O
word	O
transcripts	O
.	O
We	O
present	O
a	O
vocabulary	B
independent	O
system	O
that	O
can	O
handle	O
arbitrary	O
queries	O
,	O
exploiting	O
the	O
information	O
provided	O
by	O
having	O
both	O
word	O
transcripts	O
and	O
phonetic	O
transcripts	O
.	O
A	O
speech	B
recognizer	I
generates	O
word	O
confusion	O
networks	O
and	O
phonetic	O
lattices	O
.	O
The	O
transcripts	O
are	O
indexed	O
for	O
query	O
processing	O
and	O
ranking	O
purpose	O
.	O
The	O
value	O
of	O
the	O
proposed	O
method	O
is	O
demonstrated	O

.	O

Fidelity	B
of	O
quantum	B
teleportation	I
through	O
noisy	O
channels	O
We	O
investigate	O
quantum	B
teleportation	I
through	O
noisy	B
quantum	I
channels	I
by	O
solving	O
analytically	O
and	O
numerically	O
a	O
master	O
equation	O
in	O
the	O
Lindblad	O
form	O
.	O
We	O
calculate	O
the	O
fidelity	B
as	O
a	O
function	O
of	O
decoherence	O
rates	O
and	O
angles	O
of	O
a	O
state	O
to	O
be	O
teleported	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
found	O
that	O
the	O
average	O
fidelity	B
and	O
the	O
range	O
of	O
states	O
to	O
be	O
accurately	O
teleported	O
depend	O
on	O
types	O
of	O
noises	O
acting	O
on	O
quantum	B
channels	I
.	O

the	O
quantum	B
channels	I
are	O
subject	O
to	O
isotropic	B
noise	I
,	O
the	O
average	O
fidelity	B
decays	O
to	O
1/2	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
smaller	O
than	O
the	O
best	O
possible	O
value	O
of	O
2/3	O
obtained	O
only	O
by	O
the	O
classical	B
communication	I
.	O
On	O
the	O
other	O
hand	O
,	O
if	O
the	O
noisy	B
quantum	I
channel	I
is	O
modeled	O
by	O
a	O
single	O
Lindblad	O
operator	O
,	O
the	O
average	O
fidelity	O
is	O
always	O
greater	O
than	O
2/3	O

Modeling	B
collaboration	I
processes	I
is	O
a	O
challenging	O
task	O
.	O

approaches	I
are	O
not	O

of	O
expressing	O

unpredictable	O

of	O
human	B

,	O
which	O

by	O
the	O
social	O
context	O
of	O

collaborators	O

approach	I

processes	I

of	I

of	I

and	I

of	I

structures	I

and	O

of	O

and	O

,	O

and	O

.	O

models	I
-LRB-	O
M&RM	O
-RRB-	O
for	O

.	O

the	O

concept	O

Computing	O
transient	B
gating	I
charge	I
movement	I
of	O
voltage-dependent	O
ion	O
channels	O
The	O
opening	O
of	O
voltage-gated	O
sodium	O
,	O
potassium	O
,	O
and	O
calcium	O
ion	B
channels	I
has	O
a	O

relationship	O
with	O
voltage	O
.	O

to	O
changes	O
in	O
the	O
transmembrane	B
voltage	I
,	O
structural	O
movements	O
of	O
an	O
ion	B
channel	I
that	O

channel	O
opening	O
generate	O
a	O
capacitative	O
gating	B
current	I
.	O

net	O
gating	O
charge	O
displacement	O
due	O
to	O
membrane	O
depolarization	O

in	O

ABSTRACT	O
In	O
traditional	O
game	B
theory	I
,	O
players	O
are	O
typically	O
endowed	O
with	O
exogenously	O
given	O
knowledge	O
of	O
the	O
structure	O
of	O
the	O
game	O
--	O
either	O
full	O
omniscient	O
knowledge	O
or	O
partial	O
but	O
fixed	O
information	O
.	O
In	O
real	O
life	O
,	O
however	O
,	O
people	O
are	O
often	O
unaware	O
of	O
the	O

of	O
taking	O
a	O
particular	O
action	O
until	O
they	O
perform	O
research	O
into	O
its	O
consequences	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
model	O
this	O
phenomenon	O
.	O
We	O
imagine	O
a	O
player	O
engaged	O
in	O
a	O
questionand-answer	O
session	O
,	O
asking	O
questions	O
both	O
about	O
his	O
or	O
her	O
own	O

and	O
about	O
the	O
state	O
of	O
reality	O
;	O
thus	O
we	O
call	O
this	O
setting	O
``	O
Socratic	O
''	O
game	B
theory	I
.	O
In	O
a	O
Socratic	B
game	I
,	O
players	O
begin	O
with	O
an	O
a	O
priori	B
probability	I
distribution	I
over	O
many	O
possible	O
worlds	O
,	O
with	O
a	O
different	O

world	O
.	O

can	O
make	O
queries	O
,	O

some	O
cost	O
,	O
to	O
learn	O
partial	O
information	O
about	O
which	O
of	O
the	O
possible	O
worlds	O
is	O
the	O
actual	O
world	O
,	O
before	O
choosing	O
an	O
action	O
.	O
We	O
consider	O
two	O
query	O
models	O
:	O
-LRB-	O
1	O
-RRB-	O
an	O
unobservable-query	O
model	O
,	O
in	O
which	O
players	O
learn	O
only	O
the	O
response	O
to	O
their	O
own	O
queries	O
,	O
and	O
-LRB-	O
2	O
-RRB-	O
an	O
observable-query	O
model	O
,	O
in	O
which	O
players	O
also	O
learn	O
which	O
queries	O
their	O
opponents	O
made	O
.	O
The	O
results	O
in	O
this	O
paper	O
consider	O
cases	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
underlying	O
worlds	O
of	O
a	O
two-player	O
Socratic	B
game	I
are	O
either	O
constant-sum	B
games	I
or	O
strategically	O

games	O
,	O
a	O
class	O
that	O
generalizes	O

games	I
to	O
include	O
all	O
games	O
in	O

sum	O

.	O

.	O

Methods	O
for	O

detection	I

centralized	I
methods	I
,	O
which	O
rely	O
on	O

shared	I
models	I
.	O
In	O
data	B
mining	I
,	O
the	O
notion	B
of	I
locality	I
is	O
often	O
given	O
as	O
distance	B
between	I
data	I
values	I
(	O

metric	I

distance	I
)	O
.	O

data	O

to	I
the	I
value	I
of	I
its	I
nearest	I
neighbors	I
in	O
terms	O
of	O
data	O
distance	O
[	O
42	O
]	O
.	O

,	O

notion	I
of	I

between	O

.	O

(	O
i.e.	O
,	O
data	O

distance	O
among	O

other	O

,	O

,	O
while	O
values	B
that	I
are	I
less	I
similar	I

in	I
a	I
lower	I
density	I
.	O

can	O

outside	O
of	O
any	O

but	O
,	O

,	O
can	B
form	I
a	I
cluster	I
too	O
.	O

if	I
a	I
datum	I

compared	O
to	O

challenge	O
.	O

On	O
generalized	B
Gaussian	I
quadratures	I
for	O
exponentials	O
and	O
their	O
applications	O
We	O
introduce	O
new	O
families	O
of	O
Gaussian-type	O
quadratures	O
for	O
weighted	B
integrals	I
of	O
exponential	O
functions	O
and	O
consider	O
their	O
applications	O
to	O
integration	O
and	O
interpolation	O
of	O
bandlimited	O
functions	O
.	O
We	O
use	O
a	O
generalization	O
of	O
a	O
representation	O
theorem	O
due	O
to	O
Caratheodory	O
to	O
derive	O
these	O
quadratures	O
.	O
For	O
each	O
positive	O
measure	O
,	O
the	O
quadratures	O
are	O
parameterized	O
by	O
eigenvalues	B
of	O
the	O
Toeplitz	B
matrix	I
constructed	O
from	O
the	O
trigonometric	B
moments	I
of	O
the	O
measure	O
.	O
For	O
a	O
given	O
accuracy	O
epsilon	O
,	O
selecting	O
an	O
eigenvalue	B
close	O
to	O
epsilon	O
yields	O
an	O
approximate	B
quadrature	O
with	O
that	O
accuracy	O
.	O
To	O
compute	O
its	O
weights	O
and	O
nodes	O
,	O
we	O
present	O
a	O
new	O
fast	O
algorithm	O
.	O
These	O
new	O
quadratures	O
can	O
be	O
used	O
to	O
approximate	B
and	O
integrate	B
bandlimited	B
functions	I
,	O
such	O
as	O
prolate	B
spheroidal	I
wave	I
functions	I

Combinatorial	O
Resource	B
Scheduling	O
for	O
Multiagent	O
MDPs	O
ABSTRACT	O
Optimal	O
resource	B
scheduling	O
in	O
multiagent	O
systems	O
is	O
a	O
computationally	O
challenging	O
task	O
,	O
particularly	O
when	O
the	O
values	O
of	O
resources	O
are	O
not	O
additive	O
.	O
We	O
consider	O
the	O
combinatorial	O
problem	O
of	O
scheduling	B
the	O
usage	O
of	O
multiple	O
resources	B
among	O
agents	O
that	O
operate	O
in	O
stochastic	O
environments	O
,	O
modeled	O
as	O
Markov	B
decision	I
processes	I
-LRB-	O
MDPs	O
-RRB-	O
.	O
In	O
recent	O
years	O
,	O
efficient	O
resource-allocation	O
algorithms	O
have	O
been	O
developed	O
for	O
agents	O
with	O
resource	B
values	O
induced	O
by	O
MDPs	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
this	O
prior	O
work	O
has	O
focused	O
on	O
static	O
resource-allocation	O
problems	O
where	O
resources	B
are	O
distributed	O
once	O
and	O
then	O
utilized	O
in	O
infinite-horizon	O
MDPs	O
.	O
We	O
extend	O
those	O
existing	O
models	O
to	O
the	O
problem	O
of	O
combinatorial	O
resource	B
scheduling	O
,	O
where	O
agents	O
persist	O
only	O
for	O
finite	O
periods	O
between	O
their	O
-LRB-	O
predefined	O
-RRB-	O
arrival	O
and	O
departure	O
times	O
,	O
requiring	O
resources	O
only	O

A	O

of	O
probability	B
matching	I
and	O
rational	B
choice	O
In	O

probability	B
learning	I
task	I

are	O

with	O
a	O

.	O
Rational	B

theory	O
requires	O
that	O

to	O
the	O

probabilities	I
.	O

.	O

Adaptive	O
optimizing	B
compilers	O
for	O

century	O

.	O

biased	B
random	I

.	O

Robust	B
self-tuning	I
PID	I
controller	I
for	O
nonlinear	B
systems	I
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
robust	B
self-tuning	I
PID	I
controller	I
suitable	O
for	O
nonlinear	B
systems	I
.	O
The	O
control	O
system	O
employs	O
a	O
preload	B
relay	I
-LRB-	O
P_Relay	O
-RRB-	O
in	O
series	O
with	O
a	O
PID	O
controller	O
.	O
The	O
P_Relay	O
ensures	O
a	O
high	O
gain	O
to	O
yield	O
a	O
robust	B
performance	I
.	O
However	O
,	O
it	O
also	O
incurs	O
a	O
chattering	B
phenomenon	I
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O

we	O

as	O
a	O

occurring	I
signal	I
for	O
tuning	O
and	O

the	O
PID	O
controller	O
as	O
the	O
operating	B
regime	I
digresses	O
.	O
No	O
other	O
explicit	O
input	O
signal	O
is	O
required	O
.	O
Once	O

PID	O
controller	O
is	O

point	O

.	O
However	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
invoked	O
when	O
there	O
is	O
a	O
change	O
in	O
setpoint	O
to	O
another	O
operating	B
regime	I
.	O
In	O
this	O
way	O
,	O
the	O
approach	O
is	O
also	O
applicable	O
to	O
time-varying	B
systems	I
as	O

PID	O

can	O
be	O
continuous	O
,	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
latest	O

of	O

characteristics	O
.	O

on	O

stability	B

of	O

3D	B
reconstruction	I
from	O
uncalibrated-camera	B
optical	I
flow	I
and	O
its	O
reliability	B
evaluation	I
We	O
present	O
a	O
scheme	O
for	O
reconstructing	O
a	O
3D	O
structure	O
from	O
optical	O
flow	O
observed	O
by	O
a	O
camera	O
with	O
an	O
unknown	O
focal	O
length	O
in	O
a	O
statistically	O
optimal	O
way	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
evaluating	O
the	O
reliability	O
of	O
the	O
computed	O
shape	O
.	O
First	O
,	O
the	O
flow	B
fundamental	I
matrices	I
are	O
optimally	O
computed	O
from	O
the	O
observed	O
flow	O
.	O
They	O
are	O
then	O
decomposed	O
into	O
the	O
focal	O
length	O
,	O
its	O
rate	O
of	O
change	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
motion	B
parameters	I
.	O
Next	O
,	O
the	O
flow	O
is	O
optimally	O
corrected	O
so	O
that	O
it	O
satisfies	O
the	O
epipolar	B
equation	I
exactly	O
.	O

Multiple	B
shooting	I
using	O
a	O

stable	I
integrator	I
for	O

equations	I
In	O

first	O
author	O

that	O
a	O

stable	O

when	O

a	O
stiff	B
boundary-value	I
problem	I
in	O
ordinary	B

equations	I
-LRB-	O
ODEs	O
-RRB-	O
,	O
when	O

of	O
the	O
interval	O
.	O
A	O

stable	O
implicit	B

method	I
,	O

,	O

,	O

IIIA	I
formulae	I
,	O
has	O

in	O

step-size	O

integrator	I
,	O
which	O
could	O
be	O
used	O

approach	O
.	O

equations	I
-LRB-	O

-RRB-	O

.	O

of	O

,	O

Real-time	B
estimations	I
of	O

for	O

structures	I

.	O
Well-known	O
frequency	B
estimation	I
methods	O
are	O

and	O

.	O

method	I
is	O

of	O
a	O

equation	I
for	O

of	O

,	O
and	O

.	O

.	O

that	O

auto	O

-LRB-	O
AR	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
auto	O

and	O
moving	O
average	O
-LRB-	O
ARMA	B
-RRB-	O
methods	O
are	O
unsuitable	O

.	O

other	O
methods	O

method	O
have	O
fast	O
tracking	O
capability	O
.	O

the	O

is	O
very	O

.	O

notch	I
filter	I
and	O

maximum	I

methods	I
have	O
average	O
performances	O
.	O

An	O
Evaluation	O
of	O
Availability	B
Latency	I
in	O
Carrier-based	O
Vehicular	O
Ad-Hoc	O
Networks	O
Shahram	O
ABSTRACT	O
On-demand	O
delivery	O
of	O
audio	B
and	I
video	I
clips	I
in	O
peer-to-peer	O
vehicular	O

networks	O
is	O
an	O
emerging	O
area	O
of	O
research	O
.	O
Our	O
target	O
environment	O
uses	O
data	B
carriers	I
,	O
termed	B
zebroids	I
,	O
where	O
a	O

.	O
In	O

variation	O
in	O

latency	I
with	O

as	O
a	O

of	O
a	O

of	O

such	O
as	O

per	O
device	O
,	O

,	O
and	O

policies	O
employed	O
by	O

.	O

and	O

,	O
we	O
gain	O
novel	O
insights	O
into	O
the	O
design	O
of	O

systems	O
.	O
Significant	O
improvements	O
in	O
latency	B
can	O
be	O
obtained	O
with	O
zebroids	B
at	O
the	O
cost	O
of	O
a	O
minimal	O

.	O
These	O
improvements	O
occur	O
even	O
in	O
scenarios	O
with	O
lower	O
accuracy	O
in	O
the	O
predictions	O
of	O
the	O
car	O
routes	O
.	O
Two	O
particularly	O
surprising	O
findings	O
are	O
:	O
-LRB-	O
1	O
-RRB-	O
a	O
naive	B
random	I
replacement	I
policy	I
employed	O
by	O
the	O
zebroids	O
shows	O
competitive	O
performance	O
,	O
and	O
-LRB-	O
2	O

as	O
who	O
will	O
want	O
to	O

the	O
information	O
that	O
is	O

by	O
the	O
system	O

Understanding	O
Internet	B
traffic	I
streams	I
:	O
dragonflies	B
and	O
tortoises	B
We	O
present	O
the	O
concept	O
of	O
network	B
traffic	I
streams	I
and	O
the	O
ways	O
they	O
aggregate	O
into	O
flows	O
through	O
Internet	O
links	O
.	O
We	O
describe	O
a	O
method	O
of	O
measuring	O
the	O
size	O
and	O
lifetime	O
of	O
Internet	O
streams	O
,	O
and	O
use	O
this	O
method	O
to	O
characterize	O
traffic	B
distributions	I
at	O
two	O
different	O
sites	O
.	O
We	O
find	O
that	O
although	O
most	O
streams	O
-LRB-	O
about	O
45	O
percent	O
of	O
them	O
-RRB-	O
are	O
dragonflies	B
,	O
lasting	O
less	O
than	O
2	O
seconds	O
,	O
a	O
significant	O
number	O
of	O
streams	O
have	O
lifetimes	O
of	O
hours	O
to	O
days	O
,	O
and	O
can	O
carry	O
a	O
high	O
proportion	O
-LRB-	O
50-60	O
percent	O
-RRB-	O
of	O
the	O
total	O
bytes	O
on	O
a	O
given	O
link	O
.	O
We	O
define	O
tortoises	B
as	O
streams	O
that	O
last	O
longer	O
than	O
15	O
minutes	O
.	O
We	O
point	O
out	O
that	O
streams	O
can	O
be	O
classified	O
not	O
only	O
by	O
lifetime	O
-LRB-	O
dragonflies	B
and	O
tortoises	B
-RRB-	O
but	O
also	O
by	O
size	O
-LRB-	O
mice	B
and	O
elephants	B
-RRB-	O
,	O
and	O
note	O
that	O
stream	O
size	O
and	O
lifetime	O
are	O
independent	O
dimensions	O
.	O
We	O
submit	O
that	O
ISPs	B
need	O
to	O
be	O
aware	O
of	O
the	O
distribution	O
of	O
Internet	O
stream	O
sizes	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
impact	O
of	O
the	O
difference	O
in	O
behavior	O
between	O
short	O
and	O
long	O
streams	O
.	O
In	O
particular	O
,	O
any	O
forwarding	B
cache	I
mechanisms	I
in	O
Internet	B
routers	I
must	O
be	O
able	O
to	O
cope	O
with	O
a	O
high	O
volume	O
of	O
short	O
streams	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
ISPs	B
should	O
realize	O
that	O
long-running	B
streams	I
can	O
contribute	O
a	O
significant	O
fraction	O
of	O
their	O
packet	O
and	O
byte	O
volumes-something	O
they	O
may	O
not	O
have	O
allowed	O
for	O
when	O
using	O
traditional	O
``	O
flat	O
rate	O
user	O
bandwidth	O
consumption	O
''	O
approaches	O
to	O
provisioning	O
and	O
engineering	O

AdaRank	O
:	O
A	O
Boosting	B
Algorithm	O
for	O
Information	B
Retrieval	I
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
address	O
the	O
issue	O
of	O
learning	B
to	I
rank	I
for	O
document	B
retrieval	I
.	O
In	O
the	O
task	O
,	O
a	O
model	O
is	O
automatically	O
created	O
with	O
some	O
training	O
data	O
and	O
then	O
is	O
utilized	O
for	O
ranking	O
of	O
documents	O
.	O
The	O
goodness	O
of	O
a	O
model	O
is	O
usually	O
evaluated	O
with	O
performance	O
measures	O
such	O
as	O
MAP	O
-LRB-	O
Mean	O
Average	O
Precision	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
NDCG	O
-LRB-	O
Normalized	O
Discounted	O
Cumulative	O
Gain	O
-RRB-	O
.	O
Ideally	O
a	O
learning	O
algorithm	O
would	O
train	O
a	O
ranking	B
model	I
that	O
could	O
directly	O
optimize	O
the	O
performance	O
measures	O
with	O
respect	O
to	O
the	O
training	O
data	O
.	O
Existing	O
methods	O
,	O
however	O
,	O
are	O
only	O
able	O
to	O
train	B
ranking	I
models	I
by	O
minimizing	O
loss	O
functions	O
loosely	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
performance	O
measures	O
.	O
For	O
example	O
,	O
Ranking	O
SVM	O
and	O
RankBoost	B
train	B
ranking	I
models	I
by	O
minimizing	O
classification	O
errors	O
on	O
instance	O
pairs	O
.	O
To	O
deal	O
with	O
the	O
problem	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
novel	B
learning	I
algorithm	I
within	O
the	O
framework	O
of	O
boosting	B
,	O
which	O
can	O
minimize	O
a	O
loss	O
function	O
directly	O
defined	O
on	O
the	O
performance	O
measures	O
.	O
Our	O
algorithm	O
,	O
referred	O
to	O
as	O
AdaRank	O
,	O
repeatedly	O
constructs	O
`	O
weak	B
rankers	I
'	O
on	O
the	O
basis	O
of	O
re-weighted	B
training	I
data	I
and	O
finally	O
linearly	O
combines	O
the	O
weak	B
rankers	I
for	O
making	O
ranking	O
predictions	O
.	O
We	O
prove	O
that	O
the	O
training	B
process	I
of	O
AdaRank	O
is	O
exactly	O
that	O
of	O
enhancing	O
the	O
performance	O
measure	O
used	O
.	O
Experimental	O
results	O
on	O
four	O
benchmark	O
datasets	O
show	O
that	O
AdaRank	O
significantly	O
outperforms	O
the	O
baseline	O
methods	O
of	O
BM25	O
,	O
Ranking	O
SVM	O
,	O
and	O
RankBoost	B
.	O

Nonlinear	B
control	I
of	O

alloy	I

Shape	B

Alloy	I
-LRB-	O
SMA	O
-RRB-	O
.	O

.	O

.	O

for	O

loop	I

of	O

.	O

.	O

on	O
Variable	B
Structure	I

.	O

.	O

.	O

show	O

of	O

system	O
.	O
Computer	O

and	O

results	O
for	O

stabilization	B
and	O

situations	O
are	O

presented	O

The	O

of	I
plasmas	I

Schema	B
evolution	I
in	O
data	B
warehouses	I
We	O
address	O
the	O
issues	O
related	O
to	O
the	O
evolution	O
and	O
maintenance	O
of	O
data	O
warehousing	O
systems	O
,	O
when	O
underlying	O
data	B
sources	I
change	O
their	O
schema	O
capabilities	O
.	O
These	O
changes	O
can	O
invalidate	O
views	O
at	O
the	O
data	O
warehousing	O
system	O
.	O
We	O
present	O
an	O
approach	O
for	O
dynamically	O
adapting	O
views	O
according	O
to	O
schema	O
changes	O
arising	O
on	O
source	B
relations	I
.	O
This	O
type	O
of	O
maintenance	O
concerns	O
both	O
the	O
schema	O

ABSTRACT	O
In	O

paper	O

resource	B
allocation	I
game	O

system	O
.	O
Multiple	O
users	O

-LRB-	O
bids	O
-RRB-	O

machines	O

their	O

.	O

and	O

of	O
the	O
allocation	O

is	O

measures	O
of	O

that	O

but	O
poor	O

proposed	O
allocation	O
scheme	O
achieves	O
a	O
nice	O
balance	O
of	O
high	O
degrees	O
of	O
efficiency	B
and	O
fairness	B
at	O
the	O
equilibrium	O
.	O

results	O
demonstrate	O
that	O

predicts	O
complicated	O

data	I
with	O

algorithms	I
.	O

,	O

that	O

of	I
models	I

data	O
by	O

is	O
effective	O
for	O
compatibility	O
of	O

prediction	O
performance	O

complexity	O
.	O
However	O

solved	O
in	O
SW-SVR	B
.	O
Firstly	O
,	O
the	O
prediction	O
performance	O
of	O
SW-SVR	O
sometimes	O
deteriorates	O
despite	O
an	O
increase	O
of	O
training	B
data	I
.	O
In	O
particular	O
,	O

under	O
the	O
conditions	O
that	O
prediction	O
horizons	O
are	O
6	O
h	O
as	O
shown	O

3.	O
This	O
is	O
because	O
data	O

by	O

involves	O
unnecessary	O
training	B
data	I
for	O

.	O

the	O

data	O

data	O

are	O

prediction	O

of	O
SW-SVR	B
never	O

to	O
an	O
increase	O
of	O
training	B
data	I
.	O

so	O

.	O

SVR	I
.	O

.	O

.	O

The	O

Auction	I
Problem	I

a	O

*	O
ABSTRACT	O

strategy	I

for	O
a	O

E193FP	O
LCD	O
monitor	O
,	O

are	O

than	O

of	O
other	O

auctions	O

behavior	I

of	O

system	O
,	O

doing	O

.	O

than	O

.	O

for	O

more	O

estimates	O

Relaxed	O
Online	O
SVMs	O
for	O
Spam	B
Filtering	I
ABSTRACT	O
Spam	O
is	O
a	O
key	O
problem	O
in	O
electronic	O
communication	O
,	O
including	O
large-scale	O
email	O
systems	O
and	O
the	O
growing	O
number	O
of	O
blogs	B
.	O
Content-based	O
filtering	O
is	O
one	O
reliable	O
method	O
of	O
combating	O
this	O
threat	O
in	O
its	O
various	O
forms	O
,	O
but	O
some	O
academic	O
researchers	O
and	O
industrial	O
practitioners	O
disagree	O
on	O
how	O
best	O
to	O
filter	O
spam	O
.	O
The	O
former	O
have	O
advocated	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
Support	B
Vector	I
Machines	I
-LRB-	O
SVMs	O
-RRB-	O
for	O
content-based	O
filtering	O
,	O
as	O
this	O
machine	O
learning	O
methodology	O
gives	O
state-of-the-art	O
performance	O
for	O
text	O
classification	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
similar	O
performance	O
gains	O
have	O
yet	O
to	O
be	O
demonstrated	O
for	O
online	O
spam	B
filtering	I
.	O
Additionally	O

cite	O

high	O
cost	O
of	O
SVMs	O
as	O
reason	O
to	O
prefer	O
faster	O
-LRB-	O
if	O
less	O
statistically	O
robust	O
-RRB-	O
Bayesian	B
methods	I
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
offer	O
a	O

this	O

.	O

indeed	O
give	O

classification	O

on	O
online	O
spam	B
filtering	I
on	O
large	O

data	O
sets	O
.	O

we	O
show	O
that	O
nearly	O

performance	O
may	O
be	O
achieved	O
by	O
a	O
Relaxed	O
Online	O
SVM	O
-LRB-	O
ROSVM	O
-RRB-	O
at	O
greatly	O

computational	O
cost	O
.	O

on	O

Succession	O
in	O
standardization	B
:	O
grafting	O
XML	B
onto	O
SGML	B
Succession	O
in	O
standardization	B
is	O
often	O
a	O
problem	O
.	O
The	O

of	O

.	O

process	I

.	O

.	O
A	O
Type	B
I	I
succession	I
,	O
where	O

-LRB-	O

.	O

Traditionally	O
,	O
the	O
simulation	B
of	I
incompressible	I
fluid	I
flow	I

method	I
has	O

through	O
a	O

compressible	I
SPH	I
formulation	I
(	O
WCSPH	B
)	O
.	O

the	O

is	O

of	I
state	I
.	O
The	O

is	O
set	O
to	O
be	O
sufficiently	O
high	O
to	O
limit	O

.	O

places	O
a	O

on	O
the	O
maximum	O
permissible	O
time-step	O
size	O
through	O
the	O
Courant	O
–	O
Friedrichs	O
–	O
Lewy	O
(	O

)	O
constraint	O
.	O

to	O
noise	O
in	O

field	O

.	O

The	O

of	O

organic	B
semiconductor	I

.	O

charge	I

organic	B
materials	I

the	O
surroundings	O
and	O

around	O

is	O

as	O
a	O

Finite	B
Element	I
Tearing	I
and	I
Interconnecting	I
(	O
FETI	B
)	O
methods	O

to	O

solvers	B
for	I
large-scale	I
problems	I
in	I

.	O

problem	I

a	O

of	I
independent	I
sub-problems	I
,	O
which	O
are	O
then	O
coupled	O
in	O
appropriate	O
ways	O
.	O
NURBS	B
-	O
(	O
Non-Uniform	B
Rational	I
B-spline	I
)	O
based	O
isogeometric	B
analysis	I
(	O

)	O
applied	O
to	O
complex	B
geometries	I

domain	I
as	I
a	I

.	O

several	B

for	O
using	O

paper	O

new	O
IsogEometric	O

and	O

(	O

of	O

.	O

subdomains	O

)	O
.	O

Watermarking	B
techniques	I
for	O

delivery	I

sensing	I
images	I

observation	I

of	O

.	O

.	O
A	O

when	O

with	O
digital	B
image	I
distribution	I
is	O
copyright	B
protection	I
.	O

has	O

to	O

technology	O
.	O

.	O

Improving	O
computer	B
security	I
for	O
authentication	O
of	O
users	O
:	O
influence	O
of	O
proactive	B
password	I
restrictions	I
Entering	O
a	O
user	O
name-password	O
combination	O
is	O
a	O
widely	O
used	O
procedure	O
for	O
identification	O
and	O
authentication	O
in	O
computer	O
systems	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
a	O
notoriously	O
weak	O
method	O
,	O
in	O
that	O
the	O
passwords	O
adopted	O
by	O
many	O
users	O
are	O
easy	O
to	O
crack	O
.	O
In	O
an	O
attempt	O
to	O
,	O
improve	O
security	O
,	O
proactive	B
password	I
checking	I
may	O
be	O
used	O
,	O
in	O
which	O
passwords	O
must	O
meet	O
several	O
criteria	O
to	O
be	O
more	O
resistant	O
to	O
cracking	O
.	O
In	O
two	O
experiments	O
,	O
we	O
examined	O
the	O
influence	O
of	O
proactive	B
password	I
restrictions	I
on	O
the	O
time	O
that	O
it	O
took	O
to	O
generate	O
an	O
acceptable	O
password	O
and	O
to	O
use	O
it	O
subsequently	O
to	O
log	O
in	O
.	O
The	O
required	O
length	O
was	O
a	O
minimum	O
of	O
five	O
characters	O
in	O
experiment	O
I	O
and	O
eight	O
characters	O
in	O
experiment	O
2	O
.	O
In	O
both	O
experiments	O
,	O
one	O
condition	O
had	O
only	O
the	O
length	B
restriction	I
,	O
and	O
the	O
other	O
had	O
additional	O
restrictions	O
.	O
The	O
additional	O
restrictions	O
greatly	O
increased	O
the	O
time	O
it	O
took	O
to	O
generate	O
the	O
password	O
but	O
had	O
only	O
a	O
small	O
effect	O
on	O
the	O
time	O
it	O
took	O
to	O
use	O
it	O
subsequently	O
to	O
log	O
in	O
.	O
For	O
the	O
five-character	B
passwords	I
,	O
75	O
%	O
were	O
cracked	O
when	O
no	O
other	O
restrictions	O
were	O
imposed	O
,	O
and	O
this	O
was	O
reduced	O
to	O
33	O
%	O
with	O
the	O
additional	O
restrictions	O
.	O
For	O
the	O
eight-character	B
passwords	I
,	O
17	O
%	O
were	O
cracked	O
with	O
no	O
other	O
restrictions	O
,	O
and	O
12.5	O
%	O
with	O
restrictions	O
.	O
The	O
results	O
indicate	O
that	O
increasing	O
the	O
minimum	O
character	O
length	O
reduces	O
crackability	O
and	O
increases	O
security	O
,	O
regardless	O
of	O
whether	O
additional	O
restrictions	O
are	O
imposed	O

PV	B
cells	I
are	O
one	O
of	O

promising	O

for	O
conversion	B
of	I
incident	I
solar	I

into	I
electric	I
power	I
.	O
However	O
,	O
this	O
technology	O
is	O
still	O
far	O
from	O

with	O

energy	I

and	O

.	O

;	O

,	O

with	O

;	O

)	O

,	O

of	O
the	O

states	O
radioactively	O

ground	O

maximum	O

output	O
(	O
Hanna	O

,	O
2006	O
;	O

,	O

)	O
.	O

,	O
for	O
different	O

gap	O
Eg	O

and	O

by	O
areas	O
S1	O
,	O
S2	O
,	O
and	O

in	O

1.	O

per	O

load	O
.	O

The	O
test	O
cases	O
confirm	O
that	O
the	O
high-order	B
discretisation	I

convergence	I
properties	I
with	O

expansion	O

order	O

solution	B
and	O
true	B
surface	I
are	O

.	O
Errors	O
are	O

to	O

when	O

,	O

to	O

of	I
the	I
surface	I
elements	I
,	O

.	O

solutions	I
considered	O
as	O

of	O
further	O

in	O

mesh	B

solution	I

orders	I
.	O

of	O

geometry	B
parametrisation	I

the	O
geometric	B
error	I
.	O
The	O
analytic	B
test	I
cases	I
presented	O
here	O
use	O
a	O

curvilinear	I
mesh	I
;	O
for	O

,	O

are	O
typically	O
more	O
refined	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
capture	B
features	I
in	I
the	I
solution	I
and	O
so	O
will	O
better	O
capture	B
the	I
geometry	I
and	O
consequently	O
reduce	B
this	I
lower	I
bound	I
on	O
the	O
solution	B
error	O
.	O
If	O
the	O
solution	O
is	O
not	O
smooth	O
,	O
we	O
do	O
not	O
expect	O
to	O
see	O

.	O

that	O

,	O
but	O
the	O
true	B
surface	I
is	O
not	O

then	O

convergence	I
with	O

and	O
Pg	B
can	O
only	O

if	O
,	O
and	O
only	O
if	O
,	O
the	O
discontinuities	B
are	I
aligned	I
with	I
element	I
boundaries	I
.	O
However	O
,	O

lie	O
within	O
an	O
element	O
,	O

will	O
be	O

approximation	I
,	O
since	O

true	B
surface	I
cannot	O

captured	O
.	O
In	O
the	O

problem	I
,	O
we	O
consider	O
both	O
the	O
true	B
surface	I
and	O
solution	B
to	O
be	O
smooth	O
.	O

The	O
first-principles	B
calculations	I
are	O
performed	O
using	O
the	O
Cambridge	B
Serial	I
Total	I
Energy	I
Package	I
(	O
CASTEP	B
)	O
[	O
21	O
]	O
which	O
implements	O
the	O
plane-wave	B
pseudopotential	I
DFT	I
method	I
.	O
The	O
exchange	B
correlation	I
functional	I
is	O
approximated	O
using	O
the	O
generalized	B
gradient	I
approximation	I
(	O
PBE-GGA	B
)	O
[	O
22	O
]	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
electron	B
–	O
ion	B
interactions	O
are	O
described	O
by	O
Vanderbilt-type	B
ultrasoft	I
pseudopotentials	I
[	O
23	O
]	O
.	O
The	O
plane	B
wave	I
basis	O
set	O
is	O
truncated	O
at	O
a	O
cutoff	O
of	O
400eV	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
Brillouin-zone	B
sampling	I
was	O
performed	O
using	O
the	O
Monkhorst-Pack	B
scheme	I
with	O
a	O
k-point	B
spacing	I
in	O

Design	O
and	O
Implementation	O
of	O
a	O
Distributed	B
Content	I
Management	I
System	O
ABSTRACT	O
The	O
convergence	O
of	O
advances	O
in	O
storage	O
,	O
encoding	O
,	O
and	O
networking	O
technologies	O
has	O
brought	O
us	O
to	O
an	O
environment	O
where	O
huge	O
amounts	O
of	O
continuous	O
media	O
content	O
is	O
routinely	O
stored	O
and	O
exchanged	O
between	O
network	O
enabled	O
devices	O
.	O
Keeping	O
track	O
of	O
-LRB-	O
or	O
managing	O
-RRB-	O
such	O
content	O
remains	O
challenging	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
sheer	O
volume	O
of	O
data	O
.	O
Storing	O
``	O
live	O
''	O
continuous	O
media	O
-LRB-	O
such	O
as	O
TV	O
or	O
radio	O
content	O
-RRB-	O
adds	O
to	O
the	O
complexity	O
in	O
that	O
this	O
content	O
has	O
no	O
well	O
defined	O
start	O
or	O
end	O
and	O
is	O
therefore	O
cumbersome	O
to	O
deal	O
with	O
.	O
Networked	O
storage	O
allows	O
content	O
that	O
is	O
logically	O
viewed	O
as	O
part	O
of	O
the	O
same	O
collection	O
to	O
in	O
fact	O
be	O
distributed	O
across	O
a	O
network	O
,	O
making	O
the	O
task	O
of	O
content	O
management	O
all	O
but	O
impossible	O
to	O
deal	O
with	O
without	O
a	O
content	O
management	O
system	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
present	O
the	O
design	O
and	O
implementation	O
of	O
the	O
Spectrum	B
content	I
management	I
system	I
,	O
which	O
deals	O
with	O
rich	O
media	O
content	O
effectively	O
in	O
this	O
environment	O
.	O
Spectrum	O
has	O
a	O
modular	O
architecture	O
that	O
allows	O
its	O
application	O
to	O
both	O
stand-alone	O
and	O
various	O
networked	O
scenarios	O
.	O
A	O
unique	O
aspect	O
of	O
Spectrum	O
is	O
that	O
it	O
requires	O
one	O
-LRB-	O
or	O
more	O
-RRB-	O
retention	O
policies	O
to	O
apply	O
to	O
every	O
piece	O
of	O
content	O
that	O
is	O
stored	O
in	O
the	O
system	O
.	O
This	O
means	O
that	O
there	O
are	O
no	O
eviction	O
policies	O
.	O
Content	O
that	O
no	O
longer	O
has	O
a	O
retention	O
policy	O
applied	O
to	O
it	O
is	O
simply	O
removed	O
from	O
the	O
system	O
.	O
Different	O
retention	O
policies	O
can	O
easily	O
be	O
applied	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
content	O
thus	O
naturally	O
facilitating	O
sharing	O
without	O
duplication	O
.	O
This	O
approach	O
also	O
allows	O
Spectrum	O
to	O
easily	O
apply	O
time	O
based	O
policies	O
which	O
are	O
basic	O
building	O
blocks	O
required	O
to	O
deal	O
with	O
the	O
storage	O
of	O
live	O
continuous	O
media	O
,	O
to	O
content	O
.	O
We	O
not	O
only	O
describe	O
the	O
details	O
of	O
the	O
Spectrum	O
architecture	O
but	O
also	O
give	O
typical	O
use	O
cases	O
.	O

,	O

,	O

games	B

.	O

.	O

.	O

steps	I

.	O

.	O

.	O

.	O

Elimination	O
of	O
zero-order	O
diffraction	O
in	O
digital	B
holography	I
A	O
simple	O
method	O
to	O
suppress	O
the	O
zero-order	O
diffraction	O
in	O
the	O
reconstructed	B
image	I
of	O
digital	B
holography	I
is	O
presented	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
method	O
,	O
the	O
Laplacian	B
of	O
a	O
detected	B
hologram	I
is	O
used	O

itself	O
for	O

reconstruction	O
by	O
computing	O
the	O
discrete	B
Fresnel	I
integral	I
.	O
This	O
method	O
can	O
significantly	O
improve	O
the	O
image	B
quality	I
and	O
give	O
better	O
resolution	O
and	O
higher	O
accuracy	B
of	O
the	O
reconstructed	B
image	I
.	O
The	O
main	O
advantages	O
of	O
this	O
method	O
are	O
its	O
simplicity	O
in	O
experimental	O
requirements	O
and	O
convenience	O
in	O
data	B
processing	I

Defining	O
electronic	B
librarianship	I
:	O
a	O
content	B
analysis	I
of	O
job	B
advertisements	I
Advances	O
in	O
technology	O

within	O

.	O

,	O

.	O
Electronic	B
services	I

A	O
Study	O
of	O
Poisson	O
Query	B
Generation	I
Model	O
for	O
Information	O
Retrieval	O
ABSTRACT	O
Many	O
variants	O
of	O
language	B
models	I
have	O
been	O
proposed	O
for	O
information	O
retrieval	O
.	O
Most	O
existing	O
models	O
are	O
based	O
on	O
multinomial	B
distribution	I
and	O
would	O
score	O
documents	O
based	O
on	O
query	O
likelihood	O
computed	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
query	B
generation	I
probabilistic	O
model	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
and	O
study	O
a	O
new	O
family	O
of	O
query	B
generation	I
models	O
based	O
on	O
Poisson	B
distribution	I
.	O
We	O
show	O
that	O
while	O
in	O
their	O
simplest	O
forms	O

new	O
family	O
of	O
models	O

they	O

for	O
many	O

.	O

that	O

model	O

several	O

.	O
We	O
present	O
several	O

of	O
the	O
new	O
model	O

to	O
different	O
smoothing	O
methods	O

and	O
evaluate	O

on	O
four	O
representative	O
TREC	O
test	O
collections	O
.	O

show	O
that	O
while	O
their	O
basic	O
models	O
perform	O
comparably	O
,	O
the	O
Poisson	O
model	O
can	O
outperform	O
multinomial	O
model	O
with	O
per-term	O
smoothing	O
.	O
The	O
performance	O
can	O
be	O
further	O

with	O
two-stage	O
smoothing	O
.	O

Binocular	B
model	I
for	O
figure-ground	B
segmentation	I
in	O
translucent	O
and	O
occluding	B
images	I
A	O
Fourier-based	B
solution	I
to	O
the	O
problem	O
of	O
figure-ground	B
segmentation	I
in	O
short	O
baseline	O
binocular	O
image	B
pairs	O
is	O
presented	O
.	O
Each	O
image	B
is	O

as	O
an	O
additive	O
composite	O
of	O
two	O
component	B
images	I
that	O

shift	O

to	O
the	O
binocular	O

.	O

one	O

constituent	O

its	O
appropriate	O

spectrum	I
,	O

foreground	B
and	O
background	B

the	O
inverse	B
Fourier	I
transform	I
.	O
It	O
is	O
shown	O
that	O
the	O
foreground	B
and	O
background	B
shifts	O
can	O
be	O

and	O

Robust	O
Classification	O
of	O

Queries	O
Using	O
Web	O
Knowledge	O
ABSTRACT	O
We	O
propose	O
a	O
methodology	O
for	O
building	O
a	O
practical	O
robust	O
query	B
classification	I
system	O
that	O
can	O
identify	O
thousands	O
of	O
query	O

with	O
reasonable	O

,	O
while	O
dealing	O
in	O
realtime	O
with	O
the	O
query	O
volume	O
of	O
a	O
commercial	O
web	B
search	I
engine	O
.	O
We	O
use	O
a	O
blind	O
feedback	O
technique	O
:	O

a	O
query	O
,	O
we	O

.	O

the	O

of	O
search	B
advertising	I
,	O
we	O
primarily	O
focus	O
on	O
rare	O
queries	O
,	O
which	O
are	O
the	O
hardest	O
from	O
the	O
point	O
of	O
view	O
of	O
machine	B
learning	I
,	O
yet	O
in	O
aggregation	O
account	O
for	O
a	O
considerable	O
fraction	O
of	O
search	B
engine	I
traffic	O
.	O
Empirical	O
evaluation	O
confirms	O
that	O
our	O
methodology	O
yields	O
a	O
considerably	O
higher	O
classification	O
accuracy	O
than	O
previously	O
reported	O
.	O
We	O
believe	O
that	O
the	O
proposed	O
methodology	O
will	O
lead	O
to	O
better	O
matching	O
of	O
online	O
ads	O
to	O
rare	O

and	O
overall	O

a	O
better	O
user	O
experience	O
.	O

Self-Adaptive	B
Applications	O
on	O
the	O
Grid	O
Abstract	O
Grids	O
are	O
inherently	O
heterogeneous	O
and	O
dynamic	O
.	O
One	O
important	O
problem	O
in	O
grid	B
computing	I
is	O
resource	B
selection	I
,	O
that	O
is	O
,	O
finding	O
an	O
appropriate	O
resource	O
set	O
for	O
the	O
application	O
.	O
Another	O
problem	O
is	O
adaptation	O
to	O
the	O
changing	O
characteristics	O
of	O
the	O
grid	B
environment	I
.	O
Existing	O
solutions	O
to	O
these	O
two	O
problems	O
require	O
that	O
a	O
performance	O
model	O
for	O
an	O
application	O
is	O
known	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
constructing	O
such	O
models	O
is	O
a	O
complex	O
task	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
investigate	O
an	O
approach	O
that	O
does	O
not	O
require	O
performance	O
models	O
.	O
We	O
start	O
an	O
application	O
on	O
any	O
set	O
of	O
resources	O
.	O
During	O
the	O
application	O
run	O
,	O
we	O
periodically	O
collect	O
the	O
statistics	O
about	O
the	O
application	O
run	O
and	O
deduce	O
application	O
requirements	O
from	O
these	O
statistics	O
.	O
Then	O
,	O
we	O
adjust	O
the	O
resource	O
set	O
to	O
better	O
fit	O
the	O
application	O
needs	O
.	O
This	O
approach	O
allows	O
us	O
to	O
avoid	O
performance	O
bottlenecks	O
,	O
such	O
as	O
overloaded	O
WAN	O
links	O
or	O
very	O
slow	O
processors	O
,	O
and	O
therefore	O
can	O
yield	O
significant	O
performance	O
improvements	O
.	O
We	O
evaluate	O
our	O
approach	O
in	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
scenarios	O
typical	O
for	O
the	O
Grid	O
.	O

Live	O
Data	B
Center	I
Migration	I
across	O
WANs	B
:	O
A	O
Robust	O
Cooperative	O
Context	O
Aware	O
Approach	O
ABSTRACT	O
A	O
significant	O
concern	O
for	O
Internet-based	O
service	O
providers	O
is	O
the	O
continued	O
operation	O
and	O
availability	O
of	O
services	O
in	O
the	O
face	O
of	O
outages	O
,	O
whether	O
planned	O
or	O
unplanned	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
we	O
advocate	O
a	O
cooperative	O
,	O
context-aware	O
approach	O
to	O
data	B
center	I
migration	I
across	O
WANs	B
to	O
deal	O
with	O
outages	O
in	O
a	O
non-disruptive	O
manner	O
.	O
We	O
specifically	O
seek	O
to	O
achieve	O
high	O
availability	O
of	O
data	O
center	O
services	O
in	O

of	O

and	O

of	O
data	O

.	O
We	O
make	O

of	O
server	O

technologies	O
to	O
enable	O
the	O
replication	O
and	O

of	O
server	O

.	O

new	O

functions	O
to	O
enable	O
server	O
migration	O
and	O
replication	O
across	O
wide	O
area	O

-LRB-	O
e.g.	O
,	O
the	O
Internet	O
-RRB-	O
,	O
and	O
finally	O
show	O
the	O
utility	O
of	O
intelligent	O

storage	B

technology	O
to	O

of	O

point	O
objectives	O
.	O

Dynamic	B

ABSTRACT	O

''	O

ABSTRACT	O
How	O
to	O
provide	O
appropriate	O
context	O
information	O
is	O
a	O
challenging	O
problem	O
in	O
context-aware	B
computing	O
.	O
Most	O
existing	O
approaches	O
use	O
a	O
centralized	O
selection	O
mechanism	O
to	O
decide	O
which	O
context	O
information	O
is	O
appropriate	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
novel	O
approach	O
based	O
on	O
negotiation	B
with	O
rewards	O
to	O

such	O
problem	O
.	O
Distributed	O
context	B
providers	I
negotiate	B
with	O
each	O
other	O
to	O

who	O
can	O
provide	O
context	O
and	O
how	O
they	O

.	O
In	O

support	O
our	O
approach	O
,	O
we	O
have	O
designed	O
a	O
concrete	O
negotiation	B
model	O
with	O
rewards	O
.	O
We	O
also	O
evaluate	O
our	O
approach	O
and	O
show	O
that	O
it	O
indeed	O
can	O
choose	O
an	O
appropriate	O
context	B
provider	I
and	O
allocate	O
the	O
proceeds	O
fairly	O
.	O

Method	I
(	O

)	O

]	O

.	O

Modeling	O
self-consistent	O
multi-class	O
dynamic	O
traffic	O
flow	O
In	O
this	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
present	O
a	O
systematic	O
self-consistent	O
multiclass	O
multilane	B
traffic	I
model	I
derived	O
from	O
the	O
vehicular	B
Boltzmann	I
equation	I
and	O
the	O
traffic	B
dispersion	I
model	I
.	O
The	O
multilane	O
domain	O
is	O
considered	O
as	O
a	O
two-dimensional	O
space	O
and	O
the	O
interaction	O
among	O
vehicles	O
in	O
the	O
domain	O
is	O
described	O
by	O
a	O
dispersion	O
model	O
.	O
The	O
reason	O
we	O
consider	O
a	O
multilane	O
domain	O
as	O
a	O
two-dimensional	O
space	O
is	O
that	O
the	O
driving	O
behavior	O
of	O
road	B
users	I
may	O
not	O
be	O
restricted	O
by	O
lanes	O
,	O
especially	O
motorcyclists	O
.	O
The	O
dispersion	O
model	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
a	O
nonlinear	B
Poisson	I
equation	I
,	O
is	O
derived	O
from	O
the	O
car-following	O
theory	O
and	O
the	O
equilibrium	O
assumption	O
.	O
Under	O
the	O
concept	O
that	O
all	O
kinds	O
of	O
users	O
share	O
the	O
finite	O
section	O
,	O
the	O
density	O
is	O
distributed	O
on	O
a	O
road	O
by	O
the	O
dispersion	O
model	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
the	O
dynamic	B
evolution	I
of	O
the	O
traffic	O
flow	O
is	O
determined	O
by	O
the	O
systematic	O
gas-kinetic	O
model	O
derived	O
from	O
the	O
Boltzmann	O
equation	O
.	O
Multiplying	O
Boltzmann	O
equation	O
by	O
the	O
zeroth	O
,	O
first	O
-	O
and	O
second-order	O
moment	O
functions	O
,	O
integrating	O
both	O
side	O
of	O
the	O
equation	O
and	O
using	O
chain	O
rules	O
,	O
we	O
can	O
derive	O
continuity	O
,	O
motion	O
and	O
variance	B
equation	I
,	O
respectively	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
the	O
second-order	O
moment	O
function	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
the	O
square	O
of	O
the	O
individual	O
velocity	O
,	O
is	O
employed	O
by	O
previous	O
researches	O
does	O
not	O
have	O
physical	O
meaning	O
in	O
traffic	O
flow	O

Combining	O

scale-space	B
techniques	I
for	O
edge	B
detection	I
to	O

a	O

noise	I

algorithm	I
New	O
methods	O
for	O
detecting	O
edges	O
in	O
an	O
image	O
using	O
spatial	O
and	O
scale-space	O
domains	O
are	O
proposed	O
.	O
A	B
priori	I
knowledge	I
about	O
geometrical	B
characteristics	I
of	O
edges	O
is	O
used	O
to	O
assign	O
a	O
probability	B
factor	I
to	O
the	O

of	O
any	O
pixel	O
being	O
on	O
an	O
edge	O
.	O
An	O
improved	O
double	B
thresholding	I
technique	I
is	O
introduced	O
for	O
spatial	B
domain	I
filtering	I
.	O

that	O

belong	O
to	O
a	O

are	O
assigned	O
based	O
on	O
pixel	B
similarity	I
across	O
gradient	B
amplitudes	I
,	O
gradient	B
phases	I
and	O
edge	B
connectivity	I
.	O
The	O
scale-space	O
approach	O
uses	O
dynamic	B
range	I
compression	I
to	O
allow	O
wavelet	B
correlation	I
over	O
a	O
wider	O
range	O
of	O
scales	O
.	O
A	O
probabilistic	B
formulation	I
is	O
used	O
to	O

the	O
results	O
obtained	O
from	O
filtering	O
in	O
each	O
domain	O
to	O
provide	O
a	O
final	B
edge	I
probability	I
image	I
which	O
has	O
the	O
advantages	O
of	O
both	O
spatial	O
and	O
scale-space	O
domain	O
methods	O
.	O

this	O
edge	O
probability	O
image	O
with	O
the	O
same	O
wavelet	O
as	O
the	O
original	O
image	O

of	O

filters	I
that	O
can	O

of	O
the	O

Evicting	O

A	O

,	O

module	I
,	O
a	O

for	I

module	I

module	I

.	O

.	O

Multilayered	O
image	B
representation	I
:	O
application	O
to	O
image	B
compression	I
The	O
main	O
contribution	O
of	O
this	O
work	O
is	O
a	O
new	O
paradigm	O
for	O
image	B
representation	I
and	O
image	B
compression	I
.	O
We	O
describe	O
a	O
new	O
multilayered	B
representation	I
technique	O
for	O
images	O
.	O
An	O
image	O
is	O
parsed	O
into	O
a	O
superposition	O
of	O
coherent	O
layers	O
:	O
piecewise	B
smooth	I
regions	I
layer	I
,	O
textures	B
layer	I
,	O
etc.	O
.	O
The	O
multilayered	B
decomposition	I
algorithm	I
consists	O
in	O
a	O
cascade	O
of	O
compressions	O
applied	O
successively	O
to	O
the	O
image	O
itself	O
and	O
to	O
the	O
residuals	O
that	O
resulted	O
from	O
the	O
previous	O
compressions	O
.	O
During	O
each	O
iteration	O
of	O
the	O
algorithm	O
,	O
we	O
code	O
the	O
residual	B
part	I
in	O
a	O
lossy	O
way	O
:	O
we	O
only	O
retain	O
the	O
most	O
significant	O
structures	O
of	O
the	O
residual	B
part	I
,	O
which	O
results	O
in	O
a	O
sparse	B
representation	I
.	O
Each	O
layer	O
is	O
encoded	O
independently	O
with	O
a	O
different	O
transform	O
,	O
or	O
basis	O
,	O
at	O
a	O
different	O
bitrate	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
combination	O
of	O
the	O
compressed	O
layers	O
can	O
always	O
be	O
reconstructed	O
in	O
a	O
meaningful	O
way	O
.	O
The	O
strength	O
of	O
the	O
multilayer	O
approach	O
comes	O
from	O
the	O
fact	O
that	O
different	O
sets	O
of	O
basis	B
functions	I
complement	O
each	O
others	O
:	O
some	O
of	O
the	O
basis	B
functions	I
will	O
give	O
reasonable	O
account	O
of	O
the	O
large	O
trend	O
of	O
the	O
data	O
,	O
while	O
others	O
will	O
catch	O
the	O
local	O
transients	O
,	O
or	O
the	O
oscillatory	O
patterns	O
.	O
This	O
multilayered	B
representation	I
has	O
a	O
lot	O
of	O
beautiful	O
applications	O
in	O
image	O
understanding	O
,	O
and	O
image	O
and	O
video	O
coding	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
implemented	O
the	O
algorithm	O
and	O
we	O
have	O

Mediators	B
in	O
Position	B
Auctions	I
ABSTRACT	O
A	O
mediator	B
is	O
a	O

entity	O
,	O
which	O
can	O
play	O
on	O
behalf	O
of	O
agents	B
in	O
a	O

.	O

can	O

of	O

services	O
,	O
and	O

to	O

in	O

.	O

paper	O
we	O

of	O

for	O

of	O
position	B

.	O

position	B

position	B

and	O
their	O

VCG	O
position	O
auctions	O
.	O

to	O

ex	B

A	O
formal	B
model	I
of	O
computing	B
with	I
words	I
Classical	O
automata	O
are	O
formal	B
models	I
of	O

with	O
values	O
.	O

automata	I
are	O

automata	O
where	O
the	O

about	O
the	O

for	O

of	O

.	O

difficult	O

in	O

because	O
of	O
high	O

is	O

.	O

have	O

.	O

the	O
multiuser	O
007	O

indicate	O
that	O
for	O

40	O
to	O
80	O

to	O

A	O
routing	O
policy	O
is	O
the	O
method	O
used	O
to	O
select	O
a	O
specific	O
output	O
channel	O
for	O
a	O
message	O
from	O
among	O
a	O
number	O
of	O
acceptable	O
output	O
channels	O
.	O
An	O
optimal	B
routing	I
policy	I
is	O
a	O
policy	O
that	O
maximizes	O
the	O
probability	O
of	O
a	O
message	O
reaching	O

destination	O
without	O
delays	O
.	O
Optimal	B

have	O
been	O

.	O

no	O

.	O

.	O

Grid	B
and	I

support	O

models	I
.	O
In	O

a	O

system	I
.	O

a	O

server	I
,	O

.	O

Horizontal	O
waypoint	O
guidance	O

using	O

control	O
A	O
horizontal	B
waypoint	I

algorithm	I
is	O

by	O

guidance	I
to	O
waypoint	B
line	I
segments	I
in	O

.	O
The	O

guidance	I
is	O
designed	O
using	O

LQR	B
-LRB-	O
linear	B
quadratic	I
regulator	I
-RRB-	O
.	O

,	O
the	O
optimal	B
waypoint	I
changing	I
points	I
are	O

by	O

required	O
for	O
changing	O

waypoint	B

.	O

a	O

for	O
the	O
stability	B
bound	I
of	O
ground	B
speed	I

.	O

line	I
segments	I

In	O
search	O
of	O

operations	O
research/management	O
science	O
We	O

strategic	B
OR/MS	I
as	O
``	O

work	O
that	O

to	O

.	O
''	O
We	O
found	O

Trading	B
Networks	I
with	O
Price-Setting	O
Agents	O
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
a	O
wide	O
range	O
of	O
markets	B
,	O
individual	O
buyers	O
and	O
sellers	O
often	O
trade	O
through	O
intermediaries	O
,	O
who	O
determine	O
prices	O
via	O
strategic	O
considerations	O
.	O
Typically	O
,	O
not	O
all	O
buyers	O
and	O
sellers	O
have	O
access	O
to	O
the	O
same	O
intermediaries	O
,	O
and	O
they	O
trade	O
at	O
correspondingly	O
different	O
prices	O
that	O
reflect	O
their	O
relative	O
amounts	O
of	O
power	O
in	O
the	O
market	B
.	O
We	O
model	O
this	O
phenomenon	O
using	O
a	O
game	O
in	O
which	O
buyers	O
,	O
sellers	O
,	O
and	O
traders	O
engage	O
in	O
trade	O
on	O
a	O
graph	O
that	O
represents	O
the	O
access	O
each	O
buyer	O
and	O
seller	O
has	O
to	O
the	O
traders	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
model	O
,	O
traders	O
set	O
prices	O
strategically	O
,	O
and	O
then	O
buyers	O
and	O
sellers	O
react	O
to	O
the	O
prices	O
they	O
are	O
offered	O
.	O
We	O
show	O
that	O
the	O
resulting	O
game	O
always	O
has	O
a	O
subgame	O
perfect	O
Nash	O
equilibrium	O
,	O
and	O
that	O
all	O
equilibria	O
lead	O
to	O
an	O
efficient	O
-LRB-	O
i.e.	O
socially	O
optimal	O
-RRB-	O
allocation	O
of	O
goods	O
.	O
We	O
extend	O
these	O
results	O
to	O
a	O
more	O
general	O
type	O
of	O
matching	O
market	B
,	O
such	O
as	O
one	O
finds	O
in	O
the	O
matching	O
of	O
job	O
applicants	O
and	O
employers	O
.	O
Finally	O
,	O
we	O
consider	O
how	O
the	O
profits	O
obtained	O
by	O
the	O
traders	O
depend	O
on	O
the	O
underlying	O
graph	O
--	O
roughly	O
,	O

trader	O
can	O
command	O

positive	O
profit	O
if	O
and	O
only	O
if	O
it	O
has	O
an	O
``	O
essential	O
''	O
connection	O
in	O
the	O
network	O
structure	O

.	O

from	O

of	O

Distributed	O

of	O

Times	I
Schedules	B
ABSTRACT	O
We	O

of	O

.	O

none	O

.	O

activities	O

.	O

agent	B

1	O
-RRB-	O
a	O
``	O
flexible	B

''	O

of	O
the	O
agent	O
's	O
schedule	B
-LRB-	O

a	O

Network	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
-LRB-	O
2	O
-RRB-	O

.	O

A	O
Reinforcement	B
Learning	I
based	O
Distributed	B
Search	I
Algorithm	I
For	O
Hierarchical	O
Peer-to-Peer	O
Information	O
Retrieval	O
Systems	O
ABSTRACT	O
The	O
dominant	O
existing	O
routing	O
strategies	O
employed	O
in	O
peerto-peer	O
-LRB-	O
P2P	O
-RRB-	O
based	O
information	O
retrieval	O
-LRB-	O
IR	O
-RRB-	O
systems	O
are	O
similarity-based	O
approaches	O
.	O
In	O
these	O
approaches	O
,	O
agents	O
depend	O
on	O
the	O
content	O
similarity	O
between	O
incoming	O
queries	B
and	O
their	O
direct	O
neighboring	O
agents	O
to	O
direct	O
the	O
distributed	O
search	O
sessions	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
such	O
a	O

is	O
myopic	O

that	O
the	O
neighboring	O
agents	O
may	O
not	O
be	O
connected	O
to	O
more	O
relevant	O
agents	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
an	O
online	O
reinforcement-learning	O
based	O
approach	O
is	O

to	O
take	O
advantage	O
of	O

dynamic	O
run-time	O

of	O

systems	O
as	O
represented	O
by	O
information	O
about	O
past	O
search	O
sessions	O
.	O
Specifically	O
,	O
agents	O
maintain	O
estimates	O
on	O
the	O
downstream	O
agents	O

abilities	O
to	O
provide	O
relevant	O
documents	O
for	O
incoming	O
queries	B
.	O

are	O
updated	O
gradually	O
by	O
learning	O
from	O
the	O
feedback	O
information	O
returned	O
from	O
previous	O
search	O
sessions	O
.	O
Based	O
on	O
this	O
information	O
,	O
the	O
agents	O
derive	O
corresponding	O
routing	B
policies	I
.	O
Thereafter	O
,	O
these	O
agents	O
route	O
the	O
queries	B
based	O
on	O
the	O
learned	O
policies	O
and	O
update	O
the	O
estimates	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
new	O
routing	B
policies	I
.	O
Experimental	O
results	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
the	O
learning	B
algorithm	I

considerably	O
the	O
routing	O
performance	O

two	O
test	O
collection	O

that	O
have	O
been	O
used	O
in	O
a	O

of	O
distributed	O
IR	O
studies	O
.	O

ABSTRACT	O

.	O

Managing	O
system	O
risk	O

are	O
increasingly	O
required	O
to	O

that	O

are	O

standards	I
.	O

of	O

systems	O
and	O

risk	B

Measuring	O
keyboard	O

In	O
the	O
past	O
,	O
the	O
proposed	O
method	O
has	O
been	O
to	O
check	B
the	O

.	O

model	B
change	I

for	O

checking	B
.	O

PC	O

of	O
a	O
sound	B

to	O

timing	I
function	I
.	O

of	O

keyboard	B

time	I

.	O

Real-Time	O
Agent	O

ABSTRACT	O

The	O
Role	O
of	O
Compatibility	O
in	O
the	O
Diffusion	O
of	O
Technologies	O
Through	O
Social	O
Networks	O
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
many	O
settings	O
,	O
competing	O
technologies	O
--	O
for	O
example	O
,	O
operating	O
systems	O
,	O
instant	O
messenger	O
systems	O
,	O
or	O
document	O
formats	O
--	O
can	O
be	O
seen	O
adopting	O
a	O
limited	O
amount	O
of	O
compatibility	O
with	O
one	O
another	O
;	O
in	O
other	O
words	O

difficulty	O

multiple	O

is	O
balanced	O
somewhere	O
between	O

of	O

and	O

.	O

why	O
this	O

occurs	O
,	O
many	O

--	O
based	O
on	O
legal	O
,	O

,	O

to	O

models	O
.	O

we	O

that	O

of	O
limited	B
compatibility	I
can	O

a	O

simple	O
model	O
of	O

in	O
social	O
networks	O
,	O

a	O

for	O
this	O

in	O
purely	O

terms	O
.	O
Our	O

builds	O
on	O
work	O
on	O
the	O
diffusion	B
of	I
innovations	I
in	O
the	O
economics	O
literature	O
,	O
which	O
seeks	O
to	O
model	O
how	O
a	O
new	O
technology	O

might	O
spread	O
through	O
a	O
social	O
network	O
of	O
individuals	O
who	O
are	O
currently	O
users	O
of	O
technology	O
B	O
.	O
We	O
consider	O
several	O
ways	O
of	O

the	O

of	O
A	O
and	O
B	O
,	O

on	O
a	O
model	O

users	O
can	O

to	O
adopt	O
A	O
,	O
adopt	O
B	O
,	O

--	O

extra	O

--	O
adopt	O
both	O
A	O
and	O
B	O
.	O
We	O
characterize	B
how	O
the	O
ability	O
of	O
A	O
to	O
spread	O
depends	O
on	O
both	O
its	O
quality	O
relative	O
to	O
B	O
,	O
and	O
also	O
this	O
additional	O
cost	O
of	O
adopting	O
both	O
,	O
and	O
find	O
some	O
surprising	O
non-monotonicity	O
properties	O
in	O
the	O
dependence	O
on	O
these	O
parameters	O
:	O
in	O
some	O
cases	O
,	O
for	O
one	O
technology	O
to	O
survive	O

introduction	O
of	O
another	O

technologies	O

a	O

.	O

that	O
a	O
simple	O

Efficient	O
Bayesian	O

User	O
Modeling	B
for	O
Recommendation	B
Systems	I
ABSTRACT	O
A	O
content-based	O
personalized	B
recommendation	B
system	I

.	O

of	O
users	O
can	O

for	O
a	O
new	O
user	O

a	O
user	O

of	O
a	O

hierarchical	I
model	I
.	O
Learning	O

model	B
parameters	B
to	O
optimize	O
the	O
joint	O
data	O
likelihood	O
from	O
millions	O
of	O
users	O
is	O
very	O

expensive	O
.	O
The	O
commonly	O
used	O
EM	B
algorithm	I
converges	O
very	O
slowly	O
due	O
to	O
the	O

of	O
the	O

in	O

.	O
This	O
paper	O
proposes	O
a	O
new	O
fast	O
learning	B
technique	I
to	O
learn	O
a	O
large	O

of	O
individual	O
user	O
profiles	O
.	O

efficacy	O
and	O

of	O
the	O
proposed	O
algorithm	O
are	O

by	O
theory	O
and	O

and	O

.	O

Although	O

models	I
have	O
been	O

in	O
all	O

,	O

their	O

extended	I
dynamical	I
systems	I
.	O

,	O

to	O

.	O
The	O
Liley	B
model	I
[	O
15	O
]	O
considered	O

,	O

of	O

(	O

)	O

.	O

model	O

of	O

(	O

)	O

only	O

,	O
and	O
the	O

system	O
has	O

numerical	B
bifurcation	I
analysis	I
(	O
see	O
[	O
16	O
]	O
and	O
references	O
therein	O
)	O
.	O
In	O

to	O

,	O

and	O

objects	O

model	I
,	O

for	O

,	O

.	O

efficient	B
,	I

for	I

with	I

,	I

matrices	I
.	O
In	O

,	O

ABSTRACT	O
Many	O

required	O
to	O

documents	B
for	O

may	O

to	O

.	O

may	O

needed	O
for	O

.	O

,	O
to	O

.	O

.	O

machine	O
.	O

for	O
pedestrian	B
dynamics	I
We	O
present	O
simulations	O
of	O
evacuation	O
processes	O
using	O
a	O
recently	O
introduced	O
cellular	O
automaton	O
model	O
for	O
pedestrian	B
dynamics	I
.	O
This	O
model	O
applies	O
a	O
bionics	O
approach	O
to	O
describe	O
the	O
interaction	O
between	O
the	O
pedestrians	O
using	O
ideas	O
from	O
chemotaxis	B
.	O
Here	O
we	O
study	O
a	O
rather	O
simple	O
situation	O
,	O
namely	O
the	O
evacuation	O
from	O
a	O
large	O
room	O
with	O
one	O
or	O
two	O
doors	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
shown	O
that	O
the	O
variation	O
of	O
the	O
model	O
parameters	O
allows	O
to	O
describe	O
different	O
types	O
of	O
behaviour	O
,	O
from	O
regular	O
to	O
panic	O
.	O
We	O
find	O
a	O
non-monotonic	O
dependence	O
of	O
the	O
evacuation	O
times	O
on	O
the	O
coupling	B
constants	I
.	O
These	O
times	O
depend	O
on	O
the	O
strength	O
of	O
the	O
herding	B
behaviour	I
,	O
with	O
minimal	O
evacuation	O
times	O
for	O
some	O
intermediate	O
values	O
of	O
the	O
couplings	O
,	O
i.e.	O
,	O
a	O
proper	O
combination	O
of	O
herding	O
and	O
use	O
of	O
knowledge	O
about	O
the	O
shortest	O
way	O
to	O
the	O
exit	O

.	O

Worst-Case	O
Optimal	O

ABSTRACT	O
Many	O
important	O
problems	O
in	O
multiagent	O
systems	O
involve	O
the	O
allocation	O
of	O
multiple	O
resources	O
among	O
the	O
agents	O
.	O
For	O
resource	O
allocation	O
problems	O
,	O
the	O
well-known	O
VCG	O
mechanism	B
satisfies	O
a	O
list	O
of	O
desired	O
properties	O
,	O
including	O
efficiency	O
,	O
strategy-proofness	O
,	O
individual	O
rationality	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
non-deficit	O
property	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
VCG	O
is	O
generally	O
not	O
budget-balanced	O
.	O
Under	O
VCG	O
,	O
agents	O
pay	O
the	O
VCG	O
payments	O
,	O
which	O
reduces	O
social	O
welfare	O
.	O
To	O
offset	O
the	O
loss	O
of	O
social	O
welfare	O
due	O
to	O
the	O
VCG	O
payments	O
,	O
VCG	O
redistribution	O
mechanisms	B
were	O
introduced	O
.	O
These	O
mechanisms	B
aim	O
to	O
redistribute	O
as	O
much	O
VCG	O
payments	O
back	O
to	O
the	O
agents	O
as	O
possible	O
,	O
while	O
maintaining	O
the	O
aforementioned	O
desired	O
properties	O
of	O
the	O
VCG	O
mechanism	B
.	O
We	O
continue	O
the	O
search	O
for	O
worst-case	O
optimal	O
VCG	O
redistribution	O
mechanisms	B
--	O
mechanisms	B
that	O
maximize	O
the	O
fraction	O
of	O
total	O
VCG	O
payment	B
redistributed	I
in	O
the	O
worst	O
case	O
.	O
Previously	O
,	O
a	O
worst-case	O
optimal	O
VCG	O
redistribution	O
mechanism	B
-LRB-	O
denoted	O
by	O
WCO	O
-RRB-	O
was	O
characterized	O
for	O
multi-unit	O
auctions	O
with	O
nonincreasing	O
marginal	O
values	O
-LSB-	O
7	O
-RSB-	O
.	O
Later	O
,	O
WCO	O
was	O
generalized	O
to	O
settings	O
involving	O
heterogeneous	O
items	O
-LSB-	O
4	O
-RSB-	O
,	O
resulting	O
in	O
the	O
HETERO	O
mechanism	B
.	O
-LSB-	O
4	O
-RSB-	O
conjectured	O
that	O
HETERO	O
is	O
feasible	O
and	O
worst-case	O
optimal	O
for	O
heterogeneous-item	O
auctions	O
with	O
unit	O
demand	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
a	O
more	O
natural	O
way	O
to	O
generalize	O
the	O
WCO	O
mechanism	B
.	O
We	O
prove	O
that	O
our	O
generalized	O
mechanism	B
,	O
though	O
represented	O
differently	O
,	O
actually	O
coincides	O
with	O
HETERO	O
.	O
Based	O
on	O
this	O
new	O
representation	O
of	O
HETERO	O
,	O
we	O
prove	O
that	O
HETERO	O
is	O
indeed	O
feasible	O
and	O
worst-case	O
optimal	O
in	O
heterogeneous-item	O
auctions	O
with	O
unit	O
demand	O
.	O
Finally	O
,	O
we	O
conjecture	O
that	O
HETERO	O
remains	O
feasible	O
and	O
worst-case	O
optimal	O
in	O
the	O
even	O
more	O
general	O
setting	O
of	O
combinatorial	O
auctions	O
with	O
gross	O
substitutes	O
.	O

Why	O
your	O
Web	B
strategy	I
is	O
,	O
err	O
,	O
wrong	O
An	O

views	O
from	O
the	O
author	O
,	O
who	O

that	O

,	O
err	O
,	O
wrong	O
.	O

,	O

ObjectiveElectrically	O
evoked	O
auditory	O
steady-state	O
responses	O
(	O
EASSRs	O
)	O
are	O
neural	O
potentials	O
measured	O
in	O
the	O
electroencephalogram	O
(	O
EEG	O
)	O
in	O
response	O
to	O
periodic	O
pulse	O
trains	O
presented	O
,	O
for	O
example	O
,	O
through	O
a	O
cochlear	O
implant	O
(	O
CI	O
)	O
.	O
EASSRs	O
could	O
potentially	O
be	O
used	O
for	O
objective	O
CI	O
fitting	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
EEG	O
signals	O
are	O
contaminated	O
with	O
electrical	O
CI	O
artifacts	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
characterized	O
the	O
CI	O
artifacts	O
for	O
monopolar	O
mode	O
stimulation	O
and	O
evaluated	O
at	O
which	O
pulse	O
rate	O
,	O
linear	O
interpolation	O
over	O
the	O
signal	O
part	O
contaminated	O
with	O
CI	O
artifact	O
is	O
successful.MethodsCI	O
artifacts	O
were	O
characterized	O
by	O
means	O
of	O
their	O
amplitude	O
growth	O
functions	O
and	O
duration.ResultsCI	O
artifact	O
durations	O
were	O
between	O
0.7	O
and	O
1.7ms	O
,	O
at	O
contralateral	O
recording	O
electrodes	O
.	O
At	O
ipsilateral	O
recording	O
electrodes	O
,	O
CI	O
artifact	O
durations	O
are	O
range	O
from	O
0.7	O
to	O
larger	O
than	O
2ms.ConclusionAt	O
contralateral	O
recording	O
electrodes	O
,	O
the	O
artifact	O
was	O
shorter	O
than	O
the	O
interpulse	O
interval	O
across	O
subjects	O
for	O
500pps	O
,	O
which	O
was	O
not	O
always	O
the	O
case	O
for	O
900pps.SignificanceCI	O
artifact-free	O
EASSRs	O
are	O
crucial	O
for	O
reliable	O
CI	O
fitting	O
and	O
neuroscience	O
research	O
.	O
The	O
CI	O
artifact	O
has	O
been	O
characterized	O
and	O
linear	O
interpolation	O
allows	O
to	O
remove	O
it	O
at	O
contralateral	O
recording	O
electrodes	O
for	O
stimulation	O
at	O
500pps	O
.	O

The	B
threshold	I
values	I
for	I
removing	I
large	I
caters	I
were	I
determined	I
by	O
examining	O
the	O
craters	O
within	O
the	O
study	O
area	O

studies	O
(	O

and	O

)	O
,	O
and	O

error	O
.	O

values	O
are	O

,	O

is	O

.	O

some	O
minimum	O

of	O
Mars	O
.	O

“	O

for	I

1.1	O
times	O
.	O

ABSTRACT	O
Low-cost	O

for	O

relevance	O
judgments	O

to	O
evaluate	B
new	O

.	O

:	O

of	O

of	O

.	O

then	O
present	O
a	O
method	O
for	O
augmenting	O
a	O
set	O
of	O
relevance	O
judgments	O
with	O
relevance	O
estimates	O
that	O
require	O
no	O
additional	O
assessor	O
effort	O
.	O
Using	O
this	O
method	O

guarantees	O

as	O

as	O

from	O

systems	O

can	O

evaluate	B
a	O

systems	O
.	O

sets	O
of	O
judgments	O
can	O
be	O
useful	O
for	O
evaluation	B
of	O
new	O
systems	O
.	O

of	O

order	O
based	O
QSARs	O

order	I
theory	I
-LRB-	O
POT	O
-RRB-	O

descriptors	I

order	I
-RRB-	O
,	O
or	O

on	O
their	O
end	B
points	I
,	O

,	O
solubility	B
-LRB-	O
experimental	O
order	O
-RRB-	O
.	O

order	I

problem	I

Typical	O

2D	I

Water	I
Equations	I
(	I

)	I
,	O

.	O

Using	O
latent	B
semantic	I
analysis	I
to	O

latent	B
semantic	I
analysis	I
-LRB-	O
LSA	O
-RRB-	O
.	O

-LRB-	O

-RRB-	O

prior	O
text	O

world	B

human	B

and	O
LSA	O
.	O

Self-calibration	O
from	O

Separation	O
and	O
tracking	O
of	O
multiple	O
broadband	O
sources	O
with	O
one	O
electromagnetic	B
vector	I
sensor	I
A	O
structure	O
for	O
adaptively	O
separating	O
,	O
enhancing	O
and	O
tracking	O
uncorrelated	B
sources	I
with	O
an	O
electromagnetic	B
vector	I
sensor	I
-LRB-	O
EMVS	O
-RRB-	O
is	O
presented	O
.	O
The	O
structure	O
consists	O
of	O
a	O
set	O
of	O
parallel	B
spatial	I
processors	I
,	O
one	O
for	O
each	O
individual	O
source	O
.	O
Two	O
stages	O
of	O
processing	O
are	O
involved	O
in	O
each	O
spatial	O
processor	O
.	O
The	O
first	O
preprocessing	B
stage	I
rejects	O
all	O
other	O
sources	O
except	O
the	O
one	O
of	O
interest	O
,	O
while	O
the	O
second	O
stage	O
is	O
an	O
adaptive	O
one	O
for	O
maximizing	O
the	O
signal-to-noise	B
ratio	I
-LRB-	O
SNR	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
tracking	O
the	O
desired	O
source	O
.	O
The	O
preprocessings	O
are	O
designed	O
using	O
the	O
latest	O
source	O
parameter	O
estimates	O
obtained	O
from	O
the	O
source	O
trackers	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
redesign	O
is	O
activated	O
periodically	O
or	O
whenever	O
any	O
source	O
has	O
been	O
detected	O
by	O
the	O
source	O
trackers	O
to	O
have	O
made	O
significant	O
movement	O
.	O
Compared	O
with	O
conventional	O
adaptive	O
beamforming	O
,	O
the	O
algorithm	O
has	O
the	O
advantage	O
that	O
no	O
a	O
priori	O
information	O
on	O
any	O
desired	O
signal	O
location	O
is	O
needed	O
,	O
the	O
sources	O
are	O
separated	O
at	O
maximum	B
SNR	I
,	O
and	O
their	O
locations	O
are	O
available	O
.	O
The	O
structure	O
is	O
also	O
well	O
suited	O
for	O
parallel	B
implementation	I
.	O
Numerical	O
examples	O
are	O
included	O
to	O
illustrate	O
the	O
capability	O
and	O
performance	O
of	O
the	O
algorithm	O

Analyzing	O
the	O
potential	O
of	O
a	O
firm	O
:	O
an	O
operations	B
research	I
approach	O
An	O
approach	O
to	O
analyzing	O
the	O
potential	O
of	O
a	O
firm	O
,	O
which	O
is	O
understood	O
as	O
the	O
firm	O
's	O
ability	O
to	O
provide	O
goods	O
or	B
-LRB-	O
and	O
-RRB-	O
services	O
to	O
be	O
supplied	O
to	O
a	O
marketplace	O
under	O
restrictions	O
imposed	O
by	O
a	O
business	O
environment	O
in	O
which	O
the	O
firm	O
functions	O
,	O
is	O
proposed	O
.	O
The	O
approach	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
using	O
linear	B
inequalities	I
and	O
,	O
generally	O
,	O
mixed	O
variables	O
in	O
modelling	O
this	O
ability	O
for	O
a	O
broad	O
spectrum	O
of	O
industrial	O
,	O
transportation	O
,	O
agricultural	O
,	O
and	O
other	O
types	O
of	O
firms	O
and	O
allows	O
one	O
to	O
formulate	O
problems	O

ABSTRACT	O

need	I

.	O

.	O

.	O

ABSTRACT	O

no	O
a	O
priori	O

distributed	O
over	O
the	O
network	O
.	O
We	O
show	O
that	O
the	O
complexity	O
of	O
this	O
problem	O
remains	O
NPhard	O
.	O
Moreover	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
not	O
approximable	O
within	O
some	O
factor	O
.	O
We	O
develop	O
an	O
algorithm	B
based	O
on	O
the	O
contract-net	O
protocol	O
.	O
Our	O
algorithm	B
is	O
completely	O
distributed	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
assumes	O
that	O
agents	B
have	O
only	O
local	O
knowledge	O
about	O
tasks	O
and	O
resources	B
.	O
We	O
conduct	O
a	O
set	O
of	O
experiments	O
to	O
evaluate	O
the	O
performance	O
and	O
scalability	O
of	O
the	O
proposed	O
algorithm	B
in	O
terms	O
of	O
solution	O
quality	O
and	O
computation	O
time	O
.	O
Three	O
different	O
types	O
of	O
networks	O
,	O
namely	O
small-world	O
,	O
random	O
and	O
scale-free	O
networks	O
,	O
are	O
used	O
to	O
represent	O
various	O
social	B
relationships	I
among	O
agents	B
in	O
realistic	O
applications	O
.	O

results	O

that	O
our	O
algorithm	B
works	O
well	O
and	O
that	O
it	O
scales	O
well	O
to	O
large-scale	O
applications	O
.	O

limit	I

.	O

for	O
a	O

design	O
.	O

study	O

mask	I

periodic	O

to	O

.	O

near-field	B

of	O
a	O

's	O
function	O

for	O

-RRB-	O

DPD	B
was	O
first	O
proposed	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
recover	O
the	O
properties	O
of	O
isotropy	B
(	O
and	O
Galilean	B
invariance	I
)	O
that	O
were	O
broken	O
in	O
the	O
so-called	O
lattice-gas	B
automata	I
method	O
[	O
5	O
]	O
.	O
In	O
DPD	B
,	O
each	O
body	O
is	O
regarded	O
as	O
a	O
coarse-grained	B
particle	I
.	O
These	O
particles	B
interact	O
in	O
a	O
soft	O
(	O
and	O
short-ranged	O
)	O
potential	O
,	O
allowing	O
larger	O
integration	O
timesteps	O
than	O
would	O
be	O
possible	O
in	O
MD	B
,	O
while	O
simultaneously	O
decreasing	O
the	O
number	O
of	O
degrees	O
of	O
freedom	O
required	O
.	O
As	O
in	O
Langevin	B
dynamics	I
,	O
a	O
thermostat	B
consisting	O
of	O
well-balanced	O
damping	O
and	O
stochastic	O
terms	O
is	O
applied	O
to	O
each	O
particle	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
unlike	O
in	O
Langevin	B
dynamics	I
,	O
both	O
terms	O
are	O
pairwise	O
and	O
the	O
damping	O
term	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
relative	O
velocities	O
,	O
leading	O
to	O
the	O
conservation	O
of	O
both	O
the	O
angular	B
momentum	I
and	O
the	O
linear	B
momentum	I
.	O
The	O
property	O
of	O
Galilean	B
invariance	I
(	O
i.e.	O
,	O
the	O
dependence	B
on	I
the	I
relative	I
velocity	I
)	O
makes	O
DPD	B
a	O
profile-unbiased	B
thermostat	I
(	O
PUT	B
)	O
[	O
6,7	O
]	O
by	O
construction	O
and	O
thus	O
it	O
is	O
an	O
ideal	O
thermostat	O
for	O
nonequilibrium	B
molecular	I
dynamics	I
(	I
NEMD	I
)	I
[	O
8	O
]	O
.	O
The	O
momentum	O
is	O
expected	O
to	O
propagate	O
locally	O
(	O
while	O
global	O
momentum	O
is	O
conserved	O
)	O
and	O
thus	O
the	O
correct	O
hydrodynamics	O
is	O
expected	O
in	O
DPD	B
[	O
8	O
]	O
,	O
as	O
demonstrated	O
previously	O
in	O
[	O
9	O
]	O
.	O
Due	O
to	O
the	O
aforementioned	O
properties	O
,	O
DPD	O
has	O
been	O
widely	O
used	O
to	O
recover	B
thermodynamic	I
,	I
dynamical	I
,	I
and	I
rheological	I
properties	I
of	O
complex	B
fluids	I
,	O
with	O
applications	O
in	O
polymer	B
solutions	I
[	O
10	O
]	O
,	O
colloidal	B
suspensions	I
[	O
11	O
]	O
,	O
multiphase	B
flows	I
[	O
12	O
]	O
,	O
and	O
biological	B
systems	I
[	O
13	O
]	O
.	O

Bullet	B
:	O

Bandwidth	B
Data	B
Dissemination	I
Using	O
an	O
Overlay	O
Mesh	O
ABSTRACT	O
In	O
recent	O
years	O
,	O
overlay	O
networks	O
have	O
become	O
an	O
effective	O
alternative	O
to	O
IP	B
multicast	I
for	O
efficient	O
point	O
to	O
multipoint	B
communication	I
across	O
the	O
Internet	O
.	O
Typically	O
,	O
nodes	O
self-organize	O
with	O
the	O
goal	O
of	O
forming	O
an	O
efficient	O
overlay	O
tree	O
,	O
one	O
that	O
meets	O
performance	O
targets	O
without	O
placing	O
undue	O
burden	O
on	O
the	O
underlying	O
network	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
we	O
target	O
high-bandwidth	O
data	O
distribution	O
from	O
a	O
single	O
source	O
to	O
a	O
large	O
number	O
of	O
receivers	O
.	O
Applications	O
include	O
large-file	O
transfers	O
and	O
real-time	O
multimedia	O
streaming	O
.	O
For	O
these	O
applications	O
,	O
we	O
argue	O
that	O
an	O
overlay	O
mesh	O
,	O
rather	O
than	O
a	O
tree	O
,	O
can	O
deliver	O
fundamentally	O
higher	O
bandwidth	B
and	O
reliability	O
relative	O
to	O
typical	O
tree	O
structures	O
.	O
This	O
paper	O
presents	O
Bullet	B
,	O
a	O
scalable	O
and	O
distributed	O
algorithm	O
that	O
enables	O
nodes	O
spread	O
across	O
the	O
Internet	O
to	O
self-organize	O
into	O
a	O
high	O
bandwidth	B
overlay	O
mesh	O
.	O
We	O
construct	O
Bullet	B
around	O
the	O
insight	O
that	O
data	O
should	O
be	O
distributed	O
in	O
a	O
disjoint	O
manner	O
to	O

points	O
in	O
the	O
network	O
.	O
Individual	O
Bullet	B
receivers	O
are	O
then	O
responsible	O
for	O
locating	O
and	O
retrieving	O
the	O
data	O
from	O
multiple	O
points	O
in	O
parallel	O
.	O
Key	O

of	O
this	O
work	O
include	O
:	O
i	O
-RRB-	O
an	O
algorithm	O
that	O

data	O
to	O
different	O

in	O

to	O

at	O
any	O
node	O
,	O
ii	O
-RRB-	O
a	O
scalable	O
and	O

that	O
allows	O
nodes	O
to	O
locate	O
and	O
recover	O
missing	O
data	O
items	O
,	O
and	O
iii	O
-RRB-	O
a	O

and	O

of	O

running	O
across	O
the	O

a	O

environment	O
reveals	O
up	O
to	O
a	O
factor	O
two	O
bandwidth	B
improvements	O
under	O
a	O

of	O
circumstances	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
we	O
find	O
that	O
,	O

to	O
tree-based	O
solutions	O
,	O

.	O

a	O
tree	O
,	O

node	O

.	O

.	O

Fuzzy	O
control	O
of	O
multivariable	B
process	I
by	O
modified	B
error	I
decoupling	I
In	O
this	O
paper	O
,	O
a	O
control	O
concept	O
for	O
the	O
squared	O
-LRB-	O
equal	O
number	O
of	O
inputs	O
and	O
outputs	O
-RRB-	O
multivariable	B
process	I
systems	O
is	O
given	O
.	O
The	O
proposed	O
control	O
system	O
consists	O
of	O
two	O
parts	O
,	O
single	O
loop	O
fuzzy	O
controllers	O
in	O
each	O
loop	O
and	O
a	O
centralized	B
decoupling	I
unit	I
.	O
The	O
fuzzy	O
control	O
system	O
uses	O
feedback	B
control	I
to	O
minimize	O
the	O
error	O
in	O
the	O
loop	O
and	O
the	O
decoupler	O
uses	O
an	O
adaptive	O
technique	O
to	O
mitigate	O
loop	O
interactions	O
.	O
The	O
decoupler	O
predicts	O
the	O
interacting	O
loop	O
changes	O
and	O
modifies	O
the	O
input	O
-LRB-	O
error	O
-RRB-	O
of	O
the	O
loop	O
controller	O
.	O

The	O

Improving	O

In	O

how	O
sharing	O
advance	B
demand	I
information	I
-LRB-	O
ADI	O
-RRB-	O
can	O
improve	O
supply-chain	O
performance	O
.	O
We	O
consider	O
two	O
types	O
of	O
ADI	O
,	O
aggregated	B
ADI	I
-LRB-	O
A-ADI	O
-RRB-	O
and	O
detailed	B
ADI	I
-LRB-	O
D-ADI	O
-RRB-	O
.	O
With	O

,	O
customers	O
share	O
with	O
manufacturers	B
information	O
about	O
whether	O
they	O
will	O

for	O
some	O

in	O
the	O
next	O
time	O
period	O
,	O
but	O
do	O
not	O
share	O
information	O
about	O
which	O
product	O
they	O
will	O
order	O
and	O
which	O
of	O
several	O
potential	O
manufacturers	B
will	O
receive	O
the	O
order	O
.	O
With	O

customers	O

share	O
information	O
about	O
which	O
product	O
they	O
will	O
order	O
,	O
but	O
which	O
manufacturer	B
will	O
receive	O
the	O
order	O
remains	O
uncertain	O
.	O
We	O
develop	O
and	O
solve	O
mathematical	B
models	I
of	O
supply	O
chains	O
where	O
ADI	O
is	O
shared	O
.	O
We	O

expressions	O
and	O
closed-form	B
approximations	I
for	O
expected	B
costs	I
,	O
expected	B
base-stock	I
levels	I
,	O
and	O
variations	O
of	O
the	O
production	O

.	O

show	O
that	O

manufacturer	B

ADI	O
,	O

the	O
bullwhip	B
effect	I
.	O
We	O

.	O

demand	I

.	O

Least	B
load	I
dispatching	I
algorithm	I
for	O
parallel	B
Web	I
server	I
nodes	I
A	O
least	B
load	I
dispatching	I
algorithm	I
for	O
distributing	O
requests	O
to	O
parallel	B
Web	I
server	I
nodes	I
is	O
described	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
algorithm	O
,	O
the	O
load	O
offered	O
to	O
a	O
node	O
by	O
a	O
request	O
is	O
estimated	O
based	O
on	O
the	O
expected	O
transfer	B
time	I
of	O
the	O
corresponding	O
reply	O
through	O
the	O
Internet	B
.	O
This	O
loading	O
information	O
is	O
then	O
used	O
by	O
the	O
algorithm	O
to	O
identify	O
the	O
least	O
load	O
node	O
of	O
the	O
Web	O
site	O
.	O
By	O
using	O
this	O
algorithm	O
,	O
each	O
request	O
will	O
always	O
be	O
sent	O
for	O
service	O
at	O
the	O
earliest	O
possible	O
time	O
.	O
Performance	O
comparison	O
using	O
NASA	O
and	O
ClarkNet	B
access	I
logs	I
between	O
the	O
proposed	O
algorithm	O
and	O
commonly	O
used	O
dispatching	O
algorithms	O
is	O
performed	O
.	O
The	O
results	O
show	O
that	O
the	O
proposed	O
algorithm	O
gives	O
10	O
%	O
higher	O
throughput	B
than	O
that	O
of	O
the	O
commonly	O
used	O
random	O
and	O
round-robin	B
dispatching	I
algorithms	I

MRP	B
in	O
a	O
job	B
shop	I
environment	I
using	O
a	O
resource	O
constrained	O
project	O
scheduling	B
model	O
One	O

,	O

In	O

we	O

that	O
material	B
requirements	I
planning	I
can	O

a	O
job	B
shop	I
environment	I

a	O

project	O
scheduling	B
model	O
.	O
The	O
proposed	O
model	O

models	O
by	O
incorporating	O
capacity	B
constraints	I
and	O
using	O
variable	B
lead	I
time	I
lengths	I
.	O
The	O

of	O
this	O
approach	O
is	O
tested	O
on	O

systems	O

comparing	O
the	O
inventory	B
carrying	I
costs	I
and	O
resource	B
allocation	I
of	O
the	O
solutions	O

by	O
the	O
proposed	O
model	O
to	O

obtained	O
by	O
using	O
a	O

model	O
.	O

,	O

is	O

that	O

proposed	O
model	O
provides	O
improved	O
schedules	B
with	O
considerable	O
reductions	O
in	O
inventory	B
carrying	I
costs	I

Even	B
unimodular	I
Gaussian	I
lattices	I
of	O
rank	O
12	O
We	O
classify	O
even	B
unimodular	I
Gaussian	I
lattices	I
of	O
rank	O
12	O
,	O
that	O
is	O
,	O
even	B
unimodular	I
integral	I
lattices	I
of	O
rank	O
12	O
over	O
the	O
ring	O
of	O
Gaussian	B
integers	I
.	O
This	O
is	O
equivalent	O

dependent	I

is	O

of	O

.	O

.	O

.	O

shape	B
